But the content of the post itself does not get processed, markdown and liquid tags are just output in the browser.
Is this expected behavior?
I tried digging around but couldnt find anything about it.

title: Window hint isn't being set to float
body: (PD) I use the i3 window manager where windows are tiled instead of floated by default.

(PD) The way the window manager decides which windows should float and which should tile, is to look at the hints set by the application so that if a window really needs to float for whatever reason, it gets to do that.

(PD) The SparkleShare GUI looks really, really bad when it gets tiled, I'm almost certain it's intended to float, however the application doesn't set the appropriate hint to tell the wm this by default, this should probably be fixed.
do you know what this hint is and how to set it?
i've never heard of this window manager before.
(M) Hmm, I think it is _NET_WM_WINDOW_TYPE_DIALOG mentioned in http://standards.freedesktop.org/wm-spec/latest/ar01s05.html that would be the correct hint to set.
(P) you mentioned on IRC that the fix on the i3fix branch works.
(M) i've applied it to the about dialog now as well.
(P) i'll close this issue now and will merge the branch when i have access to my Linux box again.

title: Error building lilypond 2.13.36
body: I have a configure error when I try to install lilypond.

(PD) It looks like it is missing some font related tools called metafont and metapost:

https://gist.github.com/663255
(P) You need to install TeX first: http://www.tug.org/mactex/
Thanks.

(W) Installed mactex, now I'm getting an error during lilypond make : 
 Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "/private/tmp/homebrew-lilypond-2.13.36-kkPm/lilypond- 2.13.36/stepmake /bin/install.py", line 78, in  
    shutil.copy2 (f, dest)
   File  "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.6/lib/python2.6/shutil.py", line 99, in copy2
    copyfile(src, dst)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.6/lib/python2.6/shutil.py", line 52, in copyfile
    fsrc = open(src, 'rb')
 IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: './out/emmentaler-11.woff'
 make [1]: *** [local-install-outfiles] Error 1
 make : *** [install] Error 2
 Exit status: 2
I'll try to post more info soon, but in the mean time I just wanted to post this in case you already have an idea what might be wrong.

(P) Turns out the WOFF files are never built, because the fontforge that ships in homebrew today (fontforge 20100501) emits this message when asked to build them:

    This version of fontforge cannot handle WOFF files.
(P) You need to recompile it with libpng and zlib
(P) patched at https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/pull/3692
I'm still getting this error after updating homebrew.
Any ideas?
(W) updated to Lilypond 2.13.52; fontforge is now at 20110222.
Lillypond built OK for me / MacTeX light.

title: Flexible routing scopes
body: (PD) One of the things that I think could make  Devise really handy, and understandable to newcomers is making scopes more flexible for constraints.

(PD) Take this for example:

```ruby
  devise_scope :user, lambda { |user| user.role == "admin"  } do
    root to: "admin#dashboard"
  end
```
or

```ruby
  authenticated :user, lambda { |user| user.role == "admin"  } do
    root to: "admin#dashboard"
  end
```

Each of these is something pretty easily understood, and would provide a bit of clarity to the routes, and clean up any before_filters that you would use instead.
(PD)I've already got a start on an implementation of this, but wanted to know if this make s sense, or maybe there is already a way to do this with Devise as it stands.
(P) Yes, this looks great and make s sense for `authenticate(d)`.
Is there a test for ```authenticate(d)``` I could use as a basis for testing these?
(W) And how does the implementation look?
Anything I should clean up?
Thanks!
(P) The implementation looks good, but could you please use (`&&` and `||`) instead of `and` and `or`?

(P) About the tests, you will need to define new routes here:

https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/master/test/rails_app/config/routes.rb

And then add new tests for these routes inside this test case (where we keep tests for authenticated, unauthenticated, and so on):

https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/master/test/integration/authenticatable_test.rb#L137
Thanks José!
(W) I added some tests and changed to the boolean logic like you mentioned.
Anything else?
Meeeeeeerged, thanks!

title: use the same logic for selecting extra attributes in addSbtPlugin as in pluginProjectId
body:
This enables us to use the same plugins.sbt in projects for release and
pre-release versions of sbt.

(PD) Right now you have to use

    addSbtPlugin(org % name % version, sbtVersion = "0.12.0-Beta2")

to suport add a plugin for the beta version of sbt.
(PD) This, however, means you have to update your scripted tests for each (pre-) release version of sbt to find the plugin you are testing.

(PD) With this change the declaration stays

     addSbtPlugin(org % name % version)

regardless of the sbt version you are using.
(MD) This is a follow-up to https://groups.google.com/d/msg/simple-build-tool/hIcElXd38xw/nn1muiC6yfEJ
Merged in https://github.com/harrah/xsbt/commit/8f14df193062e079f0caee43dbd586256ae43e76
Thanks, Mark.

title: Denial-of-service prevention
body: The big idea: if a peer is sending you obviously wrong information, punish it by maybe dropping your connection to it, and ban it's IP address so it cannot immediately re-connect.
The probability of dropping the connection, and the length of the ban, depend on how wrong, and how potentially wasteful/damaging, the peer is.
So sending an extra 'version' message is a minor transgression that is usually tolerated, sending an more than MAX_BLOCK_SIZE block is a major transgression.

(PD) Detailed how-it-works, using "I got a version message I wasn't expecting" as the specific example:

Getting a version message from a peer increases that peer's 'misbehaving' score by 10, and (assuming that is the peer's first bad behavior) gives it a 10% of being disconnected.
(MD) If it is disconnected, then that peer's IP address is banned from connecting for a couple of hours.
(MD) If it is not disconnected, then nothing happens unless the peer misbehaves again; if it does, then its chances of being disconnected go up, and the length of time it will be banned increases.
(MD) Misbehavior/ban information is stored only in memory, and information about misbehaving peers is never broadcast.
(PD) Also, peers that are disconnected/banned are just dropped, there is no warning or reason sent.
(PD) I think this will eliminate a lot of potential denial-of-service attacks, and could be a good framework for responding to other potential attacks.

(PD) "We" should still look through the code and limit the potential size of any data structures that an attacker might target (transaction pool, orphan block pool); the DoSprevention changes are meant to make  it harder for an attacker to stay connected long enough to pull off an attack.
The danger is that I got something wrong; what if an attacker can leverage the DoSprevention code to split or shatter the network?

(PD) Here's my thinking on that, please help check my work:

+ I'm relying on TCP to prevent IP address spoofing (otherwise an attacker could force you to disconnect from your peers by pretending to be them and sending you a bad block).
(MD) + Peers are only penalized for sending messages that won't, and shouldn't, get relayed.
(MD) So an attacker shouldn't be able to poison the network with a bad message that is propogated and then causes everybody to disconnect from everybody else.
(MD) + I specifically do not punish peers for relaying what look like double-spend transactions.

(MD) If I did, then an attacker could try to segment the network into two pieces by broadcasting a series of double-spends from two halves of the network, and waiting until the nodes "in the middle" disconnected/banned across the 'seam'.
So: please let me know if or how I'm being an idiot.

(PD) I'm still thinking about the best way of testing this; at the very least, running a node for several days with this patch applied should result in a minimal number of "disconnected %s for misbheavior" messages in debug.log.

(P) The only other thing to worry about is that someone working on client development might inadvertently run a buggy version of the client and wind up locked out of parts of the network for a few hours.
(P) I would add one other change to help prevent this.
(P) When you 'punish' an IP, check to see if you made the connection to them or they connected to you.
(M) If they connected to you, punish them for a few hours.
(P) If you connected to them, just don't connect to them for a few hours, still let them connect to you.
(P) That way, unless you're actually malicious or make  large numbers of outbound connections accidentally, you'll only get locked out for hours of a small number of peers.
(M) Someone trying to launch a DoS attack by waiting for people to connect to them will find it slow going.

(M) Also see my post [DoS countermeasures may facilitate network fragmentation attacks](https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=44954.0)
Summary: Pay attention to new block headers with valid hashes of sufficient difficulty even from banned peers.

(P) Rebased into fewer commits, and removed banning due to getting too many free transactions and getting blocks with bad timestamps, because they might have opened up a possible split-the-network attack.

title: Possibility to add members to a group, which are then automatically added/inherited to all the group's projects.
body: (WD) This would be really nice to have, given that where I work, we usually have about 5 people which are _always_ assigned to every project in a certain group.
(PD) On GitHub we use the "Teams" feature for that, but GitLab doesn't seem to have that.

If I haven't made clear what I mean:

1.

(PD) create a group
1.

(MD) Add members to that group
1.

(MD) Add project to the group
    * All members of the **group** are now automatically members of the **project**
PLUS 1!
(W) We're dealing with nearly 40 people now within our system and it's a nightmare to have to manually add or even rake task additions when new projects are created.

For some reason, I assumed that by being a member of a group it would automatically allow you access to the projects contained within, which is why I upgraded from our former, and very useful, 'public' GitLab fork.
Now it is no longer public in a way that is useful for our organization.
(P) @x3ro  You should flag this as a feature request.
@damassi: I don't think I can add labels to an issue as its creator.
That is left to the repository devs, afaik.

(P) Indeed, until this is implemented, the group functionality is incomplete IMO, and pretty much unmanageable, partly because of the following in addition to the issue mentioned in OP:

- There's no method for updating a user's role within a group (ie, changing a user from reporter to developer)
- There's no method removing a user from a group (other than deleting each one of the user's repository permissions individually)
- Project Access column is unwieldy with many users and projects (cosmetic, low-prio)
@x3ro you see Team functionality?
(P) You can create team, add member, assign project on team.
It is already in master.
(P) @zzet - that doesn't solve the problem, because you can't assign a team to a group.
(P) actually, that alone would probably solve most of my issues, provided the team permissions were automatically applied to new projects.
(W) This bug still needs to be resolved though.
@pdf - in repo Base team functional.
(W) Of course not all implement.

title: jemalloc: make  pprof opt-in
body: (PD) pprof needs to be opt-in as it is supposed to be installed by google-perftools so there is no need for `conflicts_with`.
(W) The fact that it conflicts with another formulae isn't a good reason to just remove a tool.
(W) What if someone wants to use it?
(M) We have a `conflicts_with` DSL field that can be used to annotate and warn users of these conflicts.
(W) What if you want to have two of them installed at the same time ?
(P) The user is advised to unlink one of them when installing the other.
Then doctor complains that you have unlinked kegs.

On Nov 25, 2012, at 9:45 AM, Stefan wrote:
> Is there a reason why you are repackaging pprof, isn't it supposed to come with gperftools ?

On Nov 25, 2012, at 7:15 PM, Jason Evans wrote:
> The heap profiling functionality in jemalloc isn't very useful without pprof.
(W) Also, when I first added heap profiling to jemalloc, there was a critical bug in pprof that remained unfixed for quite some time (IIRC, more than six months, across two releases).
(W) At the time, I had little choice but to package a patched pprof, and even when patches aren't necessary, I think it's a good idea to provide pprof with jemalloc.
(W) however, I'm open to naming it something else to avoid packaging conflicts.
(W) Any suggestions?
pprof-jemalloc is cumbersome, jeprof strikes me as presumptuous (though it matches the default prefix for the files jemalloc outputs), and that's about the extent of my naming creativity.
(P) I could also rename it as `jemalloc-pprof` instead as it might happen upstream too.
(M) Ok, let's install it with a rename and remove the conflicts-with.
Thanks for following up here.
(W) updated.
(P) `jemalloc-pprof`, `pprof-jemalloc` would one be preferable over other one ?
`jemalloc-pprof`

title: Httpfoundation\Request::preparePathInfo() returns incorrect path
body:
(WD) Hello,
I believe that there's a bug in:
`Symfony\Component\Httpfoundation\Request.php`

We need to host our Symfony2 based application in a subdirectory, and hence cannot set document root to `/web` (as per Symfony Standard Edition).

We're using mod_rewrite to delegate all requests to `/web`:

    RewriteEngine On
    
    # internally rewrite all paths to /web/* (and prevent looping)
    RewriteRule !^web/ web%{REQUEST_URI}
    
    # front-end: allow access to debug mode
    RewriteRule app_dev\.php.

* - [QSA,L]
    
    # front-end: delegate everything else to front-controller
    RewriteRule .

* app.php [QSA,L]

`Request::preparePathInfo()` behaves incorrectly in this case.

Initial values are:
`$baseurl    = /web/app_dev.php`
`$requestUri = /app_dev.php/lorem-ipsum`

The returned value:
`$pathInfo = em-ipsum`

Note that due to the URI rewrite, `$baseurl` contains `/web` (extra 4 characters) while `$requestUrl` does not.

(WD) Due to this the following condition cuts 4 characters from the beginning of `$pathInfo`:

```php
if ((null !== $baseUrl) && (false === ($pathInfo = substr($requestUri, strlen($baseUrl))))) {
```

This affects routing:

* `/web/app_dev.php/lorem-ipsum` - routing works correctly
* `/app_dev.php/lorem-ipsum` - routing does not work without `/web` as prefix, a 404 exception is thrown `... No route found for "GET em-ipsum"` (note the trimmed value, this came from the method described above).
May I please ask you to look into this?
(WD) Please note that I'm new to Symfony2, so I may be appraoching this from a bad angle.
(WD) If there are some actions/settings required to make  Symfony2 work in a subdirectory, I'd be very grateful for any advise.

Thank you for your help,
M.
(M) Using ``app_dev.php`` does not use the rewrite rule at all as it access an existing file.

(W) Hello stof,
actually, it did use the rewrite rule in our case, since the file was physically not in document root, but in `/web` subdirectory (`example.com/app_dev.php` got translated `/path-to-doc-root/web/app_dev.php`).
(P) however we already managed to fix it (so I'll close this ticket), there's no need to update `Request::preparePathInfo()` after all.
(P) The solution is to move the bootstrap files (`app.php` and `app_dev.php`) outside of the `/web` subdirectory, and keep only static files in `/web` (rewrite rules need to be updated accordingly).
(W) Edit: credit for the fix goes to xaav on the [old Symfony forums](http://forum.symfony-project.org/viewtopic.php?p=118836#p118836).
(W) I'll post a small update to the readme file that comes with the standard edition which might help to clarify this for people.

Thank you for looking into this,
M.

title: improve Error and Exception Handling
body: (PD) create a generic SlimException sub-class of Exception.

(MD) This Exception should be used for:

- Slim::error
- Slim::redirect
- Arbitrary exceptions

The Slim::run method will have a try/catch block which will catch any thrown Exceptions and use the Exception status code to set the HTTP status code, and the Exception message as the response body.
(PD) Also, I may change Slim::error to Slim::raise( message, status = 500 ) since this feature may be used for more than just "errors".
This is complete.

(P) Slim::error is now deprecated and has been replaced with Slim::raise( $message, $status = 500 ); A try/catch block now surrounds Slim::run and catches SlimExceptions (thrown with Slim::raise), or other non-fatal Exceptions which trigger a 500 response.
(W) Sorry I didn't get chance to look at this last night - your implementation looks great.
(W) I can see a couple of possible issues that still remain.
One is the question of what happens to exceptions thrown outside the `run` method.
Both the `Router` and the `View` throw `RuntimeException`s which are currently unhandled.
Should these also trigger a 500 error?
(M) This could be done explicitly (`try`/`catch` block) or we could use `set_exception_handler` to catch everything.
Also, what happens if PHP throws an error rather than an exception?
(M) Should these also be handled somehow, with `set_error_handler` perhaps?
Good catch.
Looks like I overlooked these last night.
(P) I can setup a global exception and error handler which both create and send a stand-alone Response object independent of the actual Slim app.

title: Add arguments to pyphantomjs.main().
body: Cf http://code.google.com/p/phantomjs/issues/detail?id=296
Looks good.
(P) just one small tiny detail.. Due to Python [PEP8](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/) formatting, can you remove the spaces for the default argument?
E.g.
`def main(arguments=None):`.
Thanks for your contribution!
Done.
(P) I've decided that I'm not going to make  the arguments parameter optional, which allows us to remove the `if arguments is None:` part.
(P) This make s everything more elegant in my opinion.
(P) We'd just simply provide `sys.argv[1:]` in the main initializer instead.
You can do this modification, or I can do it after the pull request is integrated.
Whatever you prefer.

```python
if __name__ == '__main__':
    sys.exit(main(sys.argv[1:]))
```
Done.
(P) I added a second commit for passing the "arguments" argument to QApplication, which must not read the original sys.argv.
Is it right ?
(P) QApplication must always have at least one valid character string, so for that we can keep `sys.argv[0]`.
(M) As for `arguments`, it's fine to add those in, that way QApplication will always get the correct arguments.

(P) although, for `sys.argv[0:] + arguments`, if we use `sys.argv` for the arguments, then all the arguments will be repeated all over, so it should suffice to just do `[sys.argv[0]] + arguments` instead.
(M) I meant [sys.argv[0] + arguments, sorry.
I squashed the commits and committed manually.
Thanks a lot!

sio = StringIO.new(Base64.decode64('base64 String goes here'))

```

body: (WD) This seems to report errors regarding linking and/or installing.

==> ./configure --prefix=/usr/local/Cellar/hunspell/1.3.2 --disable-debug --with-ui --with-readline
==> make 
==> make  install
ln: hunspell.mo: Permission denied
Error: The linking step did not complete successfully
The formula built, but is not symlinked into /usr/local
You can try again using `brew link hunspell'
==> Summary
/usr/local/Cellar/hunspell/1.3.2: 49 files, 1.3M, built in 21 seconds
(M) Try running `brew doctor` and see what is says.
(P) probably something previously installed created some share/locale folders with root ownership.
(W) Fair enough, that seems to be the case.
There are certainly _many_ brew doctor reported issues!

(P) I'd like to suggest that the search path should, by default, include ~/Library/Spelling as otherwise, it does not search the per user directory for dictionaries - unless the cwd is the users home directory

george-russells-imac:~ grrussel$ hunspell -D
SEARCH PATH:
.

::/usr/share/hunspell:/usr/share/myspell:/usr/share/myspell/dicts:/Library/Spelling:/Users/grrussel/.openoffice.org/3/user/wordbook:.openoffice.org2/user/wordbook:.openoffice.org2.0/user/wordbook:Library/Spelling:/opt/openoffice.org/basis3.0/share/dict/ooo:/usr/lib/openoffice.org/basis3.0/share/dict/ooo:/opt/openoffice.org2.4/share/dict/ooo:/usr/lib/openoffice.org2.4/share/dict/ooo:/opt/openoffice.org2.3/share/dict/ooo:/usr/lib/openoffice.org2.3/share/dict/ooo:/opt/openoffice.org2.2/share/dict/ooo:/usr/lib/openoffice.org2.2/share/dict/ooo:/opt/openoffice.org2.1/share/dict/ooo:/usr/lib/openoffice.org2.1/share/dict/ooo:/opt/openoffice.org2.0/share/dict/ooo:/usr/lib/openoffice.org2.0/share/dict/ooo

(P) The issue here is that something else installed to /usr/local/share and change permissions so Homebrew can't create folders as your user:

````
ln /usr/local/share/locale/it/LC_MESSAGES/hunspell.mo
ln /usr/local/share/locale/hu/LC_MESSAGES/hunspell.mo
````

You should `chown` back /usr/local/share and then this should install with no problem.

title: suport 'file' scheme
body: (WD) I was using urllib on a project and decided to change to requests, but I was using a mix of 'http' and 'file' schemes on some scenarios which is handled by urllib.
(PD) I know requests is mostly about network and doesn't make  much sense to use for files but transparency would be useful.
(WD) Would this be possible?
(P) I'm pretty sure this suport would have to be added to urllib3 (or if it's already there, the vendorized package would have to be updated).
(P) @shazow might be a better person to talk to about this.
In the meantime, I'll see if it's part of urllib3.
(P) It could be done on the requests side since `file` scheme won't be doing any network-based work nor does it require any connection pooling.
For those reasons I'm also uncomfortable adding it into urllib3.
:/ What do you think, @kennethreitz?
(P) Once we have transport adapters, this will be really easy to write, but this is currently one of the biggest problems with urllib2.
Massive security exploit.
(P) I use requests to do scraping and we have html files of the pages we scrape that we want to use for tests.

(P) We wanted to just tell requests the path to these files instead of the URL of the site, but because of this bug we need to go write some custom code now to check the scheme, using requests accordingly.
(P) This means we have to add functionality to our codebase to suport our tests, which is certainly not ideal.
Don't know what transport adapters are, so can't comment on that, but thought I'd put a use case in here in case it's useful.
(P) You have two options.
(M) The first is to write a custom Transport Adapter, which isn't very hard.
(P) Unfortunately, this won't work in the current version of Requests, which insists you have both a netloc (e.g.
hostname) and a path.
A `file` URL does not have a netloc, so we throw exceptions.
(P) The second option is to run a local webserver to host the files for testing.
(M) You can do that very easily: go to the directory the files are in and run `python -m SimpleHTTPServer`.

(P) I tried using the SimpleHTTPServer as mentioned above, but I don't want to have to start it up before running my tests, and if you start it as part of the setUp or setUpClass method in your unittests, there's no way to tear it down in the tearDown method.
(M) This leaves you with frustrating issues around tied up addresses and "Address already in use" exceptions.
(P) Beyond that, starting up a server just to do local file access seems like the wrong appraoch in a unittest.

r.status_code = 200
            except IOError as e:
                r.status_code = 404
                raise ConnectionError(e)

            r._content_consumed = True

            #: Final URL location of Response.

r.url = self.url

            #: Resulting :class:`HTTPError` of request, if one occurred.

self.error = None

            #: Encoding to decode with when accessing r.content.

(P) self.encoding = None

            #: The :class:`Request <Request>` that created the Response.

self.request = self

            # Return the response.

(P) return r

This is currently working in my unit tests, where I can easily change the request.method to "LOCAL", and then use the MockRequest object instead of a standard one.
(M) I only took the most cursory dive into the requests library, but maybe something like this would provide a useful tool to people using requests in testing environments.
(W) Is this something that could be added to Requests, in lieu of the other options above, which it seems wont' be moving forward any time soon?
(W) I'm glad you got something working for your use case, @mlissner!
(P) I doubt Requests will ever have direct suport in the main library for the `file:` URL scheme.
(M) Aside from Kenneth's point above about it being a security risk, Requests is strictly an HTTP library.
(M) `file:` URLs do not use HTTP, so they're outside the Requests use case.

(P) If you wanted a more transparent example, you should be able to use something like this:

```python
import requests
from cStringIO import StringIO

class TestAdapter(requests.adapters.HTTPAdapter):
    urlmap = {'http://www.google.com/', '/home/lukasa/test.html'}

    def send(self, request, **kwargs):
        try:
            rsp = open(urlmap[request.url])
            status = 200
        except IOError:
            rsp = StringIO()
            status = 404

        response = requests.Response()
        response.status_code = status
        response.headers = {}
        response.encoding = None
        response.raw = rsp
        response.url = request.url
        response.request = request
        response.connection = self
       
        return response
```

Mounting that transport adapter _should_ (I haven't tested it) provide you with the behaviour you want.
Thanks @Lukasa.
(W) I gave that a whirl and tried to make  it work for a bit, but I ran into an error I can't get past.

(W) This line is the one causing trouble: https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/blob/master/requests/cookies.py#L109

From what I can tell, setting response.raw to a file or StringIO object won't work because: 

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/mlissner/Programming/intellij/juriscraper/tests/tests.py", line 43, in test_scrape_all_example_files
    site.parse()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/juriscraper/GenericSite.py", line 85, in parse
    self.html = self._download()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/juriscraper/GenericSite.py", line 238, in _download
    r = s.get(self.url, headers={'User-Agent': 'Juriscraper'})
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 347, in get
    return self.request('GET', url, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 335, in request
    resp = self.send(prep, **send_kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 446, in send
    extract_cookies_to_jar(self.cookies, request, r.raw)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/requests/cookies.py", line 108, in extract_cookies_to_jar
    res = MockResponse(response._original_response.msg)
AttributeError: 'file' object has no attribute '_original_response'
```

I'm not sure how to proceed with this, though I read your FTP Adapter code and blog entry (but there's not much else on transport adapters yet!).
(W) I'm tempted to say that not allowing file-like objects is a bug, but I know that's been closed before as a wont-fix.
(M) I've also gotten the impression that _original_response shouldn't be used for anything (though it is used in cookie.py).
(P) So...I'm confused how to make  this work properly, whether _original_response shouldn't be used the way it is, and what the proper fix for this should be.
(W) That's an interesting bug.

(M) Could you perhaps trying using @kanzure's 
requestions?

(P) I suspect that's probably getting a little long in the tooth but 
it probably works around that issue if I remember it correctly.

(P) I forget, 
however, whether it uses transport adapters.
@sigmavirus24 I took a look at requestions, but don't see any use of adapters (or workarounds) in there.
(P) Regardless, I'd rather avoid the dependency if possible.
Roger that.
(W) I can confirm that I don't remember if I added suport for adapters in kanzure/requestions.

title: d3.geo.area and d3_geo_clipAreaRing should be consistent.
body: (MD) Already being worked on by @jasondavies, but creating an issue to track this feature.
(MD) The end goal is that topojson, d3.geo.area and d3_geo_clipAreaRing use the same algorithm to guarantee consistent winding order detection.
(PD) (although, this issue will likely become less critical when topojson removes features smaller than the simplification threshold.)
(W) Couple observations so far.
First, why is there an arc whose second coordinate is [0,0]?
(M) Coincident vertexes should be skipped.
(P) So, the fact that the polygon isn't precisely closed is the reason in this case that topojson and d3 disagree on the area.
(P) since d3.geo.stream doesn't visit the last coordinate in the polygon, d3.geo.area uses the first coordinate of the ring as the closing coordinate, whereas topojson uses the last coordinate.
(P) I'll add some checks to topojson to (make  SURE) that polygons are closed.
(P) This was a bug with ring rotation (mbostock/topojson#36) in TopoJSON that I introduced two days ago, and have since fixed.
Some flickering has resurfaced in http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/raw/4183330/ (when it gets to Burundi).
(W) Hey @jasondavies, do you think this is the same bug, or something else?
I’ll investigate more tomorrow.
(M) I think there’s an edge case that I don’t handle properly when clipping against a circle, e.g.
(P) when a polygon just touches the clip edge or just intersects slightly.
(P) I’ve seen this somewhere else in a simpler test case, so I’ll try fixing that and see if that solves it.
(P) I’ll also check to see whether the CCW detection is at fault here, but I don’t think it is.

There are two pieces of code that can cause this type of problem (insertion of an edge around the clipping region, either entirely or almost entirely):

1.
(P) CCW detection: when a polygon does not intersect with the clip edge, its winding order is checked so we know whether to draw an edge along the entire clip edge.
(P) This should rarely occur with real-world polygons because it means the polygon entirely surrounds the clip edge (so the antimeridian or the small-circle)!

(P) If a polygon *does* intersect with the clip edge, then some care needs to be taken to avoid coincident intersection points along the edge, otherwise the algorithm may inadvertently swap two points as they get ordered along the clip edge.
(P) This can happen if a polygon just touches the clip edge, for instance.
(P) Random jittering can solve this one.
(P) Note that self-intersecting polygons exacerbate this, because coincident points could intersect (at the self-intersection point), and it’s more work to detect this case.
(W) Having said all of this, it’s strange that the flickering has surfaced in this particular example just now, so I’ll check for coincident points and self-intersections in this world-110m.json too.
(W) It’s quite likely that my recent changes to TopoJSON have surfaced this bug.
(W) And it’s possible (as before!)
(W) that the bug is in TopoJSON.
(W) although, that is becoming less likely as I write more tests for TopoJSON.

(P) I have created a simple test case here (currently land, but I can reduce it to the offending country shortly): 

http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/a957ca28e262f3fced9e

Edit: reduced it to the major polygon in Antarctica.
Interestingly, flickering in the rotating world tour example goes away when I use a clip angle of 90° rather than 87°.
(P) The above fixes both the test case and the tour to Burundi.
(W) Jason, do you think it’s okay to close this bug now?
I feel like we’ve squashed the various issues with winding-order detection.

(P) The detection methods are not yet consistent (we still use an approximate algorithm for winding order detection when clipping), but I don’t mind if you want to close the bug or change milestone as I don’t know of anything that is affected by this at the moment.
(M) When my clipPolygon stuff lands, it will reuse the more accurate d3.geo.area algorithm.
There are some issues with performance and the way I handle degeneracies that I’d like to tackle first before merging though.
(P) fix staged in #1285 for 3.2.

title: Exception after removing twig template file in dev mode
body: (WD) The bootstrap cache tries to evaluate whether a file is outdated using filemtime, which obviously fails if the file has been deleted: Version: Symfony RC3 ErrorException: Warning: filemtime() [function.filemtime]: stat failed for D:\Symfony\src\XXX\YYYBundle/Resources/views/Front/stories.html.twig in D:\Symfony\vendor\symfony\src\Symfony\Bundle\FrameworkBundle\Templating\Loader\FilesystemLoader.php line 68 (uncaught exception) at D:\Symfony\app\bootstrap.php.cache line 528
I tried and couldn't reproduce the issue, if I delete a twig template, it correctly throws an exception saying it can not find the template.
Can you reproduce it reliably?
(W) If you can't fix it yourself providing more information would be great.
(W) @Seldaek it just occured to me when switching to another older branch of the git repo that don't have the template
(P) Well then maybe you can fix it ;) If I delete any template used on the page I'm looking at here it throws an exception.
(W) @Seldaek The template is not used on the current page (I don't understand why it checks the cache for another template btw)

Call the action again

=> Exception thrown

 b.

(P) Call another action of the same controller

=> Exception thrown

* Also delete the action itself, then call another action of that controller

=> Exception still thrown

Clearing the caches obviously fixes the problem :)

Hope this helps
(M) Note that the issue is not related to SensioFrameworkExtraBundle as I had it without using SensioFrameworkExtraBundle

The issue is in AsseticBundle:

Notified event "kernel.request" to listener "Symfony\Bundle\FrameworkBundle\EventListener\SessionListener::onKernelRequest".
Notified event "kernel.request" to listener "Symfony\Component\Security\Http\Firewall::onKernelRequest".
Notified event "kernel.request" to listener "Symfony\Bundle\FrameworkBundle\EventListener\RouterListener::onKernelRequest".
Notified event "kernel.request" to listener "Symfony\Bundle\AsseticBundle\EventListener\RequestListener::onKernelRequest".
Notified event "kernel.controller" to listener "Symfony\Bundle\FrameworkBundle\DataCollector\RequestDataCollector::onKernelController".
I will look into this.

(P) @fabpot By looking more deeper, the real issue occurs in both TwigBundle and Twig: the filesystem loaders are serialized in the asseticResource but they keep their lookup cache when serializing them.
(M) and so they don't throw a Twig_Error_Loader when the template does not exist anymore and so ``filemtime`` is called.
(M) Assetic should not serialize the Twig loaders.
(P) But it needs it to check if the template is still fresh or not as the template is a resource for the routing.
I added an issue on AsseticBundle for this: https://github.com/symfony/AsseticBundle/issues/17

(W) @fabpot: Assetic uses templates as configuration files and needs to be able to serialize resource objects that expose the contents of the template and its mtime so it can smartly manage its cache.
(M) I have not been able to accomplish this without serializing the loader object.
(W) this is a bug in AsseticBundle (and there is a ticket on it) so closing this one

title: Single Post View WIP
body: Second stab at this.

(PD) This is a different appraoch at the problem; rather than trying to revert back to a "Pre-Backbone" single post view, this instead is an attempt to restyle the layout to feel much more natural and less invasive.
(PD) I'd like to make  a balance between legibility and ease of composing responses.

DONE:
1.
(MD) Disabled post-nav in Single Post.
(MD) Restyled comment box.
(PD) Interaction pane is now permanently open, and stands at full height without the need to scroll.
(PD)  because this is now based on the Single Post View in upstream, no tests should fail on it.
(PD) improved typography of post, may need a second go-around just for the sake of being uniform with the rest of the application.
(PD) Remove unnecessary hiding/invoking functionality for comments, as that's no longer needed.
(MD) Interactions pane now sits directly under the body of the posted content.
(MD) All posts now use the same template, meaning no more wallpaper posts.
(MD) Incidentally, embedded videos look nicer with the unified post template.
(MD) Remove processing for text header, which currently is done after the first line break in a post.

TODO:

1.
(MD) Ensure comments are in proper order (mine for some reason are in reverse order somehow?)
(PD) make  clicking the comment icon automatically scroll to comment box (maybe something like scroll-spy would be useful here?)

(PD) Comment box currently shrinks while it's being typed in (probably a styling issue, just needs some tweaking)
4.
(PD) Bring in the Navigation header used in the rest of Diaspora, for easy-access to messages, notifications, contacts, and settings.
(PD) Strip out unused post-picker templates.

Latest commit strips out the unnecessary "headline" stuff, allowing for the entire post to be rendered in a uniform manner.

1.

Additionally, I've looked into the oEmbed bits for the single-post view.
(P) Adding suport for Instagram, SoundCloud, and other non-video providers will take a little extra bit of work to get going, and I believe it is out of the scope of this PR.
(P) I'd be happy to work on that next, or if someone who has experience with working with oEmbed, such as @Ruxton would be willing to help with that, more power to him.
What's different for oEmbed in the single post view than in the stream view?
Correct, there's only one post-viewer "mood" now, which is Newspaper.
This can be titled to something else if necessary.
(P) I'd like to strip the other templates out, but really I just wanted to make  a functional SPV first.
(P) oEmbed in SPV is different because of things like app/assets/templates/oembed_tpl.jst.hbs, which seems to check whether the oEmbed content is a video or not.
(P) If it's a video, it gets rendered, if not, it seems to just be left as a link.
(M) I think we should get rid of the grey background, replace the home button with the header again and use a slightly larger font-size.
(P) And maybe use the full width of the page, splitting in the middle for post content on one side and interactions on the other.
(W) So basically make  our SPV like Libertree's?
:P

(W) Basically..... :P


If there's only one mood why is that system needed at all?
Can't we drop it?
(P) What if we just compose a new single post view out of the Views the stream uses?
(W) Wouldn't we get oEmbed suport from it for free?
(P) We can probably drop the mood system easily enough, but if we took your solution of composing an entirely new view using stream elements, does it really matter?
(P) If we take that option, most of the work here will be rendered irrelevant anyway, and most of the existing single-post stuff could probably just be purged out of D*.

(P) I'm not against constructing a new view if it's necessary, but that's a little beyond the scope of what was to be accomplished here, that is, repurposing an existing view to be more usable than before.
(P) I like the work of Sean here and the "page" appraoch, this is great for sharing articles / big texts, exactly the kind of stuff which are not really good rendered in the stream.
So about the design, I'd say it's good !
What about merge that in develop and listen about remarks from the users ?
(W) I'm not against Mr. ZYX's appraoch.

(P) In some ways, I think the view could
actually be quite a bit more usable than what I've got, especially when
lengthy content is used.

(P) Being able to see the content and comments
simultaneously without obstructing one another is good usability, IMO.

On Thursday, February 21, 2013, Antoine D. wrote:

> I like the work of Sean here and the "page" appraoch, this is great for
> sharing articles / big texts, exactly the kind of stuff which are not
> really good rendered in the stream.
So about the design, I'd say it's good !

>

>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/diaspora/diaspora/pull/3942#issuecomment-13909315>.
(P) I've created an ongoing discussion [here](https://www.loomio.org/discussions/2110) to see what our end users and developers think.
Feel free to chime in.
(P) Closing this PR; having discussed a much better set of ideas and implementation on Loomio, I would like to start over from scratch once we've settled on a final design.
(P) This here is just a bit too messy; starting over to build exactly what the project wants would be much easier.

title: STI table organization
body: The STI table minimum is `id` and `type` fields.
And in Rails docs mentioned that you should add `type` to all of your indexes in such table, but why initial table creation does not do this with `PRIMARY KEY` ?

(PD) Talking about MySQL version (any other DB should handle this well too) I have to do

```ruby
    create_table(:sti_objects, id: false) do |t|
      t.integer :id
      t.string  :type

      #... my fields

      t.timestamps
    end

    ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute "ALTER TABLE `messages` ADD PRIMARY KEY (`id`, `type`)"
    ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute "ALTER TABLE `messages` MODIFY `id` INT AUTO_INCREMENT"

```

This make s my primary key not only by `id` but on `type` too, which better reflects STI idea and _should_ improve performance on some queries.

(PD) **BUT** this works well with other AR infrastructure **only** if I overload root `StiObject` class method `primary_key` as:

```ruby
class StiObject < ActiveRecord::Base

  def self.primary_key
    'id'
  end
end

```

In other case nothing works, because Rail's AR cannot work with multi-column primary keys as they should be in case of STI by default.
(WD) All this investigation was done with Rails 3.2.2 - may there be any changes or I'm wrong in some basic ideas of STI and DB performance?

(P) whether or not MySQL uses a query depends on the order of the keys so defining the primary key to be `id, type` won't help queries like this:

``` ruby
class Vehicle < ActiveRecord::Base; end
class Car < Vehicle; end
class Van < Vehicle; end
```

``` irb
>> Car.scoped.to_sql
=> "select * FROM `vehicles` WHERE `vehicles`.`type` = 'Car'"
```

If you define a separate index for `type` then MySQL will use it to optimize the query.

(P) Also you can only use `AUTO INCREMENT` with a single column primary key on InnoDB tables and the behaviour with multi-column primary keys and MyISAM tables is probably not what you'd want - you'd end up with repeated id values.
(M) So, two indexes may be good, but index on `type` field has no sense due to poor cardinality.
(P) That explain me that patches has no sense at all.
Thanks :) I forgot about column order in index!
(P) But, you are wrong about `AUTO INCREMENT` - it does work with multi-column index `id, type` and works w/o any duplicates, but this index has no sense, ok!

(P) > But, you are wrong about AUTO INCREMENT - it does work with multi-column index id, type

From: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.6/en/innodb-restrictions.html

    For an AUTO_INCREMENT column, you must always define an index for the table, 
    and that index must contain just the AUTO_INCREMENT column.

(M) In MyISAM tables, 
    the AUTO_INCREMENT column may be part of a multiple-column index.
(P) >  and works w/o any duplicates, but this index has no sense, ok!

(P) From: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.6/en/example-auto-increment.html

``` sql
create TABLE animals (
    grp ENUM('fish','mammal','bird') NOT NULL,
    id MEDIUMINT NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
    name CHAR(30) NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (grp,id)
) ENGINE=MyISAM;

INSERT INTO animals (grp,name) VALUES
    ('mammal','dog'),('mammal','cat'),
    ('bird','penguin'),('fish','lax'),('mammal','whale'),
    ('bird','ostrich');

select * FROM animals ORDER BY grp,id;
```

which returns:

```
+--------+----+---------+
| grp    | id | name    |
+--------+----+---------+
| fish   |  1 | lax     |
| mammal |  1 | dog     |
| mammal |  2 | cat     |
| mammal |  3 | whale   |
| bird   |  1 | penguin |
| bird   |  2 | ostrich |
+--------+----+---------+
```

As you can see there are duplicate IDs in the table.
(W) Yes, I've read this all already, but in practice this (example in first post) worked for me on InnoDB.

(W) Wierd, but worked at all

Thanks for the initial explanation!
You've helped a lot

(P) Looks like it was changed in MySQL 5.0:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5060927/convert-myisam-to-innodb-where-tables-have-two-column-pk-and-one-of-those-is-aut
http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/innodb-auto-increment-handling.html

and there's a bug against the documentation:

http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=60139

Still needs to be the first column though so doesn't really help.

title: mcabber, "HEAD", looks for libtoolize
body:
(WD) mcabber head-version starts building process with running `autogen.sh`, but `autogen.sh` tries to execute `libtoolize`, which doesn't exist on Mac OS X

Mac has `/usr/bin/glibtoolize` instead
That should help :-)
(W) The pull request linked to this was closed, so closing this.

title: Hit Targets For Secondary Navigation Too Small
body: Android design guidelines recommend 48dp square as a minimum.
On the action bar, action items have a minimm width of 56dp by default.

On larger devices (e.g., Nexus 7) the action bar becomes 56dp tall rather than 48dp which further exacerbates the thinness.

!

[](http://i.imgur.com/9Agxa.png)
![](http://i.imgur.com/HobkD.png)
!

[](http://i.imgur.com/UjWoE.png)

For comparison, here's the overflow menu on the Galaxy Nexus:

!
[](http://i.imgur.com/3HsLb.png)
(W) So images used for main action bar icon (on the left) are supposed to be different sizes then the icons shown on the right?
(P) I think all the action bar icons in the app were generated from the Android asset studio so I'm just trying to figuring out what we need to change them too size-wise.
Thanks for reporting this.

title: 2456 - Restricted how many "ajax send" requests can be executed concurrently.
body: - The manager is used to control how many active ajax "send" requests happen at the same time.
- Defaulted the max allows to 4, this allows for 1 long polling "poll" request and 1 user ajax request.
(W) Closing this PR until we have the alternate solution completed as well

(P) We looked into this bug, some notes:

Line that errors out: https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/blob/master/lib/redcarpet/render/gitlab_html.rb#L14

Comparable error in the Spinx project `ClassNotfound: no lexer for alias u'txt' found`
https://bitbucket.org/birkenfeld/sphinx/issue/499/txt-lexer-missing-for-make -latex
Comment: `This is curious.

(P) however, this exception should be caught in sphinx.highlighting and result in a warning instead of propagating to toplevel.
(M) Also, in your log the Pygments source is from a 1.2.2 egg, while you say here that you have 1.3.1 installed.`
````

(W) Added this as I have seen a few issues indicate they were fixed by updating git.

https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/issues/4027, https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/issues/3666, https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/issues/3614#issuecomment-16935752, https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/issues/3986#issuecomment-18261304, https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/issues/3781#issuecomment-18122033
(M) I think it would be better to specify specific dependencies.
(P) In the case of git, for users of RHEL, a simple package manager update did nothing.
(M) We had to go elsewhere to fullfil the git > 1.7.10 dependency.
(W) I agree.
(P) Lets update gitlab:check to (make  SURE) git has the right version.
How do we define "right version"?
that's tough.
(M) ideally you guys are running CI against different distros/os's and that should help you out.
i.e.

(P) centos 6 CI would have failed because you're now using a feature of git that was introduced in 1.7.10. so once that failed you would have to see what feature you added and then investigate what version of git that feature was released in.
(P) appears check already looks at git version... https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/blob/master/lib/tasks/gitlab/check.rake#L669
I am having almost same problem.
(W) When I create a merge request, even after approving the merge request it does not merge anything neither it closes the branch automatically.
I was using gitlab 2.1 for over 1 year, today I moved to 5.2.
I am using CentOS 6.3.
@kchandan I don't think your issue is related to this issue.
I can help you troubleshoot but don't think here is the best place.
(M) Can you post to the GitLab Google group or join IRC #gitlab on freenode and myself or someone else will help you through it.
Thanks, it turn out to be totally RVM + gitlab stuff.
(P) After changing the ruby path from /us/bin/ruby to $HOME/.rvm/bin/ruby it all worked.

title: Must set secret_key_base even for tests
body: (WD) We have session suport disabled (session_store nil).

When running tests, we get the following error:

    Failure/Error: Unable to find matching line from backtrace
    RuntimeError:
      You must set config.secret_key_base in your app's config.

(PD) .../railties-4.0.0/lib/rails/application.rb:145:in `env_config'
      .../actionpack-4.0.0/lib/action_dispatch/testing/test_request.rb:13:in `initialize'
      .../actionpack-4.0.0/lib/action_controller/test_case.rb:181:in `initialize'
      .../actionpack-4.0.0/lib/action_dispatch/testing/test_request.rb:9:in `new'
      .../actionpack-4.0.0/lib/action_dispatch/testing/test_request.rb:9:in `new'
      .../actionpack-4.0.0/lib/action_controller/test_case.rb:606:in `build_request'
      .../actionpack-4.0.0/lib/action_controller/test_case.rb:583:in `setup_controller_request_and_response'
      .../rspec-rails-2.14.0/lib/rspec/rails/adapters.rb:93:in `block (2 levels) in setup'

Setting secret_key_base to a dummy value solves the problem.
I'll take a look.
(P) I think the `secret_key_base` is not needed if you don't use sessions but on the other hand there is no harm done if you just set it.
/cc @trevorturk @spastorino
(W) It's likely required just to make  our lives easier.
(W) I'd be +1 to making it optional, but we'd need to find all the places it would be required and to raise the appropriate error at that spot instead.
(P) MessageVerifier is the only one I can think of right away, but we'd want to look carefully to (make  SURE) it's not used anywhere else.
(W) I don't think it's necessary (I'd just set secret_key_base) but if one of you guys wants to take it on, go for it!
(W) @trevorturk I agree.
I'm closing this one as it is the expected behavior.
(P) There is no harm in just setting it even if it's not getting used.

title: fix ActionView::Digestor to correctly pass format to LookupContext
body: Hi, I was playing around trying to use cache_digests to generate a checksum for a generated pdf (based on views with pdf as the format).
(WD) After much head-scratching I think I actually found a small bug in TemplateDigestor.
(WD) There seems to be a missing argument in the call to ActionView::LookupContext which causes formats of templates to be ignored.
@dhh asked me to do a PR of this for rails too.
I followed the contributing guide to the best of my abilities.
(WD) Please let me know if I should improve the PR in some way.
(W) I reverted the changes since the tests are not passing.
(P) Please resubmit the pull request and (make  SURE) that at least the actionpack tests are passing
Sorry about that.
Started looking at the failing tests.
And done the rabbit hole I went, where things got a whole lot more complicated.
(P) In Rails:master the lookup of template formats does work... but only because Digestor is passing the format in the "wrong" argument.
(P) Digestor passes an options hash in the keys array argument of LookupContext.
(M) This is passed on down the line to PatSet and on to a resolver.

(P) Digestor -> LookupContext -> PathSet ->...-> resolver

In PathSet and resolver there are several methods that just pass all this along as *args finally ending up in a find_all() where the signature does not match that in LookupContext.
(M) Down here the argument position that was "keys" is supposed to be a hash (details) which is supposed to contain a formats key.
(W) I am very unsure why it fails after my change.
(W) I see the same params being forwarded down to the resolver either way but still the Template comes back without any source contents.
(W) I'll dive back in few hours but if someone closer to this code has any hints that wouldn't be bad :)

title: Prefix route automatically adds trailing slash if a pattern is empty
body: Prefix route automatically adds trailing slash if a pattern is empty.

Example:

In the Routing.xml:
import resource="@AcmeTestBundle/Controller/TestController.php" prefix="/test" type="annotation"

In the FrameworkExtraBundle annotations:
* @Route("", name="test")

Whenever you go to /test SF2 will automatically redirect it to /test/

If you add a dummy variable however, and give it a default value it is not being redirected, example:
* @Route("{dummy}", defaults={"dummy":1} name="test")
The behavior is indeed correct.
Let me explain why.
(M) First, a `/` is always prepended to a route if it is not already the case.
(M) So, an empty route is equivalent to `/` and when you define a `{dummy}` route pattern, this is equivalent to `/{dummy}`.
(M) When you use `/test` as a prefix, you are mounting all routes under a `/test` "directory", so all defined routes are "inside" this "directory".

(M) For the first case, and empty string or `/` means the root of the directory, and if you omit the `/`, Symfony will automatically redirects you to this page (the same behavior as Apache), but when you use `/{dummy}`, you are not referencing the root anymore (even if there is a default value), so the redirection does not occur.

title: Rename kernel.listener to kernel.event_listener
body: Better consistency with doctrine.event_listener
(P) I think "symfony.event_listener" would be even better then, or just short "event_listener".

There are some more inconsistencies:
- "core.response" -> "kernel.response" / "http_kernel.response"
- "core.request" -> "kernel.request"  / "http_kernel.request"
- "core.controller" -> "kernel.controller"  / "http_kernel.controller"
- "core.view" -> "kernel.view"  / "http_kernel.view"
I proposed `event_listener` but @fabpot didn't like it, `symfony.event_listener` could do, but usual we refer to global stuff as framework more than symfony, so `framework.event_listener`?
The point is that the kernel "owns" the event dispatcher, even if anyone can dispatch his stuff through it.
You still listen on the kernel dispatcher.
So it's not that wrong imo.
(W) As for the others.
(W) I agree that the "core" name is a bit strange.
(M) kernel would be more suitable imo.
@fabpot?

(P) @Seldaek the issue with having ``kernel`` in the tag name is that some user think that they need to define their own tag when they want to dispatch their own events (I faced it a few times on #symfony and it was also the case in #1298)
Well yeah that's why I liked the idea of having only `event_listener`.
IMO even with `framework.event_listener` the confusion can still happen.
Renaming `core.response` to `kernel.response` is fine with me.
Ok, added another commit that does that renaming.
(W) updated the two related PRs in -docs and -standard as well.

title: fix default options argument on ActiveRecord::ConnectionAdaptors::Table#column_exists?
body: (PD) changed the default value for the `options` argument on `ActiveRecord::ConnectionAdapters::Table#column_exists?` from `nil` to an empty Hash `{}`.
(PD) That method calls through to `ActiveRecord::ConnectionAdapters::SchemaStatements#column_exists?` which expects `options` to be a Hash.
(PD) When `options` was `nil`, an error would occur in cases where the column did exist because the called method attempted to perform a key lookup on options.

title: Process isolation causes duplicate require/include of Symfony dependencies?
body:
(WD) I just upgraded to PHPUnit 3.7, and I am now receiving the following error for any tests using the ```@runInSeparateProcess``` annotation:

```
PHPUnit_Framework_Exception: PHP Fatal error:  Cannot redeclare class Symfony\Component\Yaml\Dumper in /usr/local/lib/php/Symfony/Component/Yaml/Dumper.php on line 20
PHP Stack trace:
PHP   1.

{main}() -:0
PHP   2. require_once() -:47
```
(P) Did work out fine for me against the SF2 test suite.
(W) I'd need more information (install method, what test suite, failures) to do anything here.
(P) For some context, I am working with a Zend Framework application that uses Doctrine ORM.
(M) I was able to track the "problem" to ```PHPUnit/Extensions/Database/Autoload.php```.
(P) Uninstalling DbUnit got rid of the error message for me, but is clearly not the proper solution.
(P) I did some more digging and discovered an older version of ```Symfony\Component\Yaml\Dumper``` in my application's include path (it was distributed with Doctrine).
(P) I removed that version of the YAML dumper from my app's include path, re-installed DbUnit, and the error message is gone.
(P) It seems that this error was caused by my muddled include path and is not the fault of PHPUnit (or DbUnit), so I'm closing this issue.

title: [DependencyInjection] Problem with unescaping class arguments
body:
(PD) bug fix: yes
Feature addition: no
Backwards compatibility break: no
Symfony2 tests pass: yes
License of the code: MIT

Hello!

I've got an error when I tried to use DI to initiate Monolog logger with next settings:


    services:
      logger_formatter:
        class:        \Monolog\Formatter\LineFormatter
        arguments:    [ "[%%datetime%%] %%channel%%.%%level_name%%: %%message%% %%context%%\n" ]  
      logger_handler:
        class:        \Monolog\Handler\StreamHandler
        arguments:
          - app.log
          - <?php echo \Monolog\Logger::DEbug, PHP_EOL; ?>
        calls:
          - [ setFormatter, [ @logger_formatter ]]
      logger:
        class:        \Monolog\Logger
        arguments:    [ 'logger_name' ]
        calls:
          - [ pushHandler, [ @logger_handler ]]


If I set argument for service logger_formatter with single % (like "[%datetime%]…") then DI threw exception that it could not resolve reference because there was non-existent parameter "datetime".
(WD) If I set argument with double % (like "[%%datetime%%]…") then DI transferred parameter to the LineFormatter object without unescaping, and LineFormatter did not work properly.
(PD) The problem was in ContainerBuilder, because there was no unescaping class parameters.
(PD) I’ve fixed problem and added tests to cover such case.
This pull request [passes](http://travis-ci.org/symfony/symfony/builds/1713074) (merged 08fe2167 into d0e15472).
(P) @avorobiev Could you just make  `unescapeValue` public and call it from the Container Builder ?
(M) (ie without adding a new method).
(P) Please also add a note in the component [changelog](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/master/src/Symfony/Component/DependencyInjection/changeLOG.md).
Thanks.

title: parse_ini_file() not behaving as expected
body:
According to the PHP doc: 
	Note: There are reserved words which must not be used as keys 
	for ini files.

(WD) These include: null, yes, no, true, false, on, 
	off, none.

Values null, no and false results in "", yes and 
	true results in "1".
Characters ?{}|&~!

[()^" must not be used 
	anywhere in the key and have a special meaning in the value.

(MD) See: http://php.net/manual/en/function.parse-ini-file.php

Let's consider the following "test.ini" file:
	; String value without quotes
	foo = bar
Now the "test.php" file:
	<?php print_r(parse_ini_file('test.ini')); ?>
Now if we run "php test.php" we get:
	Array
	(
		[foo] => bar
	)
If we run "hphpi test.php" or "hphp test.php" we get:
	HipHop Notice:  Use of undefined constant bar -- assumed 'bar'.

syntax error, unexpected '/' in test.ini on line 2
Now with the following INI file:
	; Key value with special but allowed chars
	/foo/bar/ = 42
With php:
	Array
	(
		[/foo/bar/] => 42
	)
With Hiphop:
	syntax error, unexpected '/' in test.ini on line 1
(W) We're closing out all bugs older than 2 months.

http://www.hiphop-php.com/wp/?p=575

If this is still an issue, please re-open it, and in order of goodness:

1.

Give detailed repro steps
1.

Write a test case in hphp/tests/quick (run it with hphp/tests/run) and send the pull request
1.
(W) fix it in a pull request

title: Stability - Validation Tests
body: There are some serious issues with a lot of homebrew packages.
(WD) Are validation tests possible or would this be an insane undertaking?
Examples?
(P) Donate us some money for dedicated hardware and definitely possible :)
(W) > Is unit testing possible or would this be an insane undertaking?
(M) I would love to set up a continuous integration rig---would help process pull requests a lot faster if I didn't have to manually QA them on three different platforms.
Anyone got a Quad-core MacMini server to donate?
(M) It would be nice if we had some kind of central data aggregator, to which users could (voluntarily) submit some predefined build report (formula build results, `brew --config`/`brew --env`, etc.
(P) but in a machine readable format).
(P) Then we could leverage  our very active community and would only need a central app to collect all the data.
(M) Someone with a server and a small amount of extra bandwidth could volunteer to run such an app.
(P) I think we'd need to run it ourselves or have trust people running it.
(P) @mxcl Would you object heavily to my attempting to start trying to investigate how we could solicit donations?
Realistically anything like this won't happen unless we have people donate or sponsors who give us hardware (e.g.
Github, Apple, someone else).
(W) I don't see a need for any certain persons to run the tests, people can donate their machine time instead of dollars.
(P) All we need is machine time.
(W) I'll admit I like where @jacknagel is going as far as how test should be ran.
(P) whether if its a single/couple machines or truly distributed, we should focus on finding a solution to the problem before putting a hold on something because we think we might need donations.
(P) I think the main area to focus on as far as working on stability issues is what to test, and how to test it.
(M) We can worry about how the tests are run at a later point.
(W) Would we just mainly want to focus on verifying build completion?
Any initial ideas on how the tests would be written and ran?
(P) Even without formula changes, URL's go dead and need updating to different mirror's, etc.
(P) Think this is simple yet important first step on improving homebrew's stability and "just works"ness.
(W) I'll brain storm and see what I come up with and see if we can make  these tests scaleable, in the mean time i'd love to hear ideas in general related to homebrew testing.
Also, can someone get this marked as "Feature Request"?
One problem with using "donated machine time" is that we have no control over the test environment.
I.E.
(M) I could do something stupid to my build environment and then donate machine time to tests which would fail and raise red flags.
(M) Then whoever was trying to figure out why the tests failed would have to spend a lot of manual effort to discover that I did something stupid to my build environment.
(M) I feel like controlled servers or virtual machines are the only way to get reliable test results.
The obvious benefit of distributed testing is that you get results for many more configurations.
I understand that one or two dedicated test machines can buy us speed, but I feel like we already have a large community of contributors waiting to be leveraged in this manner.
By utilizing them, we are getting test results from the very people for which we are providing packages.
It could be set up in a way that known bad settings are detected and flagged.

(Fat fingered the comment button)

It could be set up in a way that known bad settings are detected and flagged.
And really, successful builds are uninteresting.
(W) I want to know the conditions that cause something to fail.
What better way to find those conditions than by gathering information from as many different setups as possible?
Perhaps something along the lines of https://fate.ffmpeg.org (obviously less focused on rigorously testing the built software).
(W) @Sharpie agreed that is an issue, but there may be work arounds like an md5 of the code base?
(W) But yea that just doesn't sound very appetizing to me.
(P) So maybe we would want to have trusted machines for this.
(W) I just think its silly to start asking for donations / machines before any code is written.
(P) But yea want to get the discussion focused on the tests them selfs and how they might be structured.
> It could be set up in a way that known bad settings are detected and flagged.
Sure.
But to quote Donald Rumsfeld: "There are things we do not know we don't know".
(P) If it was feasible to detect and flag bad settings than our issue count would be 0 because `brew doctor` would be automatically pointing out everyone's problems.

(M) I would love to see a distributed system that leveraged the power of the community---but I'm not convinced it would give a good signal to noise ratio without some sort of control over the build environment.
(P) The ideal setup would be something like [travis-ci](http://travis-ci.org) where users could register their machine as a worker that runs test VMs managed using [Vagrant](http://vagrantup.com).
(M) But there is the sticky issue of Apple's legal department coming after us with pitchforks if we start handing out VM images with OS X installed.
(P) >But yea want to get the discussion focused on the tests them selfs and how they might be structured.
(M) I don't think the "tests" themselves can be much more than the result of the build and potentially the result of running `brew test <foo>` if foo defines a test method.
(W) Anything more would be an impossible amount of maintenance.
> And really, successful builds are uninteresting.
(W) I want to know the conditions that cause something to fail.
(W) Successful builds are interesting to me because my current QA workflow for new formulae involves manually starting three VMs, rolling back to a stable snapshots and running the build.

(W) I would love to just leave a comment in the pull request that causes a robot somewhere to queue this job up and report back the success/fail---at which point the only work left for me is to run the merge.
I do see the value of testing for failure conditions though.

(W) Perhaps we want some machines that are trusted and controlled for QA purposes alongside the ability for random community users to submit test results for the purposes of improving the intelligence of `brew doctor`.
(P) > If it was feasible to detect and flag bad settings than our issue count would be 0 because brew doctor would be automatically pointing out everyone's problems.
And that's obviously not what I was saying.
(W) I just don't see how we can find new problems without some real-world data.
Sure, we can do it _faster_ with a limited number of controlled-environment machines, and that's a worthy pursuit in itself, but I think it's addressing a different problem.

(P) I like the overall idea and it would be possible to combine community contributed build/test results with some kind of trusted build-bot machines - which can be triggered to build a certain formula (raw URL or whatever).
(M) The collected results should be public an the "trusted" build bots could be highlighted.
(P) What I wanted to say: Special trusted build bots (whether sponsored or not) contribute to the same distributed network - just that they can be identified on the collector machine.
I don't like community contributed builds unless it's a strictly controller environment (i.e.
a VM).
I see bots being useful to see if pull requests build and pass `brew audit` and `brew test`.
@samueljohn I'd still like you to point out the "serious issues with a lot of homebrew packages".

@mikemcquaid I'm not here to report a specific issue, the issue queue is large enough but i've had many random build issues in past that could have mitigated with simple build testing before committing.
Latest issue was a source tarball 404ing.
(W) I'll put in some time on figuring out how to structure tests, will report back with some ideas on implementation of tests.
Again, ideas related to building the tests them selfs are really greatly appreciated.
>I'm not here to report a specific issue, the issue queue is large enough but i've had many random build issues in past that could have mitigated with simple build testing before committing.
Please, this is not helpful.
(M) If you have issues, report them!
(W) We can't fix things that we don't know are broken.
(W) The number of issues in the queue should be of no concern to bug reporters.
(P) To be clear, yes, more aggressive testing would be nice, but it's not as if we are just committing stuff willy nilly.
It's pretty rare for something to be committed without being tested on at least one machine.
>Latest issue was a source tarball 404ing.
(W) Let's be reasonable.
This is not a "serious issue", and can happen at any time.
We don't control the source tarballs.
(P) agree'd 404ing its not a serious issue, but a preventable issue.
I wrote up that first post quickly and had bad wording.
(W) I didn't mean to suggest that people commit stuff all "willy nilly" like.
(W) bugs happen, some are preventable.
(P) Lets prevent ones that are preventable with unit testing, I think that's reasonable.
(P) If you think unit testing for homebrew is a good idea lets focus on solutions to write unit tests to (make  SURE) everything is compiling correctly.
(W) Unless you have constructive points on why unit testing for this software is not helpful or providing solutions then your not being helpful.
Homebrew has a unit test suite already, though it is out of date.

(W) Note that tests that involve downloading formulae and checking checksums, or even compiling across various platforms are not unit tests at all, but integration tests or validation tests or something else.
"unit test" has a specific smaller scoped definition.
404s are the fault of upstream, not us.
(P) The only solution to that is to mirror all upstream files which we don't have the bandwidth or team for.
(P) A CI system that hourly tried to download every URL would be the only solution to this and it probably wouldn't get fixed much quicker.
As @adamv said there are already unit tests.
(P) Feel free to submit pull requests to improve them.
Closing.
(W) It was misused terminology as @adamv pointed out, this wasn't what we were discussing about implementing.
(W) I corrected the terminology in the title of the original post, @mikemcquaid please reopen or advise if i should create a separate feature test for this.
(P) Validation Tests = We want to verify the program is functioning properly for its intended purpose.
(P) We want to verify building of formulae.
(W) At this time there are higher priority issues in the queue, like multi-repo suport and dealing with XCode 4.3+.
(P) My suggestion for moving this forward would be to add or improve formula test methods (e.g.
(P) what is run by `brew test <formula>`), and documenting your suggestions on the wishlist on the wiki.
What @jacknagel said.
(W) Feel free to implement `brew test` for various formula or additional unit tests.
(W) Anything beyond that is unlikely to be implemented I'm afraid unless we have more resources and/or funding.

title: ActiveResource Schema doesn't provide find_by_* methods
body: (WD) Is this just a documentation issue?
(WD) Or is it supposed to and I'm just missing something?
(PD) I looked through the source and I see no evidence of it suporting this, either now or since the Schema was first introduced.

(MD) https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/activeresource/lib/active_resource/base.rb#L302

PS I'm about to write a custom controller method on the server side.
Anyone know a better way to do find_by_*?
Urgh, that's a shame.
(P) It's a documentation issue.
(P) Do you want to contribute by providing us the missing feature, along with test?
(P) For now, I'm going to update in lifo/docrails saying that we don't suport it.
I'm willing to take it.
On a deadline at the moment, but I should have time to revisit in a week or so.
(W) @softwaregravy and @sikachu, I'm working on this too.
(P) I'm looking at ActiveRecord source code as a model to solve this issue.
(P) Looks like ```active_resource/base.rb``` needs a class level ```method_missing``` to handle all the find\_by\_* calls.
(P) I'm creating a ```DynamicFinderMatch``` class inside the ActiveResource module to interpret the find\_by\_* calls.
(W) Does this sound like a viable solution?
(W) Your appraoch appears to be consistent with what's there.
(P) I haven't thought through this deeply enough yet, but the server side needs to suport all the search params.
(P) The suport that ActiveResource has would be overkill since every option that ActiveResource has available to it needs to be suported directly anyway.
(P) i.e if you have attributes foo and bar, I think it's reasonable to want find_by_foo and find_by_bar.
(P) however, it's unlikely that combinations of find_by_foo_and_bar will be well suported on the server.

(P) Worse, if the server suports find_by_foo, but not find_by_foo_and_bar, then by default it will most likely just execute the find_by_foo logic

If you build what you're discussing, more power to you -- just feels like a little bit of overkill right now given the current state of ActiveResource.
(W) @softwaregravy, I read the comments in ```active_resource/base.rb```.
(W) Before I start coding in the wrong direction, I'd like to get some feedback to (make  SURE) I understood the problem at hand.
(P) I went ahead and solved one case: see the commit I did [here](https://github.com/dyba/rails/commit/1b963530a6534d8af7c5c7ece87da48fc1dc42aa).
(W) You mentioned the server side needs to suport all the search params.
(P) Did you mean the find\_by\_\<attribute\> method should be able to suport any attribute you specify in your ActiveResource::Base subclass?
(P) When you say search params, I think of a hash with options.
Would you please clarify?

(P) Also, the comments in the ```active_resource/base.rb``` file don't mention whether or not I'm supposed to return an instance of ActiveResource::Base, my gut tells me I should be returning one, but I want to double check my assumption.
@sikachu, I'd like to get some feedback from you as well.
Thanks!
I think where you're going with that is okay, except that you're ignoring the schema.
(W) Given that we have nothing, I think your changes are a vast improvement.
(P) I was saying that I would have directly implemented the methods (using the schema as the template) in the class.
(P) The code that needs to be handled on the server is in the controller.
(P) Most index methods in the controller just do a `@model = Model.all`.
(P) Whatever search params are suported need to be mapped in the controller -- for this reason, I wouldn't suport the find_by_X_and_Y variants out of the box.
(P) Thought while I write this:  given your implementation, what error will I get if I search on a param that isn't suported in the controller or doesn't exist in the model?

@sikachu, @softwaregravy
This is turning out to be more challenging than I thought.
(P) Here's a [second attempt](https://github.com/dyba/rails/commit/5277556bc953acbf1ed1ca1245ca99bb9efbfbd4).
I'm still troubleshooting an error message I'm getting.
I'm not sure if I mocked the HTTP response correctly either.
@softwaregravy, in response to your last question, you'll get a RuntimeError.
(W) probably not the best way to deal with this, but it was the first thing I thought of.
(W) suggestions?

(P) @dyba
In my opinion, we should return an array if we use :all call in find (base.rb), also I would use just the first argument in method_missing.

Please have a look here: https://github.com/novotarq/rails/commit/aa24948c063e1595f900a1ac40f21eb3f8aedcd3
@sikachu, @softwaregravy any suggestions?
(W) I agree it should be an array.
(P) I'd want to have something strung up where I'm testing these changes out before I weigh in with much more than that, and I haven't had time to do that yet.
Hi guys can we do this at [ActiveResource](http://github.com/rails/activeresource) repo?
Closing this from here.
Please open this in [ActiveResource](https://github.com/rails/activeresource) repo if problem still exists.

Cheers, 
Arun
