title: STI doesn't work properly in migrations
body: Migrations is a specific example, the problem is more general.

(WD) So, if I have a migration:

```ruby
class DoSomething < ActiveRecord::Migration
  class Post < ActiveRecord::Base
  end

  class ImagePost < Post
  end

  def up
    Post.find(1)
  end

  def down
    # ...
  end
end
```

And If I have an `ImagePost` in my database:

```ruby
{id: 1, type: "ImagePost"}
```

Then `DoSomething::Post.find(1)` will return an `ImagePost`, instead of an `DoSomething::ImagePost`.
Do you know why this is happening?
(P) because the type points to `ImagePost` and not `DoSomething::ImagePost`, so it'll find that class instead.

(P) I don't think this is something that should be changed, Rails is just using the stored information to load the correct class, if the stored information is not namespaced, it won't find a namespaced class.
(W) Does this make  sense to you?
Ahaaa, I see now.
I thought that the difference is the context from where the class is loaded from.
(W) But this really make s sense.
Thank you.

title: [2.1] Optimisations for php-fpm
body: PHP-FPM (FastCGI Process Manager) introduces a little-known feature to PHP, allowing you to deliver the response to the browser, *close* the HTTP connection, and continue execution of expensive tasks (like posting to APIs, sending e-mails, writing large cache files, etc).
The function `fastcgi_finish_request()` exposes this handy feature.
(MD) Calling it at the end of `Response::send()` is a win-win for SF2 performance.
(MD) Ideally we'll have an event dispatched right after the call, allowing us to prepare expensive code through controllers, etc.
(W) :+1:, sounds like a good change especially with the event.
(M) The point is that the Response cannot access the event dispatcher.
(M) And the Httpfoundation component is totally standalone currently so adding a dependency to the EventDispatcher component is a no-go IMO.
(M) Alternatively, could be called in the destructor of `HttpKernel`
(M) I don't like having it in the destructor.But addign a method to dispatch an event after sending the content could be doable.
(W) I agree with @lmcd that you should implement this in your front controller.
Yes, considering the limitation (that we do not have an early response that can be injected:p) I guess it should be handled in the front controller.
(P) As much as it seems hacky, I feel inclined to put it in the destructor of `HttpKernel`, as apposed to manually triggering the event in the front controller.
(M) I feel like events should be dispatched seamlessly and transparently as they are everywhere else, and not from within a project's front controller.

title: "Rich" slides in Orbit (combined text and images)
body:
(WD) Hi everyone

In the previous version of Orbit, there was a way to easily create a slide with any content overlaying the image of the slide.
(WD) That was done by setting the image position to "absolute", it's z-index to -1, and then doing whatever one wanted with the styles of the remaining slide content.
The point is, Orbit was still functioning properly with those adjustments.
I've looked at the code of the previous version, and the function responsible for proper dimensions was called ```setDimentionsFromLargestSlide```.
In there, Orbit was taking the dimensions of the largest available image in all of the slides, and applying those to the entire slider.
It was also creating a fluid placeholder from the largest image, apparently to cope with window resizing.
(WD) The biggest issue I see with that is the assumption that all slides are image-driven above all, with other content been somewhat secondary.
(PD) however, that can be easily resolved with a more sophisticated slide parser.
Aside from that, is there a reason that this feature has been removed from Orbit 4.0?
If it's a matter of time, I can add the code easily.
(WD) Were there any other considerations that I'm missing, though?
Thank you.

title: jquery Validation and foundation conflicts?
body: I was hoping foundation plays well with Jquery Validation.
(PD) I think they probably don't but it would be nice to fix since that jquery plugin is so heavily used on forms.
(WD) It would be disappointing to have those cool foundation nice forms and not be able to use them (one of the main reasons we switched was because of the nice forms automatically created).

(MD) Here is an example:
http://arihoj.freehostia.com/foundation_w_validation/
Try submitting and then try correcting the Custom Forms element errors.

(WD) They dont  ... Not sure if this needs to be attended to by foundation or the Jquery Plugin...
Also, I think the drop-down doesn't even set the correct select dropdown when i unhide it (it doesn't select anything at all in the hidden dropdown).

Thanks,
Ari
(W) So it looks like, from your example that the custom select does not work with the jquery validator.
(P) We have since pushed an update that does not set the select to `display: none` which should fix your problem.
(P) If you update to 4.1.5 it might work.

(W) Still think some weird stuff is going on: Here is the code upgraded to 4.1.5:
http://arihoj.freehostia.com/foundation4_w_validation/

Try running this when land on page in Firebug console to see how the hidden elements get values:
$('input,select').show();
$('form.custom .hidden-field')
.css('margin-left', '0px')
.css('position', 'static')
.css('visibility', 'visible');

 Dont submit yet... 
just try selecting values the custom drop-down ... it sets the hidden drop-down correctly...

Now refresh the page and first run the same Console javascript above...
Now click submit button which should set errors on all the fields...

(W) Try changing the custom select drop-down ... it doesn't change the corresponding hidden select when there is an error for some reason... Also, the hidden radio/checkboxes do get changed to their correct values, but the jquery-validator plugin doesn't clear the error messages, as if the hidden values aren't changing (not sure if they use a .change event, but theoretically it should run its validator code and clear itself).
Ah yes!
(W) Ok, I know what the issue is now, I'll have an update today!
(P) I think I fixed it.
(P) update your example with the lastest foundation.forms.js file in master.

(P) fixed in this commit: https://github.com/zurb/foundation/commit/e52cb775eacc3518ae44f5c075ce1ebc7fa265f8

Will be released in 4.1.6.
(P) I think the latest fix fixes the select drop-down not populating correctly after an error...

(P) If you submit with errors, then fix the drop-down, it sets the hidden drop down correctly and then calls jquery-validate's manual .valid() method above ... but it doesn't get rid of the error label immediately like it should, until you change the value in the dropdown again.
(W) Kinda weird, not sure its yours to fix though unless your change was supposed to fix the jquery-validation issues as well.
(M) The code above will correctly get rid of the error label on the custom radio/checkboxes though.
-Arian
(W) I was debugging and saw that because jquery-validate by default adds the label.error class after the element its validating, thats what messes up foundation Forms ...

(W) This code specifically in foundation.forms.js assumes the custom select is right after the hidden select:
refresh_custom_select: function ($select, force_refresh) {
...
$customselect = $select.next(),

Not sure below modification is safer to assume though since not sure if parent is a div, but helps my situation and :
          $customselect = $select.parents('div:eq(0)').find('div.custom.dropdown'),
//maybe more safer could get the 1st sibling ahead that matches div.custom.dropdown

There are other places in the code where next() is used... Maybe those could be updated as well.
-Arian
(P) Ah interesting, I am working on a change to this that associates a unique id to each custom form element so that prev() and next() can be avoided.

(P) Cool Let me know when that is ready to test out and I can do some more complex Form validations against it as well ... Its great because instead of writing a custom form validation plugin for foundation Forms, then people can just make  use of the very complete Jquery -Validate plugin without needing to modify the foundation source :) [i occasionally write custom validation functions for that plugin to do more complex custom validations].

title: Shared Gateway: Allow to set the number of concurrent streams doing snapshot operations
body: Allow to control the number of concurrent streams (globally, per node) that will be allowed to do the snapshot operations.
The setting for `s3` is `gateway.s3.concurrent_streams`, for `fs` is `gateway.fs.concurrent_streams`, and for `hdfs` is `gateway.s3.concurrent_streams`.
All default to `5` concurrent streams.

title: [Form] DateType ignores "empty_data" option
body: With the following test case.
(PD) https://gist.github.com/e50f4dfb88fc38486389 DateType ignores `empty_data` in the options array.
(PD) Also tried extension `DateType` and set the `empty_data` option directly in `setDefaultoptions` with the same result.
Problem here is a bit more complicated IMO.
(P) `DateType` don't uses `empty_data`, it's uses `empty_value`, and IIRC only in case when `'choice' === $options['widget']`.
(P) But even in this case that `empty_value` with value of `new \DateTime()` would probably fail.
(W) According to twitter conversation with @bschussek it seems to be a bug.
Also why does this type use empty_value and not empty_data.. Futhermore empty_value dosent have an impact.
(P) @stloyd "empty_data" and "empty_value" are two completely different options
Should we maybe rename "empty_value" to "placeholder" in order to clarify the difference?
(P) This problem is not easy to solve.
(P) The problem is that the "empty_data" doesn't exactly solve this case, but a slightly different one.
(M) When a form is bound, the data of the form's children is mapped into the form's data in *view format* and then reverse transformed to the *normalized* and *model format*.

|
    |                 |      }------- array 
<------------------ null <--´           |
```

1) When a form of type FormType is bound, the child data is written into the view data.
(P) When the view data is `null`, an appropriate view data needs to be created first (array or object).
(M) *Then* the reverse transformation starts.
(P) 2) When a form of type DateType is bound, the bound array is either transformed to `null` (if the array has only empty values) or to `DateTime` otherwise.
(P) *After* the reverse transformation, you now want to convert `null` to your DateTime.
(M) As you can see, 2) is a totally different case than 1).
(P) The only solution I see right now is to add a model transformer that converts null to a new DateTime.
(P) I'll leave this ticket open as we need to address this issue in 2.2.
(P) This one has been closed automatically and has to be reopened.
(P) I did this http://vandpibe.bjrnskov.dk/index.html#nulltodatetimetransformer and can be found here http://github.com/vandpibe/form

title: ettercap doesn't build on 10.6
body: I can't get newer versions of ettercap to build on Snow Leopard.
(WD) seems like it's not recognizing the keg-only newer libcurl, through 7.28.1 is properly installed.

(PD) The relevant line:
> /tmp/ettercap-erxm/ettercap-0.7.5.2/plug-ins/sslstrip/sslstrip.c:51:2: error: #error libcurl 7.26.0 or up is needed

https://gist.github.com/9b10cb672d0772ccc36b
Reproduced.

(W) Fails here:
````
/tmp/ettercap-13v4/ettercap-0.7.5.2/plug-ins/sslstrip/sslstrip.c:51:2: error: #error libcurl 7.26.0 or up is needed
/tmp/ettercap-13v4/ettercap-0.7.5.2/plug-ins/sslstrip/sslstrip.c: In function ‘http_send’:
/tmp/ettercap-13v4/ettercap-0.7.5.2/plug-ins/sslstrip/sslstrip.c:784: error: ‘CURLOPT_ACCEPT_ENCODING’ undeclared (first use in this function)
/tmp/ettercap-13v4/ettercap-0.7.5.2/plug-ins/sslstrip/sslstrip.c:784: error: (Each undeclared identifier is reported only once
/tmp/ettercap-13v4/ettercap-0.7.5.2/plug-ins/sslstrip/sslstrip.c:784: error: for each function it appears in.)

(W) make [2]: *** [plug-ins/Cmake Files/sslstrip.dir/sslstrip/sslstrip.c.o] Error 1
make [1]: *** [plug-ins/Cmake Files/sslstrip.dir/all] Error 2
make [1]: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....

Linking C shared module ec_stp_mangler.so
````
(W) Nothing was obvious in the project's Cmake  files on how to tell it where curl was

(P) It does `find_library(found_LIBCURL curl)` and you can pass various options into the Cmake  command line to make  it search the curl keg directory (see http://cmake .org/cmake /help/v2.8.8/cmake .html#command:find_library) such as `-DCmake _PREfix_PATH=/usr/local/opt/curl`.
(W) Cmake  is still a mystery to me; nothing I throw at it seems to help.
(P) The problem isn't Cmake  here; the Ettercap buildsystem sucks and is only looking for that version of Curl in the C header and not in Cmake .
(P) If you manually force it using CFLAGS then the same plugin fails on a missing `_strndup`.
(P) It'll either need proper patching (the buildsystem doesn't allow disabling plugins selectively) or, I'd suggest, we just make  it depend on Lion and up.
(M) Allegedly ettercap requires curl 7.26, but Lion only has 7.24.
(M) That's why we unconditionally dupe on all platofrms.
(M) Why is this working there and not on Snow Leopard?
(W) Not sure, Cmake  just picking it up differently.
(P) As said though it won't work anyway due to missing `_strndup`.
(P) Looks like the libcurl issue is resolved; just `_strndup` now.
Will report upstream.
Was this ever reported?
https://github.com/Ettercap/ettercap/issues
No, but I'll report it.
https://github.com/Ettercap/ettercap/issues/193
(P) fixed upstream already; added patch to the formula.

title: fix configure warnings when lame lib exists but not the headers (closes ...
body:
(PD) ...#13647)

reordered lame checks.
(PD) Look for the header first and only after it is found, check the lib too.
(PD) otherwise configure will throw "too many arguments" warnings
and what is the real cause of the  "too many arguments" warnings ?
(P) if you don't check for the header first, test compilation in XB_FIND_SONAME fails.
(M) Iirc the warning then comes in the "gold linker syntax" part.
(W) And I didn't find a better way to cleanly check check this, but suggestions are welcome.
(P) It'd be easier if lame suport was not auto.
(M) Note that those "too many arguments" warnings occur with all our libs due to the way we detect for gold linker syntax.
(W) I had this on my todo-list to properly fix it, but since it's a lot of work I didn't bother yet.
(P) just had a quick look, and the fix for the gold linker check seems rather trivial actually: https://github.com/arnova/xbmc/commit/ebea889c17f2341925b013061bb167e100bfa2df

(P) verified working fix for gold:
```diff
diff --git a/configure.in b/configure.in
index f037c2f..7ddcff1 100644
--- a/configure.in
+++ b/configure.in
@@ -59,7 +59,7 @@ AC_DEFUN([XB_FIND_SONAME],
     $1_FILENAME=$($CC -nostdlib -o /dev/null $LDFLAGS -l$2 -Wl,-M 2>/dev/null | grep "^LOAD.

*$2" | awk '{V=2; print $V}')
     if [[ -z $$1_FILENAME ]]; then
       #try gold linker syntax
-      $1_FILENAME=$($CC -nostdlib -o /dev/null $LDFLAGS -l$2 -Wl,-t 3>&1 1>&2 2>&3 | grep "$2")
+      $1_FILENAME=$($CC -nostdlib -o /dev/null $LDFLAGS -l$2 -Wl,-t 3>&1 1>&2 2>&3 | grep "lib$2")
     fi
     if [[ !

-z $$1_FILENAME ]]; then
       $1_SONAME=$($OBJDUMP -p $$1_FILENAME | grep "SONAME.
Please use the above, as it addresses the real issue

title: test_column_types in sqlite3_adapter_test.rb fails on 1.9.3 due to datetimes being inserted as BLOBs
body: [This test](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/activerecord/test/cases/adapters/sqlite3/sqlite3_adapter_test.rb#L23-36) is failing on Ruby 1.9.3, but not on 1.9.2.
It is not failing due to the 'name' column being inserted as a blob.
(WD) The 'owners' table also has an updated_at datetime column.
This ends up getting inserted as a blob, causing the test to fail.
The `quoted_date` method in `connection_adapters/abstract/quoting` returns a string for the datetime.
(WD) The string is encoded as ASCII-8BIT, but force encoding it to something else does not seem to make  a difference.
At this point I am stuck, help me ;)

(W) cc @luislavena

could this be a bug in the sqlite3 adapter?

(P) Hello, seems to be a bug in Ruby:

https://github.com/luislavena/sqlite3-ruby/issues/45
https://github.com/luislavena/sqlite3-ruby/issues/48
@luislavena thanks for responding.

I am confused though, for two reasons:

1.
I am unsure why this failure does not also occur in 1.9.2.
In both 1.9.2 and 1.9.3, Time.now.to_s.encoding is ASCII-8BIT, but the value is only stored as a blob on 1.9.3.
When I force-encode it to something else (e.g.
utf-8) in the `quoted_date` method, it is still inserted as a blob.

(W) Well, I'm more confused too, specially since the one that investigated the whole issue was Aaron, so:

@tenderlove, can you chime in on this?
We would <3 some knowledge :-)

(P) It turns out that it's a bug in 1.9.3:

```
$ irb
ruby-1.9.3-preview1 :001 > "a".encoding
 => #<Encoding:UTF-8>
ruby-1.9.3-preview1 :002 > a = "a".encode!

("us-ascii")
 => "a"
ruby-1.9.3-preview1 :003 > b = "b".encode!

(W) ("us-ascii")
 => "b"
ruby-1.9.3-preview1 :004 > a.encoding
 => #<Encoding:US-ASCII>
ruby-1.9.3-preview1 :005 > b.encoding
 => #<Encoding:US-ASCII>
ruby-1.9.3-preview1 :006 > "#{a}#{b}".encoding # => should be US-ASCII
 => #<Encoding:ASCII-8BIT> 
```

I am compiled 1.9.3-head to check now... Aaron says he can't repro with 1.9.4.
(P) Ruby bug filed: http://redmine.ruby-lang.org/issues/5287
@jonleighton Is this still an issue?

title: Specify error handling for uv_write and uv_connect
body: uv_write and uv_connect can fail synchronously (returning -1) and asynchronously (reporting result=-1 to the callback).
Right now it is unspecified which error will be reported how.
(MD) I think that we should guarantee that errors cause by "external" factors (like a failing network) are reported asynchronously.
(MD) Only errors that indicate user bugs (EINVAL or ENOTSOCK etc) or serious system errors (ENOMEM etc) should be reported synchronously.
I am not sure about errors that are deferred from a failed bind (EADDRNOTVAIL).
opinions?
cc @pietern
Is this not the case right now?
@piscisaureus That sounds like a solid separation.

(P) When `uv_write` only reports `ENOMEM` or `EINVAL`, people using the API can safely put a bunch of asserts there (unrecoverable or programming error), instead of having to check for the "external" conditions as well.
(P) @ry When the write queue is empty, `uv_write` attempts to do the write immediately.
When this fails with e.g.
a `ECONNRESET`, this is reported back synchronously as well.
I had expected this to be reported via the write callback with a -1 status.

(P) This is the relevant piece of code: https://github.com/joyent/libuv/blob/3c00d87b4239a6b8358e2085f806170c3eca10cf/src/unix/stream.c#L690-695

I've done some tests that showed that there is little latency difference between calling write directly (and opportunistically) and waiting for the writable event.

(W) I did this test on an Ubuntu machine and it could be that the Linux kernel has to do some extra work on the write buffer when write is called directly, because it seemed that this resulted in a bit more latency than waiting for the write event to fire.
It was a while ago that I did those tests, and did them against the Redis event loop with a lot of hackish code, so set out to reproduce.
It appears I was wrong (or my previous test was faulty), and that writing immediately has an advantage (for a small payload, such as `PING\n`).

**Linux (immediate write)**

    ping_pongs: 31676 roundtrips/s
    ping_pongs: 50.0%: 31430ns
    ping_pongs: 75.0%: 31584ns
    ping_pongs: 90.0%: 31741ns
    ping_pongs: 95.0%: 31891ns
    ping_pongs: 99.0%: 32478ns
    ping_pongs: 99.9%: 45977ns

**Linux (write on write event)**

    ping_pongs: 25472 roundtrips/s
    ping_pongs: 50.0%: 39071ns
    ping_pongs: 75.0%: 39224ns
    ping_pongs: 90.0%: 39385ns
    ping_pongs: 95.0%: 39550ns
    ping_pongs: 99.0%: 40556ns
    ping_pongs: 99.9%: 55023ns

This is the code I used to record latency: https://gist.github.com/1213510.
The difference is smaller for larger payloads.
(M) My new hypothesis is that the advantage of waiting can only be seen when there is a lot of pressure on the write buffer and the immediate writes return `EAGAIN`.
(W) Not sure how the advantage could be observed otherwise...
(P) Closing, this got fixed.
@bnoordhuis Did it?
I am not so sure.
No?
I don't think it happens with uv-unix anymore but if it's still an issue with uv-win, please reopen.

title: Asset urls
body: The full benefit of asset_host configuration is only achieved when the configuration is carried through the stylesheet where most of the images are referenced.
Without this ability, the assets are locked to whatever asset host served the stylesheet request.
(WD) This patch changes the behavior of asset_path so that it will generate a full url adhering to project's asset_host configuration when it is set.
(WD) In the past, rails has used request inspection to to avoid mixed content warnings, however, with precompiled assets this is no longer possible.
(WD) Nor is it necessary (and in fact it's harmful to cached pages) because we can serve protocol relative urls instead.
(WD) Protocol relative urls are now the default with this patch.
Compass has exposed this functionality for several years now so this strategy is battle-tested.

(PD) After this patch lands, I will be able to update sass-rails so that it exposes syntactic sugar for accessing the url helpers and update compass so that rails users who use compass have a single source for their asset configuration.
+1, thanks
(W) +1, hopefully this make s it into 3.1 release
(W) It would be great if we can add documentation for this.
Can somebody help on that?.

(P) Regarding the protocol relative url change, here's a great article on the subject: http://paulirish.com/2010/the-protocol-relative-url/

As a result of this change, best practice will be to not put a protocol in the asset host string.
(P) however sites that care about suporting IE6 users with custom security settings and currently use asset hosts will need to add an asset host proc that does not use an asset host
@spastorino: What kind of docs were you thinking of?
@radar everything :).
Can you talk with @chriseppstein about this?
(W) I just spoke with @paulirish about this.

(P) I will submit another patch to disable protocol relative urls for stylesheets in stylesheet_link_tag because ie7 and ie8 will download them twice -- in those cases we'll need to use the old appraoch of inspecting the request protocol.

(P) In order to minimize risk I have made the following changes:

1.
(M) By default, whenever a request is in scope the `:request` protocol will be used.
(M) By default, whenever a request is not in scope (E.g.
(M) rake assets:precompile) the `:relative` protocol will be used.
(M) When the default protocol is explicitly set to `:request`, asset hosts are disabled whenever a request is not in scope thus effectively disabling this entire pull request.
(P) A user can set the default protocol to `:relative` if they want to use relative assets urls even when a request is in scope.
(M) Even if the default protocol is `:relative`, the default will be :request for stylesheet link tags to avoid the IE7-8 double download issue.
(P) If a user wants to use protocol relative urls for stylesheet link tags, they will need to explicitly set the protocol in their asset host configuration.
(M) As before, if a protocol is specified by the asset host, then that is always used.
/bump

title: Remove get*() and set*() prefix from the ChannelConfig methods
body:
(PD) To be consistent with the rest of our API, I think it would make  sense to remove the get and set prefix from all of the methods of ChannelConfig and sub-types...

@trustin WDYT ?
Fine to me.
(P) Shouldn't we also check many other classes, either?
I thought about this a little bit more.
(P) For classes with mutable properties such as ChannelConfig and SslHandler, I think it's better keeping get/set prefixes because it's less confusing.
(M) Only immutable classes (or classes with mutable state and only getters (i.e.
(M) only operations can modify the state)) could have getters without `get` prefix.

(P) Good candidates I found so far:

* `MonitorName`
* `MonitorProvider`
* `TimerTask`

The properties in `IdleStateHandler` are all immutable, but I think configuration properties need to have a prefix like `SslHandler` has for consistency.
(W) make s sense ...
Sent from my iPhone.

>

> MonitorProvider
> TimerTask

title: cache_key does not consult updated_on
body: (WD) The `Timestamp` module accommodates for both `updated_at` and `updated_on` timestamps, while `.cache_key` only checks `updated_at`.
(PD) I'm thinking a sane strategy would be to check if either or both exist, and use the max of the result for the cache key.
Thoughts?
(W) sounds reasonable.
(P) If we suport `updated_at`, we should suport it throughout the system.
@rafaelfranca what do you think?

I started a stab at it here: https://github.com/bemurphy/rails/commit/da737008c9ebc23685ad65277e4ac8b2f7390959

If we think it's a good idea, I can open a separate PR.
I'm not very happy with that code though.
(W) It's a) messy and b) seems to know a lot about updated_ column names.
(P) can you make  use of `ActiveRecord::Timestamp#timestamp_attributes_for_update` ?
(M) This would allow you to be independent of the exact names but still take all available names into account (it would even be dynamic).
https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/activerecord/lib/active_record/timestamp.rb#L89-L91
@senny yeah, I was looking at that earlier and thinking it looked useful.
I'll take a stab in the morning, thanks.
(W) ping me here if you need further assistance.
(W) I think this is a good change.
(M) @senny Maybe like https://github.com/bemurphy/rails/commit/e5e0b78a611a01b7457ab2836279f889103a574a.
Still messy;  I'm feeling hesitant to pollute the methods by extracting to `#max_updated_timestamp` or something, though.
(P) closed by #9105

(WD) Is it worth me doing a PR for this change or is it not likely to be accepted?
(M) You should use the "entity" type for dealing with Doctrine entities and collection.
(M) That type also correctly handles `ArrayCollection` instances.

title: Allow 'validatable' to disable including validations for :email and :password
body: (PD) This could be useful when someone is using :login instead of :email and wants to write custom validations.
(MD) Still I would like to use Model#password_required?
(MD) and Model.password_length methods when writing my own validations.
(PD) For that reason including the module could be useful but currently this cannot be done without skipping all that things that are done in included hook.
(P) At first, we didn't want to add :validatable (neither :registerable) to Devise because we knew that people would ask for several configuration options.
(M) So we decided to add them, but provide the minimum amount of configuration required.
(P) In other words, sorry but we won't add a configuration option to validatable (note this is not the first time we deny such request).
(P) You can simply copy the password validations and the required method to your model, it is just 6 LOC anyway.
I see your point.
(W) Would you add configuration options to that module if someone else take the time to implement it or you just don't want them to mess the code?
One more question about :validatable.
Shouldn't password_required?

(M) be defined like this:
    def password_required?
(M) !persisted?
(M) || password.present?
(M) || password_confirmation.present?

(W) end

Why does current code version check for !nil? .
This one is better for mass-asignment when the fields are not touched.
(W) I read in another issue that you think that changing password should be another view anyway, so is it the reason why it is implemented this way ?
(P) This is implemented this way because we want that every time there is a password field in your form, the validation happens.
(P) If we check for presence, things like reset password would accept sending empty password and password confirmation fields, since in this case they wouldn't be required.
(P) I know you are thinking about changing this for the edit/update user page, but remember that it is not the only place in your app that requires users updating/editing their password.

title: imlib2: require x11
body:
(PD) imlib2 without x11 has missing symbols needed by other programs
like feh.
(MD) Add a `depends_on :x11`.

(MD) Remove the deps on libpng
and freetype.
(PD) works well with superenv.
(PD) fixes #15325
@2bits @adamv Can we please discuss things like this before merging?
(P) This plainly doesn't need all of X11; as far as I'm concerned unless it runs in an X server we should consider `depends_on :x11` deprecated.
(P) @2bits Can we try and work out what bits of X11 it's linking to/using?

(P) It's only a problem I suppose because we can't specify a `depends_on 'imlib2' => 'with-x'`
The missing symbols are listed in #15325.
There are only two programs that use imlib2 in the main repo, feh and minbif.
In the case of feh, it's an x11 image viewer that started this issue.
In the case of minbif, that's a command line irc client.
(P) So it fixes one, and doesn't hurt the other.
I think that's the best I can do.
(P) @2bits Can you use `otool` to show me what `imlib2` links to when compiled with (and without if you have time) X11?
I'm avoiding installing XQuartz on this machine.
I guess the `depends_on with-x` stuff could be a useful comment for when @jacknagel's branch for that lands.
Thanks!

Built `--with-x` I get this:
```
$ otool -L /usr/local/lib/libImlib2.dylib 
/usr/local/lib/libImlib2.dylib:
	/usr/local/lib/libImlib2.1.dylib (compatibility version 6.0.0, current version 6.5.0)
	/usr/local/lib/libfreetype.6.dylib (compatibility version 16.0.0, current version 16.0.0)
	/usr/lib/libz.1.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.2.5)
	/usr/lib/libbz2.1.0.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.5)
	/opt/X11/lib/libX11.6.dylib (compatibility version 10.0.0, current version 10.0.0)
	/opt/X11/lib/libXext.6.dylib (compatibility version 11.0.0, current version 11.0.0)
	/usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 169.3.0)
```


When I build imlib2 `--without-x` I get this:
```
$ otool -L /usr/local/lib/libImlib2.dylib 
/usr/local/lib/libImlib2.dylib:
	/usr/local/lib/libImlib2.1.dylib (compatibility version 6.0.0, current version 6.5.0)
	/usr/local/lib/libfreetype.6.dylib (compatibility version 16.0.0, current version 16.0.0)
	/usr/lib/libz.1.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.2.5)
	/usr/lib/libbz2.1.0.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1.0.5)
	/usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib (compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 169.3.0)
```
The only difference is libX11.
Sucks.
Thanks, by the way.

(M) yw, here is the nm output of each build so you can see the difference in symbols:

[imlib.x11.txt][1]
[imlib.nox.txt][2]

[1]: https://gist.github.com/3872464
[2]: https://gist.github.com/3872466
Our new policy with X11 is: don't depend on it unless it absolutely requires it.
@2bits I've tweaked this further in 8cea93f and 8324107.
(P) Can you see if you can still reproduce the issue in #15325; I think this should fix it in `feh`, for X11 users and for people without X11.
Thanks!
Yes it still fails.
59a2f11 defaults to `without-x`.
(P) Should work fine now I guess.
(W) It's ok with me to have it as an option either way you default it, because jack's commit will eventually land.
(W) Thanks for working on this stuff.

title: "brew upgrade" should remember install options
body: (WD) When I installed coreutils I set the "default names" option ( `brew install coreutils --default-names` ).
(WD) however, when I ran `brew upgrade` it didn't remember this so it screwed up my setup.
I had to uninstall + reinstall the formula with the proper settings.
(WD) It's hard to keep track which settings you used for each formula upon install, and on which formulas you used them.
I feel this is something Homebrew should somehow remember.
I have thought of the same.
That whenever you install something, the "install" line is kept stored, so when e.g.
you `upgrade`, they stay the same.
Thank you for creating the feature request :)
One thing to note is that Homebrew currently doesn't really "remember" anything.
It writes no metadata files, maintains no package databases.
All of its intelligence on what is installed/not installed is basically derived from the output of  the `ls` command (there is a little more to it than that, but not much).
(P) Dependency resolution is computed solely from the class definitions in the formula files.

(P) I agree that this functionality is sorely needed, but it could be difficult to implement as Homebrew derives much of it's simplicity and elegance from pathologically avoiding the maintenance of persistant data.
(M) One place to look for inspiration on this front may be the [Nix](http://nixos.org/nix) package manager.
(P) Nix takes a "pure functional programming" appraoch to package management, so it has to be careful about how it handles state and side effects.
(P) It looks like [their appraoch to options and build flags](http://hydra.nixos.org/build/565033/download/1/manual/#sec-profiles) involves hashing them into the install prefix.

(P) One thought here is to write out a "homebrewed" file to the Cellar, so for instance:

````
/usr/local/Cellar/glib/
/usr/local/Cellar/glib/homebrewed - "--universal"
/usr/local/Cellar/glib/2.2.20/ - actual install files

So then `brew install glib` or `brew install -u glib` would read in the homebrewed file and try to use those options.
(M) Except having things in the Cellar above the version folders kind of messes things up.

(M) We could write this into the Cache: ~/Library/Caches/Homebrew/InstallInfo

But it's not really cached data like the downloads, ie, it shouldn't be deletable at will.
(P) Looking like Homebrew might need some non-Cellar, non-Cache folder to store persistent data in.
~/Library/Application Data/Homebrew is a logical choice, but now we're adding folders and complexity.

(M) New thought is that the "which_versions" method from the which command can be used to determine which version is currently installed and linked, so the metadata file can go in each version's prefix.
(P) When the version # in the formula changes, we essentially use `brew which` internally to find the previous version, and from there, the metadata file.
(W) I've been through a world of pain since I updated MySQL last time...
(W) It got re-build without --D_WITH_LOCALFILE because brew didn't "remember" I needed it, and I spent hours trying to figure out why MySQL was rejecting my statements.
I am a big fan of this feature request...
(M) Another place for inspiration could be Bundler and the Gemfile/Gemfile.lock.
(P) Maybe instead of trying to force Homebrew to handle all the persistent-data-intelligence, we could offload some of it to the user!

(P) Have the user maintain a ~/.brewfile with a plain list of formulas + settings they want on their system, and then you could run "brew install brewfile" which would go through the list and install everything you need on a machine.
(P) This would make  setting up new machines way easier as well!
(P) Then, when you run "brew upgrade" the first thing it would do is read tue brewfile and install whatever needs to be upgraded, with the appropriate settings.
Stupid idea?
(W) I would love what @minusfive suggests.
It could be inspired on what Bundler does in the Gemfile, indeed...

(W) So we could specify a specific version, a minimum version, and that kind of things... To ensure we are up to date, and don't get upgrades on stuff we do NOT want to upgrade (incompatible changes, etc...)
+1 on this.
(P) I specially like @adamv's first suggestion, adding a homebrewed file to the top level folder for each formulae.
(P) Proposed fix in pull request #7784.
(W) Installation options now persist when upgrading.
To do a clean install without re-using any old flags, `brew uninstall <formula> && brew install <formula>`.
(W) brew missing does not take this into consideration.

title: Allow replacing an inbound or outbound buffer of a handler.
body: (WD) Previous Netty 4 alphas did not allow replacing a handler's inbound/outbound buffer once it's created - it's final.
(WD) Is there any reason to keep it final though?
(PD) just like a user can replace a decoder on the fly using `ByteToMessageDecoder.replace(..)`, what if a user can replace a handler's inbound (or outbound) buffer very easily?
(PD) It will give a user an alternative way to implement a decoder (or encoder).

(PD) for example, a `fixedLengthFrameDecoder` could prepare two inbound buffers and simply wait until the first inbound buffer is full, and replace the first buffer with the second buffer to continue reading the second message.
(PD) There is no need to copy the frame from the buffer at all.
(P) Sounds good.. We just need to make  it safe to ensure the other does not mess-up something once we use pooled buffers.
Hi, all.

(W) I'm still learning the Netty internals and would appreciate some opinions on my attempted solution to this issue:

1.
What should the behaviour be when replacing with a null value?
(W) My implementation throws an NPE.
(P) This might be related to question 2 if we assume a null replacement should be treated as empty.
How should pending bytes in the old buffer be handled when the new buffer does not have enough space to store them?
(P) One idea is to create a composite buffer.
(P) I have not chosen how to handle this, other than to let the IndexOutOfBoundsException happen when I attempt a write from the old to new buffer.
(P) Note that when I transfer the data, I let the reader index advance from the old buffer.
After transferring the bytes, should discardreadBytes() be called on the old buffer?
Should the replacement operation be executed on the event loop?
(P) My implementation ensures this.
I'm testing the following decision: A null parameter wraps the old buffer in a read-only buffer.
(P) The reason: we want to drain whatever's left and then shut down the buffer.
i.e.
'null' means 'shut down'.

My thoughts:

1) I think throwing a NPE is preferable than accepting null as a value.
(P) If a user wants to replace with an empty buffer they could always use Unpooled.EMPTY_BUFFER.
(M) 2) In order to avoid making the "wrong decision" for any particular use case, we could force the user to choose what to do with any unread bytes in the buffer.
(M) They could always drain into a new buffer before replacement, or handle them in whatever way is appropriate after returning the old buffer.

(M) This would allow users to do things like limit the capacity of the buffer (for say a length delimited frame decoder) then swap the buffer when it is full without having to have "read" the bytes first or worry that they would be transferred to the replacement buffer.
(P) 3) If you don't transfer the bytes then nothing should be done on any buffer other than to swap the pointers.
4) Yes -- it should.
+1 to everything that @jpinner said
Would an exception be appropriate, then, for the case where a user is trying to replace the buffer and there are still readable bytes?
The operation could return the old buffer instance so that the user can append/prepend its content to the new buffer.
(P) this make s sense as it "may" be ok to replace the buffer even if it still has data left to read...
(P) The user may want to do exactly that
(W) Well, the implementation has just become a lot simpler...
(W) Being new to Netty development, where can I paste my git diff for this implementation to have it reviewed and discussed?

(W) The best would be to "fork" netty, commit and push your changes and then issue a pull-request..


Am 12.11.2012 um 20:44 schrieb ssilverman <notifications@github.com>:

> Being new to Netty development, where can I paste my git diff for this implementation to have it reviewed and discussed?

> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
Done.
merged in.. See #732

body: Conditionally removes the Gem.source_index for the `2-3-stable` branch.

(WD) probably complements #536

**NOTE** *(2 feb 2012):* I wasn't able to setup the rails `2-3-stable` development environment, if anyone can point me to some working  instruction/tutorial I'll happily do my homework :)
Pretty please.
Some of us still use Rails 2.3.x, and latest 2.3.x with latest rubygems results in ~40 lines of deprecation warnings from rubygems on startup.

(P) See: https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/issues/145   

The rubygems team does not seem to consider it a problem.
(P) @jrochkind can you test this patch on your app, as I said in the note above I wasn't able to find instructions on how to setup a 2-3-stable development env so some feedback would be useful
(about to be on vacation for two weeks, will try to do after I return.

(W) If I can figure out how to apply a patch to rails in a 2-3 app myself,  
I don't know either.)

On Feb 2, 2012, at 8:53 AM, Elia Schito wrote:

> @jrochkind can you test this patch on your app, as I said in the  
> note above I wasn't able to find instructions on how to setup a 2-3- 
> stable development env so some feedback would be useful
>
> ---
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/4422#issuecomment-3778169

(W) It's probably enough to put:

```ruby
require 'rails/gem_dependency'

module Rails::GemDependency
  def self.add_frozen_gem_path
    @@paths_loaded ||= begin
      original_source_index = Gem::Specification.respond_to?(:dirs) ?

Gem::SourceIndex.new(Gem::Specification.dirs) : Gem.source_index
      source_index = Rails::VendorGemSourceIndex.new(original_source_index)
      Gem.clear_paths
      Gem.source_index = source_index
      # loaded before us - we can't change them, so mark them
      Gem.loaded_specs.each do |name, spec|
        @@framework_gems[name] = spec
      end
      true
    end
  end
end
```

right before `Rails.boot!` in your application `config/boot.rb`.
(W) @elia The snippet in your last comment doesn't quite work.

I got this error when I tried it:

    GemDependency is not a module (TypeError)

Changing module to class results in the error going away and the original warning being silenced.
Have not tried this in production yet.

title: Multi-field and suggest api error

body: (P) Does it work if you search on title.title?

(P) I found the *issue* which is not exactly an issue.
Sorry.
I was wrong.

(P) You have two issues here:

* In your script, you need to add a refresh after the last index command
* You have 5 shards but only 2 documents.

title: Relax Rack dependency
body: Not sure why Rack is so tight specified.
(PD) I guess the are not going to happen major changes in minor releases.
There is no reason why Rails should not run against Rack 1.5 IMO.
(P) changes were necessary to make  Rails master work with Rack ~> 1.5.0, as you can see in 7d624e0e8cfa3adffd8f475e3588d83f3b367c24.
(P) I don't think those changes are going to be backported, so I guess 3-2-stable will have to stick with 1.4.x for now.
(P) Also, as a side note, we'd have to use `~> 1.4` instead of `>= 1.4.5`, otherwise we'd be freeing too much (for instance, rack 2.0 could be used and would be a breakage).
Thanks!

title: Add option --no-server
body: (PD) I often add the `server: true` option to the yaml file, but then sometimes would just like to render the site without starting the server, like in a command that just renders and then pushes the rendered content.
(MD) In that command I'd like to be able to use `--no-server` to have it override my `server` setting in the yaml config.
Cheers and thanks!

title: ofxOpenCv should do smarter allocation
body: (WD) ofImage allocates as needed and ofxOpenCv should too.
There is of course some issues to do with ROIs but if the image width is 0 thats a no brainer.
(PD) Also if the current ROI or current cv image is larger than the input it make s sense to either reallocate or do a smart roi based copy.
(PD) either way we need to get rid of crashes relating to allocate not being called - it is just no fun.

(P) everything should auto allocate as fas as possible the only problem i 
can see is people using the same object for images of different size and 
getting really low performance but it's better than getting crashes :)

btw, if you are working with ofPixels + opencv you should be using 
ofxCv: everything is so much easy and even faster cause there's no copies.

On 07/12/11 18:10, Theodore Watson wrote:
> right now if you do
>
> ofxCvColorImage color;
> color = pixRef;
>
> you get a nasty crash because you didn't call allocate first.
> ofImage allocates as needed and ofxOpenCv should too.

>
> There is of course some issues to do with ROIs but if the image width is 0 thats a no brainer.
> Also if the current ROI or current cv image is larger than the input it make s sense to either reallocate or do a smart roi based copy.

>
> either way we need to get rid of crashes relating to allocate not being called - it is just no fun.

>
> ---
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/openframeworks/openFrameworks/issues/839
yeah - that would be a separate issue I guess.
Evaluate ofxCv as a replacement :)
+1 for ofxCV
okay almost got this done.

(W) the current logic I am working with for a = b is : 

1) auto allocate if a is not allocated
2) log an error but don't crash if a is allocated and is a different size 

I am currently not re-allocating a to b's size if they are different as this seems something that could be slow and also undesired.
(P) so mainly just trying to make  things not crash and allocate only if its obviously needed.
(P) btw there are a ton of methods in ofxOpenCv which assume allocation but don't check for it.
(P) adding guards for checking allocation.

title: missing newlines in md file
body: Hi I've been using knitr for a while and suddenly all newlines in code chunks are gone.
All code chunks are externalized and tidy is off.

This is a code chunk

```r
## @knitr input
  input.size = if(rmr.options.get('backend') == "local") 10^4 else 10^6
  data = keyval(rep(list(1), input.size),as.list(1:input.size), vectorized = TRUE)
  input = to.dfs(data)
```

And this is in md 

```r
input.size = if(rmr.options.get('backend') == "local") 10^4 else 10^6  data = keyval(rep(list(1), input.size),as.list(1:input.size), vectorized = TRUE)  input = to.dfs(data)
```

I have everything in git, both Rmd and md,  so I am looking at diffs and scratching my head.

(PD) apc-2:docs antonio$ git diff introduction-to-vectorized-API.Rmd | head -30
    apc-2:docs antonio$ git diff introduction-to-vectorized-API.md | head -30
    diff --git a/rmr/pkg/docs/introduction-to-vectorized-API.md b/rmr/pkg/docs/introduction-to-vectorized-API.md
    index 945b31e..8faf5bd 100644
    --- a/rmr/pkg/docs/introduction-to-vectorized-API.md
    +++ b/rmr/pkg/docs/introduction-to-vectorized-API.md
    @@ -21,285 +21,166 @@ because of the inefficiency of the native R serialization on small objects, even
     First let's create some input.
(PD) Input size is arbitrary but it is the one used in the automated tests included in the package and to obtain the timings.
Here we are assuming a `"hadoop"` backend.
By setting `vectorized` to `TRUE` we instruct `keyval` to consider its arguments collections of keys and values, not individual ones.
At the same time `to.dfs` automatically switches to a simplified serialization format.
(PD) The nice thing is that we don't have to remember if a data set was written out with one or the other serialization, as they are compatible on the read side.
For testing purposes  we need to create a data set in this format to maximize the benefits of the `vectorized` option.

-  input.size = if(rmr.options.get('backend') == "local") 10^4 else 10^6
    -  data = keyval(rep(list(1), input.size),as.list(1:input.size), vectorized = TRUE)
    -  input = to.dfs(data)
    +  input.size = if(rmr.options.get('backend') == "local") 10^4 else 10^6  data = keyval(rep(list(1), input.size),as.list(1:input.size), vectorized = TRUE)  input = to.dfs(data)

     
     
    -
    -
     ### read it back
     The simplest possible task is to read back what we just wrote out, and we know how to do that already.

-
     ```r
         from.dfs(input)
     ```
     
    -
    -
     In the next code block we switch on vectorization.

(PD) That is, instead of reading in a list of key-value pairs we are going to have list of vectorized key-value pairs, that is every pair contains a list of keys and a list of values of the same length.
The `vectorized` argument can be set to an integer as well for more precise control of how many keys and values should be stored in a key-value pair.

(PD) With this change alone, from my limited, standalone mode testing we have achieved an almost 7X speed-up (raw timing data is in [`vectorized-API.R`](../tests/vectorized-API.R))
    apc-2:docs antonio$
Can you try the latest version (0.7) on Github?

`devtools::install_github('knitr', 'yihui')`

I cannot reproduce your problem with either v0.7 on Github or 0.6.3 on CRAN.
That's what I am running, 0.7

(P) I checked in several examples, for instance look here
https://github.com/RevolutionAnalytics/RHadoop/tree/dev/rmr/pkg/docs
files: tutorial.

(P) {Rmd,md,html}

If you can't repro I need to provide more information, any logs, and function to debug, let me know.
Oh, wait, I see the problem now.
(W) I must have introduce a bug in 992cea654fdce24e4c4e257fb08898b643f7a6ac.
(W) I'll fix it soon.
Thanks!
(P) should be fixed now; thanks!
It is indeed!
Thanks

      passenger_root = `passenger-config --root`.chomp

      if File.directory?

(PD) (passenger_root)

The passenger"

exit

            #"--with-http_geoip_module", #this is being completely ignored!

--with-webdav'

--with-geoip'
    
    system "./configure", *args

(PD) You'll need to turn off

  end

end

__END__

+++ b/conf/nginx.conf
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@

     server {
-        listen       80;
+        listen       8080;
         server_name  localhost;

         #charset koi8-r;
```
(P) solved it, 'brew install geoip' must be installed first.
(P) Then, in case of having an optional '--with-geoip' argument, we have to add another dependency to 'depends_on' variable.
(P) I commented in code below, and obviously the proper checking and error reporting or abort of installation should take place if 'geoip' package is not already installed.
(P) edit: solved, should be a good update for nginx.rb.

```ruby
require 'formula'

class Nginx < Formula
  homepage 'http://nginx.org/'
  url 'http://nginx.org/download/nginx-1.2.0.tar.gz'
  md5 'a02ef93d65a7031a1ea3256ad5eba626'

  devel do
    url 'http://nginx.org/download/nginx-1.3.0.tar.gz'
    md5 'b02e171c4a088aa9a5ab387943ce08eb'
  end

  depends_on 'pcre'
  depends_on 'geoip' if ARGV.include? '

--width-geoip'
  
  skip_clean 'logs'

  # changes default port to 8080
  def patches
    DATA
  end

  def options
    [
      ['--with-passenger', "Compile with suport for Phusion Passenger module"],
      ['--with-webdav',    "Compile with suport for WebDAV module"],
      ['--with-geoip',     "Compile with suport for MaxMind GeoIP module"]
    ]
  end

  def passenger_config_args
      passenger_root = `passenger-config --root`.chomp

      if File.directory?

(passenger_root)
        return "--add-module=#{passenger_root}/ext/nginx"
      end

      puts "Unable to install nginx with passenger suport.

The passenger"
      puts "gem must be installed and passenger-config must be in your path"
      puts "in order to continue."

exit
  end

  def install
    args = ["--prefix=#{prefix}",
            "--with-http_ssl_module",
            "--with-pcre",
            "--with-cc-opt='-I#{HOMEBREW_PREfix}/include'",
            "--with-ld-opt='-L#{HOMEBREW_PREfix}/lib'",
            "--conf-path=#{etc}/nginx/nginx.conf",
            "--pid-path=#{var}/run/nginx.pid",
            "--lock-path=#{var}/nginx/nginx.lock"]
    
    args << passenger_config_args if ARGV.include? '

--with-passenger'
    args << "--with-http_dav_module" if ARGV.include? '

--with-webdav'
    args << "--with-http_geoip_module" if ARGV.include? '
--with-geoip' # we need to add 'geoip' package to the depends_on in this case too, how to do that?

system "./configure", *args
    system "make "
    system "make  install"
    man8.install "objs/nginx.8"

    plist_path.write startup_plist
    plist_path.chmod 0644
  end

  def caveats; <<-EOS.undent
    In the interest of allowing you to run `nginx` without `sudo`, the default
    port is set to localhost:8080.

If you want to host pages on your local machine to the public, you should
    change that to localhost:80, and run `sudo nginx`.

(P) You'll need to turn off
    any other web servers running port 80, of course.

EOS
  end

  def startup_plist
    return <<-EOPLIST
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
  <dict>
    <key>Label</key>
    <string>#{plist_name}</string>
    <key>RunAtLoad</key>
    <true/>
    <key>keepAlive</key>
    <true/>
    <key>UserName</key>
    <string>#{`whoami`.chomp}</string>
    <key>ProgramArguments</key>
    <array>
        <string>#{HOMEBREW_PREfix}/sbin/nginx</string>
        <string>-g</string>
        <string>daemon off;</string>
    </array>
    <key>workingDirectory</key>
    <string>#{HOMEBREW_PREfix}</string>
  </dict>
</plist>
    EOPLIST
  end
end

__END__
--- a/conf/nginx.conf
+++ b/conf/nginx.conf
@@ -33,7 +33,7 @@
     #gzip  on;

     server {
-        listen       80;
+        listen       8080;
         server_name  localhost;

         #charset koi8-r;

```

(P) You can declare dependencies based on conditionals just like any other code:

```rb
depends_on 'geoip' if ARGV.include? '

--with-geoip'
```
cool, thanks jackangel.
(P) I solved my installation locally.
(P) would you update the nginx.rb in brew repository to have it for the next brew update?

(P) The current policy on nginx modules is that users should modify the formula to include modules that suit their needs, but we're not going to add any more modules to the core formula--there are simply too many.
alright, I'll back my copy up.

title: Provide libgit2-config utility to report installation location and compile flags
body: (PD) I have a GSoC student working on parrot-libgit2 and as part of our development process, we parse the source code of libgit2 (!).

(WD) He has reported that there is no automatic way to detect where libgit2 is installed https://github.com/letolabs/parrot-libgit2/commit/586ec4974d529c01bc05d3b7a40269ce931432f1#commitcomment-3491301 , so I wondered if that is a feature that is wanted.
(PD) If it is, I can provide a PR that implements something that will report the installation location of libgit2.
(MD) My vision would be to emulate the gsl-config utility that the GNU Scientific Library gives developers, which reports installation directories as well as compile and linking flags.
(M) Isn't that what `pkginfo` is for?
(M) `pkginfo libgit2` should load https://github.com/libgit2/libgit2/blob/development/libgit2.pc.in and return information about its installtion path.
Thanks!
That is perfect.

title: Additive Reflection
body: (PD) As suggested in this post: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13067079/additive-reflection-in-three-js  i'd like to request additive reflections.
(PD) If you have a Environment map which is black and white, you sometimes want to have only the whites to lighten your texture up but not the blacks to darken it.
(MD) Somehow like a specular reflection, but with an Environment map.
(MD) Or like an additive blending in photoshop.
(WD) Thank you guys for your amazing work!
(M) Hmmm, there have been always some looks that were hard to achieve with cube maps, maybe this would help.
(M) We could add additive combine mode for environment mapping.
Could you put somewhere an example of such model and cubemap for testing?

(P) https://dl.dropbox.com/u/48050531/webgl_loader_obj.html

Left to Right: only Illumination, Reflection: 0.4, Reflection: -0.4 and inverted and crunched Environmentmap (see Stackoverflow)

The third version actually works pretty well...

in this case the goal was to create something like porcelain
http://media.treehugger.com/assets/images/2011/10/leo-battistelli-recovered-porcelain-1.JPG
Cool, thanks.
I added a new combine type - `AddOperation`.

(M) This is how it looks (center one):

https://dl.dropbox.com/u/26786471/tmp/tests/additive-reflection/webgl_loader_obj2.html
Yay!
nice!
thanx guys!
(W) Looks much better in darker areas and doesn't change the saturation so much
Indeed!
It's great to finally have additive environment mapping.
This is such a common an effective resource in the demoscene ^^

title: Activesuport 3.1 dies with home_run
body: I'm hoping @tenderlove will swoop in and save the day.

(PD) This commit should be reverted because it causes issues when using home_run or MRI 1.9.3.
https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/080345baca1076a9788dff4803153600aec31f86#activesuport/lib/active_suport/core_ext/time/conversions.rb

The commit assumes Ruby provides private to_date and to_datetime methods on Time but these methods are undefined when using the home_run Date/DateTime replacement or when using 1.9.3.
The original unit tests are still present.
wot?

(P) Those methods seem to be available for me:

```
irb(main):001:0> require 'date'
=> true
irb(main):002:0> Time.now.to_date
=> #<Date: 2011-08-30 ((2455804j,0s,0n),+0s,2299161j)>
irb(main):003:0> Time.now.to_datetime
=> #<DateTime: 2011-08-30T16:48:29-07:00 ((2455804j,85709s,243278000n),-25200s,2299161j)>
irb(main):004:0> RUBY_VERSION
=> "1.9.4"
irb(main):005:0>
```
Oops, I didn't require date.
Sorry about that.
Well, the issue with home_run still exists.
(P) I think `home_run` should implement those if it wants to be compatible.
Ack.
(W) Why should home_run have to conform to a private, undocumented API?

(P) because it's a public, documented API in ruby 1.9:

  https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/ext/date/date_core.c#L8618-8623
  https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/ext/date/date_core.c#L8588-8595
(W) It's public and documented in a preview release.
Would you entertain a pull request that defines if undefined?

Sent from my iPhone

On Aug 30, 2011, at 7:10 PM, tenderlove<reply@reply.github.com> wrote:

> because it's a public, documented API in ruby 1.9:
> 
>  https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/ext/date/date_core.c#L8618-8623
>  https://github.com/ruby/ruby/blob/trunk/ext/date/date_core.c#L8588-8595
> 
> -- 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/2759#issuecomment-1951072
Yes, but it's not public in ruby 1.8.7.
What's the point of the public/private distinction if you are doing to depend on private methods using send?
No offense Aaron, but that's a bad excuse.
(P) :)  If you want to do it in Rails 4, fine, since that's going to depend on ruby 1.9.
But in 3.1?
(P) This isn't hard to fix in home_run, since it already implements the methods in 1.9 mode, but having to add them as private methods in 1.8 mode is stupid.
(P) @cgriego yes, that seems fine.
Ugh, I misspoke about only being in a preview release.
I suck at facts.
My apologies.
Pull request opened https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/2760

title: PHP exec issues
body: I've noticed an increase in the number of issues reported that have to do with PHP `exec`, `shell_exec`, etc.
crashing, hanging, etc.
when trying to execute PhantomJS.
I'm not certain that there _isn't_ a problem with PhantomJS's execution wrapper login that could be causing issues.
(PD) however, when I started researching this scenario on the web, I found a _massive_ number of hits mentioning similar problems with binary execution in general—let alone for PhantomJS—for PHP.
(PD)  I'm creating this issue to centralize those other issues into one so that we can perhaps work together to verify some of the potential configuration fixes that are _outside_ of PhantomJS.
(PD)  I've tried to sort what I've found from the most promising/easy to the least.
(WD) If you were suffering from PHP `exec` problems with PhantomJS, please let us know if any of the following resolve your issues in part or in whole.
Thanks!

(MD) **PHP `exec` issues and potential workarounds:**
 1.

(MD) [Corrupted binary if uploaded via FTP without enabling binary transfer mode](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16099278/executing-a-binary-on-linux-web-server-through-phps-exec)
 1.
(MD) Apache permissions issues: normal chmod permissions do not cover it!

(MD) [\[1\]](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11216839/phantomjs-doesnt-work-in-php-through-browser-but-does-via-command-line-and-ev), [\[2\]](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6913403/running-command-line-application-from-php-as-specific-user), [\[3\]](http://devlup.com/programming/php/capture-webpage-screenshot-using-php-and-phantomjs/4484/)
 1.

(MD) [Unhandled `stdin`, `stdout`, and `stderr` lead to Apache timeouts](http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.exec.php#102342)
 1.

(MD) [Non-executable invocation will return `126` exit code](http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.exec.php#83030)
 1.

(MD) [To avoid hangs, call `session_write_close()` before the call to `exec("phantomjs ...")`](http://michielve.blogspot.com/2013/04/phantomjs-cookie.html)
 1.

(MD) [Environment variables missing](http://phponlinesuport.com/topic115550.html)
 1.

(MD) [`shell_exec` garbles input](http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.exec.php#11317)
 1.

(MD) [Remember to use unix `exit(0);` on unix calls that use Unix redirection operator `>`](http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.exec.php#13379)
 1.

(MD) [Remove the `SIGCHLD` signal handler to avoid `-1` exit code](http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.exec.php#76687)
 1.

(MD)PHP manual special notes on [`exec`](http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.exec.php):  

    > _**Note:**_ If a program is started with this function, in order for it to continue running in the background, the output of the program must be redirected to a file or another output stream.
(MD) Failing to do so will cause PHP to hang until the execution of the program ends.

(MD) > _**Note:**_ When [safe mode](http://www.php.net/manual/en/features.safe-mode.php) is enabled, you can only execute files within the [`safe_mode_exec_dir`](http://www.php.net/manual/en/ini.sect.safe-mode.php#ini.safe-mode-exec-dir).
(MD) For practical reasons, it is currently not allowed to have _.._ components in the path to the executable.

(MD) PHP manual special notes on [`shell_exec`](http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.shell-exec.php):
    > _**Note:**_ This function is disabled when PHP is running in [safe mode](http://www.php.net/manual/en/features.safe-mode.php).

(M) php is bad on memory..
i think it's memory handling issues (my comments on 11498):
https://github.com/ariya/phantomjs/issues/11498
(W) I've tried almost every solution above to no avail.
(W) Hopefully this will help you solve the problem.
I can run my phantomjs command from terminal without a problem.
(P) When I run it with PHP exec it does work but hangs AND the generated image doesn't appear in the directory.
If I load my PHP script and comment out the exec command and refresh the page, it stops hanging.
If i then look in the directory, the generated image is there.
So somewhere between rendering the image and saving it, phantomjs gets stuck.
(W) I've tried 100 different things from all of the links above but cannot get it to work properly.
Hope this helps!
(P) FYI - after hours and hours and hours of this with no luck, I came across this page, which had the answer that worked for me.
FYI the server is Ubuntu 10.4 Lucid.

(P) http://stackoverflow.com/questions/45953/php-execute-a-background-process#45966

solution is:

Proc_close (Proc_Open ("/path/to/phantomjs /path/to/render.js param1 param2 &", Array (), $foo));

No hang, image generates immediately, no problems at all!

title: Several issues with the mailing list (librelist), time to look for an alternative?
body:
There are several issues currently with the mailing list on librelist:

0.
The website (http://librelist.com/) is currently down.
(WD) This might be transient, or this might be because the service has been slowly decaying over the last months.
The synchro to http://flask.pocoo.org/mailinglist/archive/ is broken since 2012/10/29.
I've been unsubscribed a few months ago due to transient a problem with my DNS.
(WD) I have since tried many times to subscribe again with the same address, with no success.
This may be a very specific problem, or this may be a manifestation of more general issues with the mailing list management system.
(WD) I have also tried registering with gmail adresses created just for the purpose of reading the Flask mailing list.
I've had mixed successes, and I've also noticed that some of the emails I could see on the librelist.com archives were not delivered to my account(s).
AFAICT, traffic to the mailing list has been going down over approximately the last 2-3 months.

(PD) This might be because interest in Flask is slowly fading away (if true, bad news for us Flask users), or this might be because of some of the technical issues I've mentioned above (or others), in which case proactive actions should be taken to keep users engaged.
(WD) For these reasons, I'm wondering if moving to another mailing list management platform would not be appropriate.
S.
(P) #666 is related, partial duplicate.
Appears that the first issue on your list was reported to the maintainer of librelist.com.

(P) https://github.com/zedshaw/librelist/issues/2

By the github address I just posted you can see that the mailing list code is publicly available.
So anyone interested in hosting the list could.
At which time they could address items 3 and 4 and contribute back to librelist.
(W) Regardless, it might be worth it to read the readME for librelist as it very clearly states that he needs help.
Maintaining the code for the list is a part time job that he does freely for the open source community.
(P) You might also want to post these issues to librelist's github page.
(W) Hard to fix an issue you don't know about.
Regarding point 2 on mailing list sync, librelist.com does not appear to be accepting connections from rsync.

The command in use:

    rsync -qazv librelist.com::json/flask _mailinglist/incoming

The error is:

    rsync: failed to connect to librelist.com: No route to host (113)

If I try from another host:

    rsync: failed to connect to librelist.com (71.19.156.177): Connection refused (111)
    rsync: failed to connect to librelist.com (2605:2700:0:5::4713:9cb1): Network is unreachable (101)

title: non existant https site hangs
body:
The following hangs: 

requests.get("https://nonexistant-1111111111.blib.us") 

When one uses this url on chrome/firefox, they right away say its non existant or connection was reset.
This is a https sni server.
Does this belong to a unit test?

(WD) Another related problem:

requests.get("https://register.blib.us", verify=False, timeout=3.0) -> SSLError

but both the following commands work fine (and get done within 5 seconds):

requests.get("https://register.blib.us", verify=False)
requests.get("https://register.blib.us")

title: IE7 .ir on (input[type=button\submit]) element
body: I couldn't find a related topic to this issue.
The image replace (`.ir`) class isn't quite working on `input[type=button|input]` elements the way we hope in IE 7.
(WD) The value still shows.

(PD) Sample of issue: http://jsfiddle.net/k2tkt/3/show/ (view this in ie7)

I usually apply a line-height since the overflow isn't visible.

(PD)  I would suggest (would be more than happy to submit the fix) something like the following: 

```.lt-ie8 .ir { line-height: 999em; }```

If we're trying to keep ie specific fixes out of the stylesheet, then this would work too:

```.ir { line-height: 999em; }```

Not sure if it make s sense to apply this for all browsers, but I don't see any harm in it.
(PD) Sample of fix: http://jsfiddle.net/k2tkt/4/show/ (view in ie7)
(P) We have added a `*line-height: 0` that fixes this issue in #811

title: ofxSvg in 0.8.0 is closing open paths.
body:
(PD) in the current version of ofxSvg a stroke / path which is a stroke ( ie not a filled shape ) 
is coming into OF as a loop ( ie an open stroke which is a 'c' shape, comes in as an 'o' 

looking through the changes from 0.7.4 to 0.8.0 this line seems to be the culprit, commenting it out allows for paths to be rendered correctly.

(PD) https://github.com/openframeworks/openFrameworks/blob/develop/addons/ofxSvg/src/ofxSvg.cpp#L90

probably what needs to happen is that if the svg is a non filled shape ( ie stroke/path ), then we don't set the winding.
(W) pinging @arturoc @joshuajnoble as you might know what the cause of this issue is.
(P) not sure, but yes checking if it's a stroke and not setting the winding seems the way to go.
(P) svg winding is non zero by default but i guess it doesn't work for strokes
sounds good!
I'll submit a PR for this.
(W) just wanted to (make  SURE), I wasn't missing anything.
(P) closed by #2371

title: haskell-platform recipe does not install documentation
body: (WD) If you `brew install haskell-platform`, having nothing installed, then although ghc and haskell-platform both are successfully installed, there is no documentation for any of the haskell platform libraries.
(WD) It turns out this is due to hscolor being missing.

(WD) I had to use the following, horrible hack to get things working on my system:

```
  def install
    # libdir doesn't work if passed to configure, needs to be set in the environment
    system "curl", "-o", "packages/hscolour-1.20.3.tar.gz",
        "http://hackage.haskell.org/packages/archive/hscolour/1.20.3/hscolour-1.20.3.tar.gz"
    system "tar", "-C", "packages", "-xzf", "packages/hscolour-1.20.3.tar.gz"
    system "perl", "-i", "-pe", 'print "hscolour-1.20.3\n" if $.

== 1',
        "packages/platform.packages"
    system "./configure", "--prefix=#{prefix}", "--enable-profiling"
    ENV['EXTRA_CONFIGURE_OPTS'] = "--libdir=#{lib}/ghc"
    ENV['PATH'] = ENV['PATH'] + ":" + Dir.getwd() + "/packages/hscolour-1.20.3/dist/build/HsColour"
    puts ENV['PATH']
    system "make  install"
  end
```

I can't really think of a better way to do this within the homebrew architecture.
(WD) Any suggestions?
(P) @jwiegley How about patching ghc recipe by adding a 'HsColour class' and install it after 'Ghcbinary.new.brew'?
I'm not sure how exactly to do that, @deftsp.
(M) Can you add it?
I'll try to do and test it, in the next couple of days.
PS: inspried by your @jwiegley  blog, I'm trying to running a fully local Hoogle :).
Very nice!

Here's the latest version of my Hoogle building script:

``` bash
#!/bin/bash -xe

DIR=/usr/local/tools/hoogle/cabal-dev/share/hoogle-4.2.16/databases

test -d $DIR || mkdir -p $DIR
cd $DIR

export PATH=/usr/local/tools/hoogle/cabal-dev/bin/:$PATH

function import_dbs() {
    find $1 -name '*.txt' \
        | parallel 'cp -p {} .

; perl -i -pe "print \"\@url file://{//}/index.html\n\" if /^\@version/;" {/}; hoogle convert {/}'
}

import_dbs ~/fpco/.hsenvs/ghc-7.4.2.9/.hsenv/cabal/share/doc
import_dbs /usr/local/opt/ghc/var/dot-cabal/share/doc

rm -f default.hoo rehoo*

time hoogle data -r -l $(echo *.txt | sed 's/\.txt//g')
time rehoo -j4 -c64 .
Sorry for the delay, I have another idea.
(M) haskell-platform depend on ghc, and to build ghc have to install ghc binary first.
(P) So, we can install a keg_only hscolour just after install ghc binary.
(M) It will enable us to build *both* ghc and haskell-platform with hscolour.
thanks for your new script, very useful.

title: p_stat() should follow symlinks on windows
body: p_stat() should follow symlinks on win32, like its Unix counterpart.
Unfortunately, I am not adding a unit test.
I have puzzled over this one for a while.
(WD) Only administrators can make  links on Windows.
I'm not sure how to detect when you've run clar as an administrator.

(PD) We can't even say "hey, let's not run the unit tests if I couldn't make  a link" because it appears that `createSymbolicLink()` returns 0 *even when it didn't do anything because you're not an Administrator*...  And after all that this test would only ever work when you ran the test suite as administrator.
Sigh.

Okay, two questions:

1.
(W) Does it actually work?
Did you try some scenarios manually?
(P) Could you test it by creating a function `can_symbolic_links_be_created()` that called `createSymbolicLink` and then stat'ed the result to check if the function succeeded?
(P)CThen you could write a test with a symlinked `.gitconfig` or other similar high level function that would be nice to have work with symlinks (as a thought).
(W) Very excited to have this in and finally be able to start closing some of those symlinks-on-Windows bugs!

(P) Yes, I think I could have eventually iterated to a test that was probably fairly heinous but succeeded in testing that `stat` now works and that symlinks to files are successfully detected as files and that config will thus read those files, but I failed in writing one that was sufficiently not heinous as I would want to contribute.
(P) This is more true because I doubt anybody runs VS as admin, nor any CI as admin, so it would really just be an exercise to run the unit test once.
Manual testing is probably a better use of everybody's time, here, I would think.

On May 5, 2013, at 10:06 AM, Russell Belfer <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Okay, two questions:
> 
> Does it actually work?
Did you try some scenarios manually?
> Could you test it by creating a function can_symbolic_links_be_created() that called createSymbolicLink and then stat'ed the result to check if the function succeeded?
Then you could write a test with a symlinked .gitconfig or other similar high level function that would be nice to have work with symlinks (as a thought).
> Very excited to have this in and finally be able to start closing some of those symlinks-on-Windows bugs!

> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
Sounds good.
(W) Running the test suite as Admin sounds like a bad idea, I agree...
We can give this more testing over here next week, I think.
(W) I am a bit nervous about the semantics of stat changing (hopefully needlessly) so I'd love to (make  SURE) this doesn't add some other crazy regression somewhere.

On May 5, 2013, at 5:11 PM, Russell Belfer <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Sounds good.

Running the test suite as Admin sounds like a bad idea, I agree...
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
(P) whether or not a user can create symbolic links on Windows is handled via the SecreateSymbolicLinkPrivilege.
(P) It is possible to give this right to non admins via the security policy editor.
(P) I'm not sure how easy it is to check for this privilige vs just trying to create a link and handle an error.
Hmm.
(M) Let me see if I can give myself that privilege and if I can identify its SID.
(P) That would make  life a lot easier.
Sounds like a fucking pain in the ass to test.
(P) You still need to have admin rights to give the privilege to start with, so that's not going to be an option for CI.
I don't think there's ever going to be a way to test this reliably and automatically.
(W) I'm not that worried about the automated tests because of issues with setting up a reliable environment to run them.
(W) I am curious about which issues this seems to fix and which ones not.
(W) I see, I never actually made it explicit what I meant to fix here.
(P) This was meant to (and testing suggests that it resolves) the issues around symlinks to configs.
(W) There *may* be other issues that this fixes, though I haven't seen bug reports that indicate such.
(W) There may be other, similar issues around using `git_path_isfile` on Windows, but I have not seen them.

I've tested where a repository and a global config are symlinks to regular files (success), to directories (fails, as expected) and multiple levels of symlinks to each of the following, all with good results.
Thanks @ethomson.
That's good enough for me.
Not particularly looking forward to playing with Win32 privileges to test this on CI, so gonna merge this for now.
@ethomson Thanks for the extra explanation.
:zap: :zap: :zap:

title: Resolving view name in Request Vars panel.
body: (PD) I've found it very helpful to resolve named views in Request Vars panel.
(MD) That way I can use 'reverse' with the given name in my source code without looking in urls.py.
(PD) This patch removes 'process_view' method from request vars panel.
This in turn breaks my 2 old tests.
(PD) In that case I've removed them and wrote 4 tests for request vars panel instead.
(MD) They basically cover all the view information in request vars panel.
(MD) The code and tests run differently on Django prior to 1.3 and Django >= 1.3 (see https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/http/urls/#resolve).
(PD) In the formem case the URL name is not resolved and `<unavailable>` is returned instead.
