title: Nested eager loading on polymorphic association
body: (WD) The current implementation of the preloader prevent  you from eager loading inexistent association.

(WD) [preloader.rb#L144](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/activerecord/lib/active_record/associations/preloader.rb#L144)
```ruby
def records_by_reflection(association)
  records.group_by do |record|
    reflection = record.class.reflections[association]

    unless reflection || record.class.reflections[association].options[:polymorphic]
      raise ActiveRecord::ConfigurationError, "Association named '#{association}' was not found; " \
                                              "perhaps you misspelled it?"

end

    reflection
  end
end
```

Which seem reasonable but then it as the side effect of preventing nested eager loading on certain type of polymorphic association.
(WD) keep reading!

_Here an exemple involving space exploration and experimentation on animals._

```ruby
class Vehicule < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :pilot, :polymorphic => true
end

class Astronaut < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :rank
  belongs_to :vehicule
end

class Rank < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :astronaut
end

class Animal < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :vehicule
end

buzz = Astronaut.create(:name => 'Buzz Aldrin')
Rank.create(:name => 'Colonel', :astronaut => buzz)

laika = Animal.create(:name => 'Laika')

Vehicule.create(:name => 'Lunar module', :pilot => buzz)
Vehicule.create(:name => 'Sputnik 2', :pilot => laika)

Vehicule.all :include => {:pilot => :rank} # Boom.
(WD) > "Association named 'Rank' was not found; perhaps you misspelled it?"

```

As you can see, ActiveRecord seem concern that you try to retrieve the army rank of an animal.
(WD) This is sad because as a side effect, it prevent you from eager loading the legit rank association of humanoid astronaut.

(WD) Given that polymorphic association can point to any model, records that don't have the association could be simply ignored since there is no warranty that the association is not valid for the other records.
I suppose this also apply to STI.

(PD) I would suggest be to simply remove that check, filter out records with missing association like [this](https://github.com/unixcharles/rails/commit/ea22076962eee4d6f233950a4745b4534ee02bae) and leave it up to the programmer to not eager load fantasy associations.
Please advice, thanks for your time!
:smile:
(W) I just ran into this today and it is kinda frustrating.
(P) There is probably a downside to just removing the error entirely but there should be some mechanism for handling this case in my opinion.
(W) I agree with you @thegrubbsian.
That's why I didn't made it a pull request.

(P) Ideally, when the Preloader know that the record came from a STI/Polymorphic association, it should assume that therefore nested missing relationships should be ignore since they are not predictable.
(P) This look like bit of a changes since at the moment the Preloader is not aware of where the query/parent object.
(P) Meanwhile, I made a small [gem](https://github.com/unixcharles/active-record-lax-includes) that monkey patch the preloader within a block.
I hope you find it useful.
(P) Hey, thanks @unixcharles, I just ran into this issue and your gem seems to be what I need.
Hey @desireco, I'm glad it was helpful for you.
Anyone at rails core: should this turn into a pull request against rails?
I'm not quite sure about this one.
It would be good to hear what @jonleighton thinks.
(P) I think this could be a reasonable feature, but my enthusiasm will be affected by the complexity of the implementation.
(P) If someone wants to take a stab at a patch, go ahead.

Following the steps you provided above I was not able to reproduce the problem.
(W) however, I was running on jruby 1.7.4 on osx instead of windows.
Could it possibly be a windows issue?

(M) Does running this in your rails console cause the issue for you:

```ruby
ActionController::ParamsWrapper::options.from_hash(format: []).to_h
```
(P) actually I see what the issue is.
(P) It is because you are running jruby in 2.0 mode and jruby in 2.0 does explode when calling ```to_h``` on an uninitialized struct.
(P) The issue is already fixed in jruby master by https://github.com/jruby/jruby/commit/2ed03ef87f2dc7b97437b670012485982128196a and will be included in jruby 1.7.5.
(P) I would probably just go back to using jruby in 1.9 mode because jruby 2.0 mode is still very experimental.
(P) since this issue seems related to JRuby, I'm giving it a close but if you can prove that it's rails related, let me know and I will reopen.
Thank you.

title: New Feature: Web Hooks for Notes
body: (MD) There are a few areas which are code-review related in which Gitolite could be integrated with another system, if it has a web hook.
(PD) for example, when a 'code review' is launched, the set of people participating may be different than the set of people on the 'team'.

(PD) This is actually quite common in our company, because the set of people who need to be able to fetch/build our code is quite different than the set of people that are actually maintaining the code.
(PD) For our company, the 'repo team' concept is   too wide to use for code review, since most of the people on the 'repo team' do not care about code reviews.
(PD) Something like https://github.com/supermatter/reviewthis might be just the thing, to notify the proper set of people for a given commit or merge req.

(PD) however, when one goes to comment on a particular file, commit, or merge req, there is currently no way AFAIK to extend this mechanism, for example, to notify others which are currently participating in the review, of the new comment.
For us, the 'team' concept is too spammy.
(PD) If GitLab suports web hooks for notes, then this type of extension is possible.
(PD) I see this as a short to medium-term appraoch.
(PD) FWIW, in the long-term, I would love to see the concept of a 'per-commit or per-mergereq review team'  in GitLab itself, which would meet our needs in a cleaner way.
(P) A different way of addressing this would be to build out suport for 'dynamic review groups' in the GitLab UI.

(P) When starting a review, you could specify who (in the team list) to invite, and then as you make  comments, perhaps having an checkbox to mail the 'review group', just like the existing checkboxes.
(M) The idea is that for each review, you could pick and choose which people to participate, and then as comments are made, that group could be notified.
(P) So for example, you could have a Merge Request review group, or you could have a post-Commit review group.
(P) (not quite sure how that would work -- I guess someone would need to kick off a review and select the review group participants.
(P) This could be done automatically by parsing the git commit message, for example).

title: Win32: (make  SURE) error messages are consistently UTF-8 encoded
body:
W/o this a libgit2 error message could have a mixed encoding:
e.g.

a filename in UTF-8 combined with a native Windows error message
encoded with the local code page.
Signed-off-by: Sven Strickroth <email@cs-ware.de>
(W) It is somewhat maddening to me that we have to do two heap allocations just to look up a Windows error message as UTF-8.
(W) however, I have looked on the internetz and cannot find a better way to do it (and actually find a number of people recommending exactly this same solution).

(P) :sob:

Could we write a wrapper around `FormatMessage` so these two places just use the same code to format and then re-format the message as UTF-8?

(P) If realize they are getting the error code from different Windows functions, but since this formatting has grown more complex, it would be nice to just to have a single "get the system message for this Windows error code as UTF-8 for me" function.

(P) I'm thinking something like:

```c
extern char *win32_get_error_message(DWORD error_code);
```

which would do the `FormatMessageW`, `git__calloc`, `WideCharToMultiByte` and the `LocalFree` for the value from the `FormatMessageW` and just return the (to-be-freed-by-caller) UTF-8 error string.
I made some comments in the diff, but now I don't see them, so maybe they got lost.

It would be great if we could:
1.
(P) Use CP_UTF8 if we want to get UTF-8 out of WideCharToMultiByte.
(P) We should pass -1 instead of size to WideCharToMultiByte to indicate that the input string is null terminated and that the output string should also be null terminated.
(M) (FormatMessage always returns a null-terminated string.)
(P) We should make  2 calls to WideCharToMultiByte instead of trying to predict the size of the UTF-8 string in advance.
(P) If we do steps 2 and 3 above, then it should be sufficient to use git__malloc instead.
(P) We need to check all return codes, keeping in mind that on failure (presumably due to OOM), that returning -1 is probably not the best choice from the function that creates error strings.
(P) I see we are not checking return codes on some of the later git_buf calls -- we should fix that.
@arrbee Where to put win32_get_error_message?
Good question!
(M) Maybe `src/win32/error.h` or something like that?
(W) I'm open to suggestions.
It doesn't look like there is a good existing header to put it in...
(W) I tried to honour all your suggestions.
Hope it did not forget anything.
@arrbee Can you please re-review.
(W) @phkelley noted, that I need to do the error checking for git_buf_PUTS and git_buf_puts.
For future reference: the `buf` API has been designed against OOM conditions.
(M) If one of the normal `put` calls fails, the buffer will be "disabled", so you can continue using it as normal: all subsequent calls will fail silently.
Looks really good.
Thanks

title: show_placeholder doesn't add CSS
body:
I use my plugins: **3columns.html:** ```html {% extends 'mainframe.html' %} {% load cms_tags placeholder_tags %} {% block content %}
{% block column-left %}{% placeholder "left_column" or %}{% show_placeholder "left_column" 'homepage' %}{% endplaceholder %}{% endblock %}
{% block column-center %}{% placeholder "content" %}{% endblock %}
{% block column-right %}{% placeholder "right_column" or %}{% show_placeholder "right_column" 'homepage' %}{% endplaceholder %}{% endblock %}
{% endblock %} ``` **plugin.html:** ```html {% load i18n sekizai_tags %} {% addtoblock "css" %}{% endaddtoblock %}

    {% for trade in trades %}
  • {{ trade.name }}
    • {% endfor %}

    {% for country in countries %}
  • {{ country.name }}
    • {% endfor %}
``` The problem is, after server restart all is ok, but after next page reload (subpage, not index) CSS declared in plugin is not being added.

(PD) When I change :
```html{% show_placeholder "left_column" 'homepage' %}``` to ```html{% show_uncached_placeholder "left_column" 'homepage' %}``` ALL IS OK.
Problem is cached content forgets about sekizai.

(P) We need to make  caching
also include the sekizai blocks somehow.
Arguably a sekizai issue.

On Jan 8, 2013 4:23 PM, "Robert Węglarek" wrote: > I use my plugins: > > *3columns.html:* > > {% extends 'mainframe.html' %} > {% load cms_tags placeholder_tags %} > {% block content %}
{% block column-left %}{% placeholder "left_column" or %}{% show_placeholder "left_column" 'homepage' %}{% endplaceholder %}{% endblock %}
{% block column-center %}{% placeholder "content" %}{% endblock %}
{% block column-right %}{% placeholder "right_column" or %}{% show_placeholder "right_column" 'homepage' %}{% endplaceholder %}{% endblock %}
> {% endblock %} > > *plugin.html:* > > {% load i18n sekizai_tags %} > {% addtoblock "css" %}{% endaddtoblock %}
>

>
>
    > {% for trade in trades %} >
  • > {{ trade.name }} >
    • > {% endfor %} >
>
>

>
>
    > {% for country in countries %} >
  • > {{ country.name }} >
    • > {% endfor %} >
>
> > The problem is, after server restart all is ok, but after next page reload > (subpage, not index) CSS declared in plugin is not being added.

When I
> change :
> html{% show_placeholder "left_column" 'homepage' %} to html{%
> show_uncached_placeholder "left_column" 'homepage' %} ALL IS OK.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/divio/django-cms/issues/1577>.

Okay now I'm at my laptop explain me the situation a little:

``show_placeholder`` by default caches it's result.
(P) therefore, the template is only executed when it hits a cold cache.
(P) since sekizai uses templates, it's blocks are only injected when the template is executed.
(P) If ``show_placeholder`` hits a warm cache, it just renders the contents from the cache, not executing the templates, thus not triggering sekizai.

(P) The solutions has two steps (the first being optional):

1.
(P) Sekizai implements a way to "watch" for data being added.
(M) This will most likely be a context manager.
(M) 2. django CMS caches the sekizai data along the rendered HTML.

(P) Basically in CMS land this would turn  ``_show_placeholder_for_page`` into something like this:

```python

def _show_placeholder_for_page(context, placeholder_name, page_lookup, lang=None,
        site=None, cache_result=True):
    """
    shows the content of a page with a placeholder name and given lookup
    arguments in the given language.

(P) This is useful if you want to have some more or less static content that is
    shared among many pages, such as a footer.

(M) See _get_page_by_untyped_arg() for detailed information on the allowed types
    and their interpretation for the page_lookup argument.
    """
(W) If this sounds reasonable I'll starting implementing the required APIs in sekizai.
(W) Is it included in 2.4b?
(W) no this was not included in 2.4b1
(P) @digi604 before the next beta/rc, this really has to be resolved.
(W) I'll see how much I can get done tonight to solve this issue.
(W) Started work on this and can easily reproduce it in tests.
(W) I'm at a hackathon until Sunday so should have plenty of time to resolve this, stay tuned.

(P) Hmm,
i update my libs by:
pip install -U -e git://github.com/divio/django-cms.git@master#egg=django-cm
but I still have to use show_uncached_placeholder.

title: Dump specially encoded types as binary blobs in AOF rewrites
body: (MD) Small aggregate values such as lists and sets use an internal representation that is already serialized and arch-independent.
(PD) however when we rewrite the append only file using the BGREWRITEAOF command we deserialize this values into many single-value operations.

(PD) For instance a three elements list will be rendered inside the rewritten AOF as:
    RPUSH mylist value1
    RPUSH mylist value2
    RPUSH mylist value3
This is a lot of wasted work both for the AOF creation and for the AOF reloading.
(PD) instead we should put serialized values into the AOF in the direct format using some special command, possibly only valid in the context of AOF.
(PD) This will severely improve the AOF performance.
(PD) This technique is already used in the creation of RDB files.

(PD) An alternative to what proposed above would be to change format to AOF allowing for an initial section of the AOF in the form of an RDB file itself, so that we could just dump the RDB and a sequence of accumulated commands when doing the AOF rewrite operation.
(PD) This is a valid alternative but with the side effect of not having an easy to process AOF.
There is definitely to think more about this but is an interesting optimization.
(P) An alternative to the alternative would be to make  the RDB dumping and AOF cooperate more closely.
(P) I've been thinking a little about that (before I found this).
It could have several advantages.
First a short overview of what I mean.
(P) We could stop doing AOF rewrites entirely and use RDB files instead.
(P) When it's time to rewrite the AOF we would instead start a new AOF file (keeping the old one) and at the same time start a background save.

(P) The RDB would contain the name of the new AOF file, so when the RDB has been saved completely we can restore the data simply by loading the latest RDB and then reading from the AOF file that it points to.
(P) As there can be several AOF files at the same time with this method, we need to number them in some way and (make  SURE) that we continue reading all the newer ones too (i.e.
(M) those with a higher number).
(P) Before the background save is completely done, we will therefore still be able to load our data by starting at an older RDB instead.
(P) When appendonly mode is first enabled we would also save an RDB and at the same time start writing a new AOF with changes.
(M) Whenever we start a background save we could always start a new AOF at the same time (why not?
(P) ), so they would be closely linked.
(P) We could safely remove old files when they are no longer needed (or allow the user to do something with them, like archiving them somewhere).
(P) With just a little additional work we could also suport point-in-time-recovery (PITR) like e.g.
PostgreSQL.

(P) We just need to store a timestamp in the AOF each time we flush it (max one per second), have a timestamp in each RDB and then make  it possible to load up to a certain point (select the correct RDB if several and read the AOFs up to that point).

(P) If you keep old AOFs and RDBs you would then always be able to restore data at any point in time :)

It would also be good because then there would be only a single algorithm to optimize for both background saves, slave syncs and AOF "rewrites", so everything would benefit from improvements and it would (perhaps) be easier to maintain.

(P) For this to be as useful as possible, I think it's important to make  it easy to archive old AOFs and RDBs and perhaps even 
implement PITR as described above (PITR would be awesome!
See e.g.
PostgreSQL for ideas on both).
(P) The biggest problem would be to make  it easy to upgrade to this new system.
That should be solvable, though.
Hope that was pretty clear.
An interesting idea, at least!
What do you think?
(P) The right direction for Redis persistence or better to keep them separate?
(M) (Perhaps it would be better to post this to the ML, but it's so very related to this.
Would be awesome to get the issues to the mailing list too again.
(P) might be possible some way.)

Cheers,
Hampus

title: segmentation fault
body: _**[jerom...@gmail.com](http://code.google.com/u/117573970775905432410/) commented:**_ > Which version of PhantomJS are you using? 1.2.0 > > What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. phantomjs parser.coffee http://www.zappos.com/audjie-magus-brown-leather > > What is the expected output?

(WD) > > Which operating system are you using? OS X 10.7 > > Did you use binary PhantomJS or did you compile it from source? brew update || brew install phantomjs > > Please provide any additional information below. Parser and crash report attached.

**Disclaimer:**
This issue was migrated on 2013-03-15 from the project's former issue tracker on Google Code, [Issue #192](http://code.google.com/p/phantomjs/issues/detail?id=192).

title: A LESS version!
body: (PD) I've seen that a LESS version of the css is (possibly) in the works as of three months ago, any news on that?
(PD) A LESS version of the foundation system would be amazing.
(P) +2 We really need this, could be as simple as doing this: http://stackoverflow.com/a/6073820 ?
(P) foundation 3.0 is going to be written using SCSS/Sass, and then available as a (compass) gem in addition to the existing straight CSS version.
(P) I imagine once we have 3.0 rewritten into SCSS a Less port would be very easy to create / maintain.
(W) I know picking Sass or Less means pissing off everyone from the other camp but whaddya do?

(M) Here, https://github.com/alexanderbeletsky/foundstyles/

I extracted some variables into corresponding .LESS files.
(P) You might use that, before actual suport of LESS/SASS will be present in foundation;
You are a god among men, alexander.

-1

Pop over here: https://github.com/cloudhead/less.js/issues/49 for a little background.
(W) But essentially, there are bugs in LESS going back 2 years, with fixes that have never been acknowledged or pulled.
(W) The bug I've linked actually shows up in the *default* installation of Twitter Bootstrap.
(W) At the time of this writing, there are 353 bugs and 77 unreviewed pull requests.
Anyway- LESS is a really great piece of technology.
(W) Brilliant in fact.
As an open source project, I feel like it's unfortunately mismanaged.
Including LESS as a dependency would be, in my opinion, a mistake.
(P) Especially when SASS is equally as strong and the suport and community seems to be stronger (especially now that it's ia default in Rails).
I hope this doesn't come across as a bash or troll.
(W) I just think there's a clear, equally powerful alternative to LESS.
(P) I will try to create a LESS version soon...
(P) I plan to use it with my (foundation based) Flexibility MODX template: https://github.com/DESIGNfromWITHIN/Flexibility
Great!
(P) 3.0-scss branch has our Sass implementation.
We won't be developing a Less version, though anyone interested in forking and doing so is welcome to.
+1 I'd like to see Less compatibility.
(P) Less might have bugs like @jeremyricketts mentioned, but they must not be significant because I haven't experienced any bugs and have been using Less in my last projects without any hinderance.
Mybe I'm not using it's full potential.
It'd be convenient for some of us not to have to switch from Less to Sass.
(W) Guys, I'm working on a LESS version for foundation.
It's not done yet, but will be within a couple days.
See [here](https://github.com/srsgores/warp-kickstrap).
(M) Also, you don't have to wait for me to finish: [there's a php parser online](http://code.google.com/p/phamlp/).
I am currently maintaining a LESS version that is a almost mirror of the Sass version for my company.
(W) We are planning on open sourcing just haven't had the chance to work out the details just yet.
(W) @sjonnet19 : Any update on the LESS version?
I would love that!
I apologize for the delay in this we are in an agressive sprint that will hopefully be finished end of next week.
As soon as that is over I plan to sit down and see about open sourcing our Less version.
:+1: using LESS is a hell lot easier.
Waiting for LESS version as well!
Please, please, please!
I would really like a LESS version too :)
+1 would like a LESS version too

Main reason that I'm interested in LESS version, is that for some systems (.net for instance) setting up Ruby so you can use sass/compass is an unbelievable nightmare and the ports of Ruby etc are _very_ slow.
DotLessCss is a pretty good asp.net port of LESS.
I can't see this happening to be honest, but there is definitely a use-case, and I'd love to see it.
(W) I don't think this is possible.
(P) The only way a LESS version will happen, is if a few of us take ownership and fork foundation, updating it with every release.
(W) It's not inconceivable, it just needs a couple of days thrown at it.
+1 would like a LESS version very much!
+1 Give us the LESS!
@smileyj68 Is there any reason in particular to pick Sass over Less?
(W) just curious and maybe I'll learn something.

(W) +1

Using SASS in .NET environments is a bit of a turd, and in VS2012 update pack 2, LESS is now a first class language!
^ Or use vagrant.
It's a pity that there isn't a version with less, I like foundation but without less I can not use it!
+1 still waiting!
Sorry guys we dropped the fork and went with SCSS.
It was a nightmare to maintain and SASS features where killing us when trying to re-implement.

+1

--
Berkay UNAL
www.berkayunal.com


On July 16, 2013 at 12:12:25 PM, Sam Blowes (notifications@github.com) wrote:

+1

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
I love the look of foundation, but I don't like SASS at all.
Guys, this isn't practical.
The _only_ way this will happen, is if someone starts a LESS fork.

(P) If you need solutions for Windows environments:
* Use .NET Bundling + BundleTransformer (+IronRuby...): http://bundletransformer.codeplex.com/
* Use a VM for real Ruby/SASS, vagrant is great for managing this kind of thing: http://www.vagrantup.com/
* Use LESS on top of 'precompiled' foundation

Considerations:
* .NET Bundling + BundleTransformer: HASSLE to set up, slow
* VM/Vagrant: Slight learning curve, extra OS/environment to learn, FAST
* Less on top of 'precompiled' foundation: Less control of code, fast compiling, slightly bigger deliverables

title: Pow/Rack: Autoregenerate site on page load
body:
(PD) I got sick of `rake generate`ing every time I changed something to check it locally in the browser, so I wrote a quick and dirty implementation of auto-regeneration: Peeja/peeja-blog@679906e

I'm not pull-requesting it because I'm sure there are better ways to write this.
Would someone give me a hand?
In particular, the code's pretty brazen about shelling out, and I'm not sure if `#latest_modification_time_in` is optimal.
(P) Also, it requires moving `public/` to another directory, which is a big change.
(P) You can try `rake preview` instead of `rake generate` when you just changed something to check it.
(P) in addition, LiveReload may interest you.
(P) I specifically want to run this through Pow so I don't have to manually start anything to make  it work.
(P) I'll look into how `rake preview` works, though; that might provide a better implementation.
(P) Pow works fine for me when I have ´rake preview´ up and running -- I can go to http://blog.dev/ and things will be auto-generated as soon as I save the source files.
edit: ...which isn't what you asked about.
Yeah, early in the morning here.
(P) But that's how I do it when writing a new post, I have ´rake preview´ running and then check the local site via Pow until I'm done writing.
`rake preview` does exactly what you're describing.
No, `rake preview` only runs if you run `rake preview`.

This
regenerates the site through Pow, which is already running.

(P) That
means that I can start editing a post and see it immediately in the
browser, without having to remember to run `rake preview` somewhere
and keep it running in some terminal window.

(P) This just always works
in the background, because Pow is already set up that way.

(M) It may not
sound like a big difference, but it was frustrating enough that this
was worth writing.

(P) I certainly won't insist that it make  it into mainline Octopress, I
just wanted to see if people thought it was worth it.

(P) But I want to
be clear that it's different from `rake preview`.

On Fri, Dec 28, 2012 at 2:12 AM, Parker Moore <notifications@github.com> wrote:
>
> rake preview does exactly what you're describing.

:)
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

--
Sounds: http://www.welikethisnow.com/
Words: http://blog.peeja.com/
Conversation: (603) 548-1203
Your'e right it's different than rake preview, though I'll say I don't think it's a good idea to for Octopress right now due to the fact that Jekyll doesn't have partial regeneration.
(M) This means that every time a user hits their dev url, Pow will fire up and regenerate the whole site.
The way it is now, users only regenerate when they mean to.
(P) A change like this would cause annoyance to people with larger sites whose blogs take much longer to generate.
(W) A neat idea, and I wish it could work like this, but it isn't really compatible with how Jekyll is designed.

title: Add openSUSE certificate suport
body: (MD) openSUSE ships Mozilla CA certificates in a directory (/etc/ssl/certs) and for compatibility as a bundled pem (/etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem), the first is preferred though.
(PD) This patch adds suport for both, i.e.
(PD) if a path is found in possible_CA_BUNDLE_PATHS, it checks whether the ssl module suports it.
(PD) otherwise, the pem file is used (listed after '/etc/ssl/certs' in possible_CA_BUNDLE_PATHS).
This pull request [passes](http://travis-ci.org/kennethreitz/requests/builds/1410438) (merged b22088fd into de1637c3).
Looks good to me.
Cool!
(P) actually is it possible to do this using the public `ssl` API, e.g., `ssl.wrap_socket` instead of `_ssl.sslwrap`?
ssl.wrap_socket expects 'keyfile' and 'certfile', you can't pass a directory.
(P) AFAICS, the situation will improve with Python-3.3, where the ssl module will pick OS defaults by itself: http://bugs.python.org/issue14780
Sounds good to me.
(P) actually, wait, I think this is not going to work, because `urllib3` uses `ssl.wrap_socket`, not `_ssl.sslwrap`.
(M) So if `wrap_socket` does not understand directories, then our code will not either.
(M) See `VerifiedHTTPSConnection` in this file: `requests/packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py`.
So be it, then the fallback file is used

(P) Well, it seems like there are two possibilities:

1.
(P) `ssl.wrap_socket` suports (without documentation) passing a directory instead of a file as its `ca_certs` parameter.

(P) In that case, this patch is correct, except that it should use `ssl.wrap_socket` instead of `_ssl.sslwrap` (since that is a more accurate test of whether Requests will work with CA certificate directories).
(P) `ssl.wrap_socket` does not suport this, despite the backing function `_ssl.sslwrap` suporting it.

(P) In that case, there is no hope of Requests ever being able to use a certificate directory, and this patch should just be the one-line addition of `/etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem` as a possible CA certificate bundle file.
(P) Have you observed Requests to work correctly with `/etc/ssl/certs` on your system?
Thanks for your patience by the way :-)

Hi, sorry for the delay, I did the following to test it:

```python
>>> import ssl,socket,pprint
>>> ssl_sock = ssl.wrap_socket(s,cert_reqs=ssl.CERT_REQUIRED,ca_certs='/etc/ssl/certs')
>>> ssl_sock.connect(('www.verisign.com', 443))
>>> print repr(ssl_sock.getpeername())
('69.58.181.89', 443)
>>> print ssl_sock.cipher()
('DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA', 'TLSv1/SSLv3', 256)
>>> print pprint.pformat(ssl_sock.getpeercert())
{'notAfter': 'May 17 23:59:59 2014 GMT',
 'subject': ((('1.3.6.1.4.1.311.60.2.1.3', u'US'),),
             (('1.3.6.1.4.1.311.60.2.1.2', u'Delaware'),),
             (('businessCategory', u'Private Organization'),),
             (('serialNumber', u'2158113'),),
             (('countryName', u'US'),),
             (('postalCode', u'94043'),),
             (('stateOrProvinceName', u'California'),),
             (('localityName', u'Mountain View'),),
             (('streetAddress', u'350 Ellis Street'),),
             (('organizationName', u'Symantec Corporation'),),
             (('organizationalUnitName', u'Infrastructure Operations'),),
             (('commonName', u'www.verisign.com'),)),
 'subjectAltName': (('DNS', 'verisign.com'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.net'),
                    ('DNS', 'verisign.net'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.mobi'),
                    ('DNS', 'verisign.mobi'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.eu'),
                    ('DNS', 'verisign.eu'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.com'))}
>>> ssl_sock.write("""GET / HTTP/1.0\rHOST: www.verisign.com\r\n\r\n""")
41
>>> data = ssl_sock.read()
>>> data
'HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently\r\nDate: Wed, 06 Jun 2012 14:51:17 GMT\r\nServer: Apache\r\nLocation: https://www.verisign.com/\r\nCac
he-Control: max-age=2592000\r\nExpires: Fri, 06 Jul 2012 14:51:17 GMT\r\nVary: Accept-Encoding\r\nContent-Length: 233\r\nConnection: c
lose\r\nContent-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1\r\n\r\n'
>>> ssl_sock.ca_certs
'/etc/ssl/certs'
>>> ssl_sock.close()
```

So, I assume "1."
Changing the check to ssl.wrap_socket won't change much, ssl.SSLSocket (returned by ssl.wrap_socket) uses _ssl.sslwrap internally (have a look at /usr/lib64/python2.7/ssl.py).
(P) Finally, requests.models.Request has "conn.ca_certs = cert_loc = DEFAULT_CA_BUNDLE_PATH", thus passing a path works for me ;-)
(W) Excellent, I believe that 1 is in fact the case.

(P) I would greatly prefer it if the patch could use `ssl.wrap_socket` instead of `_ssl.sslwrap`, though, for the following reasons:

1.

(P) The behavior that Requests will actually take advantage of is the ability of `ssl.wrap_socket` to use a directory as its `ca_certs`, so it is a more direct test of the required functionality
2.
(P) since `_ssl.sslwrap` is not part of the public API, it's possible (although unlikely) that it might be renamed or moved in future.
(P) It seems much better to use undocumented behavior of the public API than to use an (also undocumented) private API.

(M) The intended meaning of `DEFAULT_CA_BUNDLE_PATH` was "fully qualified path", not "a directory as opposed to a file" :-)

Thanks again!
(W) Sorry about the delay, I think I missed the GitHub notification.
(W) I agree that using ssl.wrap_socket would be much better.
(P) however, ssl.wrap_socket does not complain about invalid parameters (by throwing an SSLError exception like _ssl.sslwrap), only ssl.SSLSocket.connect() does.
(P) So, doing the check with ssl.wrap_socket would actually include a real request, e.g.

(P) like this:

```diff
--- a/requests/utils.py
+++ b/requests/utils.py
@@ -15,7 +15,6 @@ import os
 import re
 import socket
 import ssl
-import _ssl
 import zlib
 from netrc import netrc, NetrcParseError
 
@@ -57,7 +56,9 @@ def get_os_ca_bundle_path():
             if os.path.isdir(path):
                 try:
                     # Current candidate is a directory, check if SSL module suports that
-                    _ssl.sslwrap(socket.socket()._sock, False, None, None, ssl.CERT_REQUIRED, ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv23, path, None)
+                    ssl.wrap_socket(socket.socket(),cert_reqs=ssl.CERT_REQUIRED,ca_certs=path)
+                    ssl_sock.connect(('www.verisign.com', 443))
+
                     return path
                 except:
                     pass # No suport, let's check the next candidate
```

I don't think this is really desired but I don't see any other way to it ATM.
What do you think?
(W) I'm sorry I'm such a pedant, but the use of `_ssl` still make s me uncomfortable.
(P) If you're continuing to ship `/etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem` for compatibility, could we just use that?
(P) Yes, that would be an options for the time being and in order to get this solved, I'll provide a stripped down patch, deal?
But this may become an issue again, as /etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem is long time deprecated ;-)
Deal.

title: Generalized immediate render callbacks?
body:
(WD) Hi group,

As per one of my previous posts, I've been working on a large mesh rendering pipeline using chunked LoD.
I've heavily modified the code in the webglrenderer to treat my objects as immediate rendering objects, and hence initiate the rendering callback on each frame render pass...
I'm doing quite a bit of optimization steps, such as reusing mesh vbos and morphing them in the vertex shaders, packing (interleaving) attributes together into larger buffers, ...
This gives me a smooth 60fps across the board, but obviously means not much of the original renderBufferImmediate code remains the same.

(PD) So what I'd like to propose/implement is a more generalized immediate rendering mode, where the low-level control is available for these specialized cases, and each implementation basically provides its own renderBufferImmediate code.
(WD) The big question I have however: is this even possible?
(PD) For a custom render function to be registered into the WebGL renderer, that function would need access to the _gl context and such, which is passed in to the WebGL renderer functions by closure.
(WD) Is there any way to expose this context in callback functions without extensive changes to the renderer (e.g.

without making all of the relevant variables actual members of the renderer etc...)

thanks!
(P) FYI @NINE78 has patched this into dev in #592

title: Add openSUSE certificate suport
body: openSUSE ships Mozilla CA certificates in a directory (/etc/ssl/certs) and for compatibility as a bundled pem (/etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem), the first is preferred though.
This patch adds suport for both, i.e.
if a path is found in possible_CA_BUNDLE_PATHS, it checks whether the ssl module suports it.
otherwise, the pem file is used (listed after '/etc/ssl/certs' in possible_CA_BUNDLE_PATHS).
This pull request [passes](http://travis-ci.org/kennethreitz/requests/builds/1410438) (merged b22088fd into de1637c3).
Looks good to me.
Cool!
actually is it possible to do this using the public `ssl` API, e.g., `ssl.wrap_socket` instead of `_ssl.sslwrap`?
ssl.wrap_socket expects 'keyfile' and 'certfile', you can't pass a directory.
AFAICS, the situation will improve with Python-3.3, where the ssl module will pick OS defaults by itself: http://bugs.python.org/issue14780
Sounds good to me.
actually, wait, I think this is not going to work, because `urllib3` uses `ssl.wrap_socket`, not `_ssl.sslwrap`.
So if `wrap_socket` does not understand directories, then our code will not either.
See `VerifiedHTTPSConnection` in this file: `requests/packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py`.
So be it, then the fallback file is used

Well, it seems like there are two possibilities:

1.
`ssl.wrap_socket` suports (without documentation) passing a directory instead of a file as its `ca_certs` parameter.

In that case, this patch is correct, except that it should use `ssl.wrap_socket` instead of `_ssl.sslwrap` (since that is a more accurate test of whether Requests will work with CA certificate directories).
`ssl.wrap_socket` does not suport this, despite the backing function `_ssl.sslwrap` suporting it.

In that case, there is no hope of Requests ever being able to use a certificate directory, and this patch should just be the one-line addition of `/etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem` as a possible CA certificate bundle file.
Have you observed Requests to work correctly with `/etc/ssl/certs` on your system?
Thanks for your patience by the way :-)

Hi, sorry for the delay, I did the following to test it:

```python
>>> import ssl,socket,pprint
>>> ssl_sock = ssl.wrap_socket(s,cert_reqs=ssl.CERT_REQUIRED,ca_certs='/etc/ssl/certs')
>>> ssl_sock.connect(('www.verisign.com', 443))
>>> print repr(ssl_sock.getpeername())
('69.58.181.89', 443)
>>> print ssl_sock.cipher()
('DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA', 'TLSv1/SSLv3', 256)
>>> print pprint.pformat(ssl_sock.getpeercert())
{'notAfter': 'May 17 23:59:59 2014 GMT',
 'subject': ((('1.3.6.1.4.1.311.60.2.1.3', u'US'),),
             (('1.3.6.1.4.1.311.60.2.1.2', u'Delaware'),),
             (('businessCategory', u'Private Organization'),),
             (('serialNumber', u'2158113'),),
             (('countryName', u'US'),),
             (('postalCode', u'94043'),),
             (('stateOrProvinceName', u'California'),),
             (('localityName', u'Mountain View'),),
             (('streetAddress', u'350 Ellis Street'),),
             (('organizationName', u'Symantec Corporation'),),
             (('organizationalUnitName', u'Infrastructure Operations'),),
             (('commonName', u'www.verisign.com'),)),
 'subjectAltName': (('DNS', 'verisign.com'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.net'),
                    ('DNS', 'verisign.net'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.mobi'),
                    ('DNS', 'verisign.mobi'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.eu'),
                    ('DNS', 'verisign.eu'),
                    ('DNS', 'www.verisign.com'))}
>>> ssl_sock.write("""GET / HTTP/1.0\rHOST: www.verisign.com\r\n\r\n""")
41
>>> data = ssl_sock.read()
>>> data
'HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently\r\nDate: Wed, 06 Jun 2012 14:51:17 GMT\r\nServer: Apache\r\nLocation: https://www.verisign.com/\r\nCac
he-Control: max-age=2592000\r\nExpires: Fri, 06 Jul 2012 14:51:17 GMT\r\nVary: Accept-Encoding\r\nContent-Length: 233\r\nConnection: c
lose\r\nContent-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1\r\n\r\n'
>>> ssl_sock.ca_certs
'/etc/ssl/certs'
>>> ssl_sock.close()
```

So, I assume "1."
Changing the check to ssl.wrap_socket won't change much, ssl.SSLSocket (returned by ssl.wrap_socket) uses _ssl.sslwrap internally (have a look at /usr/lib64/python2.7/ssl.py).
Finally, requests.models.Request has "conn.ca_certs = cert_loc = DEFAULT_CA_BUNDLE_PATH", thus passing a path works for me ;-)
Excellent, I believe that 1 is in fact the case.

I would greatly prefer it if the patch could use `ssl.wrap_socket` instead of `_ssl.sslwrap`, though, for the following reasons:

1.

The behavior that Requests will actually take advantage of is the ability of `ssl.wrap_socket` to use a directory as its `ca_certs`, so it is a more direct test of the required functionality
2.
since `_ssl.sslwrap` is not part of the public API, it's possible (although unlikely) that it might be renamed or moved in future.
It seems much better to use undocumented behavior of the public API than to use an (also undocumented) private API.

The intended meaning of `DEFAULT_CA_BUNDLE_PATH` was "fully qualified path", not "a directory as opposed to a file" :-)

Thanks again!
Sorry about the delay, I think I missed the GitHub notification.
I agree that using ssl.wrap_socket would be much better.
however, ssl.wrap_socket does not complain about invalid parameters (by throwing an SSLError exception like _ssl.sslwrap), only ssl.SSLSocket.connect() does.
So, doing the check with ssl.wrap_socket would actually include a real request, e.g.

like this:

```diff
--- a/requests/utils.py
+++ b/requests/utils.py
@@ -15,7 +15,6 @@ import os
 import re
 import socket
 import ssl
-import _ssl
 import zlib
 from netrc import netrc, NetrcParseError
 
@@ -57,7 +56,9 @@ def get_os_ca_bundle_path():
             if os.path.isdir(path):
                 try:
                     # Current candidate is a directory, check if SSL module suports that
-                    _ssl.sslwrap(socket.socket()._sock, False, None, None, ssl.CERT_REQUIRED, ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv23, path, None)
+                    ssl.wrap_socket(socket.socket(),cert_reqs=ssl.CERT_REQUIRED,ca_certs=path)
+                    ssl_sock.connect(('www.verisign.com', 443))
+
                     return path
                 except:
                     pass # No suport, let's check the next candidate
```

I don't think this is really desired but I don't see any other way to it ATM.
What do you think?
I'm sorry I'm such a pedant, but the use of `_ssl` still make s me uncomfortable.
If you're continuing to ship `/etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem` for compatibility, could we just use that?
Yes, that would be an options for the time being and in order to get this solved, I'll provide a stripped down patch, deal?
But this may become an issue again, as /etc/ssl/ca-bundle.pem is long time deprecated ;-)
Deal.
There you go, I updated the commit
This pull request [fails](http://travis-ci.org/kennethreitz/requests/builds/1626932) (merged 14e22d14 into 08ac9897).
This pull request [fails](http://travis-ci.org/kennethreitz/requests/builds/1627258) (merged 66ef8886 into 08ac9897).
travisbot is crap
Travisbot is wonderful, my tests are broken :)
This pull request [passes](http://travis-ci.org/kennethreitz/requests/builds/1734043) (merged 66ef8886 into 08ac9897).
Thanks!

title: Render content-type text/html for json responses when application/json is not in HTTP_ACCEPT header
body:
(PD) Some browsers won't send the application/json mime-type to HTTP_ACCEPT header when dealing with some tricks to enable Ajax file uploads:

https://github.com/blueimp/jQuery-File-Upload/wiki/Setup#content-type-negotiation

It would be interesting if Rails could take care of it transparently by checking for the HTTP_ACCEPT header before rendering a JSON response with the 'application/json' content-type.
(PD) When 'application/json' is missing in the header the json content would be rendered as 'text/html' for better compatibility.
How does that sound like?

title: Output handling for Background Processes
body: Right now, if you start a background process with ``Process::start()`` and then in random time intervals call ``getOutput()`` or ``getErrorOutput()`` it is always returning the entire output.
(PD) I would expect it to return only the new output since the last call.
(MD) Alternatively, we could also think about adding a separate method which only returns the incremental output.
(P) This is what the [optional callback](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/master/src/Symfony/Component/Process/Process.php#L145) allows to do: getting the output little by little
So, even if you pass a callback, it simply would never be called.
I was under the impression that this was the intended behavior, at least according to the API docs.
(P) A `getIncrementalOutput ` function wouldn't be a bad addition, however.
(P) I will need this so i would like to start working on this yes or yes

title: Refactor keytime/metadata and wallet encryption bugfix
body:
Refactor keytime:
* Key metadata is kept in a CWallet::mapKeyMetadata (std::map< CKeyID, CKeyMetadata>).
* When generating a new key, time is put in that map, and new key is written.

(PD) * AddKeyPubKey and AddCryptedKey do not take a creation time argument, but instead
  pull it from that map, if it exists there.

(PD)  bugfix:
* AddKeyPubKey and AddCryptedKey in CWallet didn't override the CKeyStore
  definition anymore.

(PD) This is fixed, as they no longed need the nCreationTime
  argument now.

(PD) Also a few related other changes:
* Metadata can be overwritten.

* Only GenerateNewKey calls GetTime(), as it's the only place where we know for
  sure a key was not constructed earlier.

(PD) * When the nTimeFirstKey is known to be inaccurate, it is set to the value 1
  (instead of 0, which would mean unknown).
(PD) * Use CPubKey instead of std::vector< unsigned char> where possible.
(PD) fixes #2779 and #2780

title: Remove symmetric Math.log.
body: (PD) since Math.log is a monotonic function for positive values, we can safely remove the Math.log from both sides of the comparison.
(MD) The reason Math.log was used previously is that this is an estimate of error (the log difference between the desired number of ticks and the actual number of ticks).
Empty

title: Nested SpotLight's Shadows
body: Lets take a light to be a THREE.SpotLight which is casting shadow.
(MD) Looks like I'll have to unnest the spot light and apply transformations manually?
Hmmm, I made lights take into account scene graph for shading but I forgot about shadows, these use local positions.
(W) I'll need to look into this.

(P) This should fix the issue:

https://github.com/alteredq/three.js/commit/74a9e249eee47bfe7b5efd13cdc58d06a0d035d6
(P) Thanks, fix verified with a quick test!
:D

title: ofVec2f::average not checking if one of the params is zero.

inline ofVec2f& ofVec2f::average( const ofVec2f* points, int num )

num could come come in as zero.
(PD) need to check if zero and handle.
https://github.com/openframeworks/openFrameworks/blob/master/libs/openFrameworks/math/ofVec2f.h#L609-619
Empty

title: fix rabbitmq build on 10.5 (single commit this time)
body: (PD) Rabbitmq fails to build on 10.5 because it relies on "cp -a", but this flag does not exist on 10.5.
(PD) It is fixed upstream, but has not yet made it out to a release.
(PD) This applies the same fix.
(PD) because of the way the rabbitmq tree is setup I could not directly apply that diff, so I've included in slightly different one that will apply cleanly to the release version.
(PD) Presumably once 2.7.2 gets released this patch can be safely dropped.
(MD) Here's the corresponding commit in the official tree: https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-public-umbrella/commit/b46edc7433b499a73531b04ba9af5d860b33737c
Thanks, pulled.

title: qemu 1.0
body:
(PD) Upgraded qemu version to 1.0
There is a problem when installing QEMU on a case-insensitive file system, solved on http://rubenerd.com/qemu-1-failing-macosx/

So I included In the formula the patch inline http://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/123112/
Thanks!
(P) For future reference You don't need to create another pull request, just force-push into the same branch.
Has this been reported upstream?
@adamv: It looks like that is the upstream mailing list discussion.
(M) Formula should have a comment "can be removed in version xxx", etc.
This should be tested to see if the `fails_with_llvm` bit is still true; see https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/issues/8445

title: fix issue #848 : broken mining on testnet
body: (PD) This is just a refactor on main-net (new updateTime() method to avoid duplication of GetMedianTimePast() math).
(PD) On testnet it fixes miners getting invalid blocks if they mine across the 20-minute "switch to minimum difficulty" rule that is new with 0.6.
ACK

title: Chmodding to 0666 & ~umask() doesn't always respect ACL
body: (WD) In several places, Symfony creates a temporary file with `tempnam()`, renames it and chmods it to `0666 & ~umask()` (this string can be grepped).

(WD) But when the `app/cache` directory is created with `chmod +a` or `setfacl` as per [the docs](http://symfony.com/doc/current/book/installation.html#configuration-and-setup), the created file will be writable only by its creator.
(WD) for example if the dir is `setfacl`'d to be writable by `smith` and `www-data`, files that `www-data` creates by this method will only be writable by `www-data`.

(WD) This isn't a problem in normal operation, because if `smith` tries to create the file by the same method, the rename() is allowed to overwrite the old version even if it can't write into the file.
(PD) But it can cause issues if `smith` wants to edit the file manually with a text editor, etc.
(PD) So this is low priority, but it should be fixed if possible.
(PD) To explain why the current method doesn't work, I need to explain how ACLs work in general.
Sorry about the length.

(PD) **Permissions of a newly created file:**

Step 1: If the parent directory has a "default ACL" (essentially a template for new files inside it), use it as the new file's ACL.
(PD) otherwise, set the ACL to "everyone can do everything except stuff that's forbidden by the umask".
(PD) Step 2: Look at the "mode" argument of the function that's creating the file (open, creat, mkdir, ...) and when a bit is missing from the mode, also remove it from the ACL.
(E.g.
when mode is 0666, nobody will be able execute it.)

(PD) The mode's first octal digit is about the file owner, and the third digit is about "others" (everyone not matched by any ACL rule), but the second number is a bit special: it's not just for the file group, it's a mask that covers all rules except the "owner" rule and the "others" rule.
(PD) So if you open("file", O_CREAT, 0644), it takes the default ACL, and it removes "x" from the "owner" rule and "wx" from all the other rules.

**What this means for Symfony:**

When Symfony does `0666 & ~umask()`, this isn't quite right.
(PD) That's because as you'll notice above, when a directory has default ACL, umask doesn't enter the equation at all.
(PD) The OS just uses the default ACL.
(PD) If you chmod a file to `0644` and the file's ACL contains `u:www-data:rw-`, it'll effectively be just `r--`.
(PD) Plus, this can actually give someone more privileges than they should have: If the default ACL says "others have no access", chmodding to `0666 & ~022` would allow "others" to read the file.

(PD) (Perhaps this is a bigger problem than the above "text editor" example...)

PHP has no functions for manipulating ACLs, so I think the only way to fix this is by completely avoiding chmod.
(PD) And that means avoiding tempnam and just creating the file directly.
(PD) (Perhaps you could use tempnam to generate a random filename, then delete it, then recreate it with normal permissions, but that seems a little too hacky.)

(PD) What might be an issue is that tempnam has some nice exclusivity guarantees - maybe losing them would be a bigger problem than what this is trying to solve (which is, admittedly, very low priority)?
I don't know.
(WD) Uh, thanks for reading through all of this.
(WD) Sorry that I don't have a better solution :-|

title: Apphook URL "reloading"
body: (PD) As we all know, adding (or removing) an apphook, moving a page with an apphook, or change the slug of a page with an apphook or any of it's parents will cause URL resolving issues.

(PD) For now, a server restart was required and the fact that we don't know the deployment methods of users we can't come up with a generic solution (sidenote: on djeese we solved this because we know exactly how things are deployed, so this IS automatable).

(PD) So here's the idea, introduce two new APIs to django CMS core:

* A signal that will be fired when apphook URLs need to be reloaded.
(MD) * A function to reload apphook URLs **in the current thread**.
(PD) **Outside** the CMS developers can then use those to implement automated systems for their deployment scenario.
(PD) One such thing (and potentially the "example implementation") could be a redis powered app, where each thread/process (hereafter process) listens to a redis channel.
(MD) When the signal is fired on any process, it publishes a message in a redis channel and reloads its URLs.
(PD) All other processes will receive the message and reload their URLs.
(PD) The beauty is this would work on a single server and a multi server environment.
(PD) Again, this is just an example and should really not be in core.

(PD Benefits from the current solution:

* Server restart not necessarily required
* since core doesn't implement anything, it should be possible to build a solution on top of it for almost any deployment strategy.

(PD) Drawbacks from the current solution:

* Two new APIs to implement.
(PD) The apphook-change-detection-signal is rather trivial, the actual hotswapping of apphook URLs is a lot trickier

title: [Validator] StaticMethodLoader invokes wrong method
body: As per request of @fabpot I opened this issue.
(PD) The problem is like in #3179 but with abstract classes instead interfaces.
(PD) I described the problem and a possible sollution in that issue in a [comment](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/issues/3179#issuecomment-21629618).
(P) @fabpot, this fix is probably wrong.
(P) In #3179 is a call of a static interface method described, which is definitely not possible in PHP, but a call of a static method of a abstract class is possible.
(P) So, I believe `isAbstract` needs to be replaced with `isInterface`.
(P) And to fix the issue of ntomka's comment, there should be a `isAbstract` check on `$reflMethod`.

title: fix ImplicitRendering for BasicRendering
body: When using `BasicRendering` you're obligated to invoke render explicitly in action method.

(PD) Before that fix, if you had controller like this:

    class PagesController < ApplicationController
      def index
      end
    end

following error was raised:

    NoMethodError in PagesController#index

    undefined method `has_key?'

(PD) for nil:NilClass

After this change user will be instructed what to do with clear message:

    ActionController::BasicRendering::NoRenderError in PagesController#index

    BasicRendering requires controller action to invoke `render` method explicitly,
    with :text or :nothing option.
(PD) For more, you need to include ActionView.
(M) Why can't `:nothing` be implicit if, well, nothing is explicitly rendered?
(W) Oh well, to be honest, I didn't thought of that and I don't know now which in which way it should be implemented now.
(P) Even if `:nothing` should be rendered, I think it would be nice to have code from this PR to disable `ImplictRender` if needed for some reason.
What do you thing about it @drogus ?
I think that raising an error is better in such situation.
When you use Rails with action view, it will render corresponding view - rendering empty response may be misleading and I don't think it's a good default.
(P) I think I tend to like exception over `:nothing` solution more as well.
I've added commits making error classes from `BasicRendering` more common and not tied to `BasicRendering` namespace.

Looks good to me

/cc @rafaelfranca @spastorino @carlosantoniodasilva
@strzalek can you squash your commits?
(P) About squashing the commits - I think that the last 3 could be squashed, but the first one should be separate, it's dealing with 2 separate things actually
(W) I wanted to write the same but @drogus was faster :dancers: I'll rebase in a moment & check why travis is failing on this.
(P) Rebase and fixed small issue.
Should be green on travis now.
(P) @josevalim I agree with you that ImplicitRender should be called only when... it's included.

(P) But to make  so, it should be then moved to ActionView and included when AV is included and here, again, we have module order issue (https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/actionpack/lib/action_controller/base.rb#L231)
Besides from the comments you've already received.
Looks good :+1:
@spastorino thanks for reviewing!
@drogus do you have idea how to easily achieve this differently, like @josevalim described?
I'm closing this for now.
The direction is to not touch ImplicitRendering and move BasicRendering to renderers.
I'll cherry-pick commit collecting errors in one place later though as I think it's worth to have in pulled in.

title: Decouple actionpack and actionview
body: This is preparation before extracting Action View from Action Pack.
(PD) Initially I went with extracting up-front, but @jeremy advised me to do changes first and then extract when everything is ready (which in fact is much better strategy).
The commits in this pull request basically get rid of Action Pack classes usage from Action View.
(PD) One of the problems that I want to ask about are deprecation messages.

(PD) I deprecated 2 things here (moving `RecordIdentifier` to Action View and mime type lookups in auto discovery link tag) to follow rule "Deprecate in 4.0, remove in 4.1" instead deprecating in 3.2.x and removing in 4.0, but this means that we will be able to extract Action View no sooner than 4.1.
(PD) Those deprecations will not be probably hit by many people, so I would like to consider moving them to `3-2-stable`, but I'm not sure about that.
/cc @spastorino @rafaelfranca @josevalim @carlosantoniodasilva

(P) If we want to avoid an AM dependency in AV, better to just have separate, duplicate ModelNaming modules in AV and AC.

(P) (I know you know this, just giving context for people who may read the ticket who don't.)

title: Rebind returns target when the source returns itself
body: (MD) The logic is as follows:  If a rebound function returns the source object, we should return the target object, even when no arguments were supplied.
(MD) Example:   If I rebind a dispatch object to a target object and call a dispatch function with no argument, it will return the target, not the dispatch object, allowing for proper chaining.
(P) I think I'd probably do one or the other, so if we switch to `value === source`, then use that exclusively instead of the arguments.length check.
(P) It seems reasonable, although it would help to have a concrete (code) example of why you want this functionality.
(P) I can't think of any places in the D3 API where this would change the behavior.
The particular usage case I had in mind was rebinding action dispatches (such as resize, redraw etc).

(M) Please see lines 15-17 of the following file for an example: https://github.com/ZJONSSON/dpl/blob/incorp_set/src/core/frame.js
If I use original d3.rebind and call frame.render() without arguments, I get the dispatch object, not the frame object.
Looks good.

title: Stateful bolts
body: (MD) This is an idea to build abstractions for bolts with fault-tolerant state (so if a task dies and gets reassigned to another machine it still has its state).
(PD) The idea is to use a similar strategy as HBase uses: Append changes to local state into a file on a DFS, and occasionally compact the file on the DFS.
(MD) This would be easier to use and more efficient than using an external database like Cassandra.
(PD) This abstraction is actually independent to Storm, it should be done as a separate project or in storm-contrib.
(PD) It does require a DFS with append functionality, which more recent versions of HDFS might provide (or MapR might provide it).
(MD) Having a pluggable scheduler can help with this as well.
(MD) The first version should just keep all the state in memory, using the DFS just for reliability.
This is a good idea.
What is it that currently occurs when a bolt task fails?
Does the source spout re-emit the tuple?

(W) Some questions for implementation: 
What happens while you are  re-initiating the bolt with the previous one's state?
Will you pause all threads in the topology or will you temporarily increase the timeout for processing a tuple?
I am not sure how long it would take to re-start a bolt with state, but it could trigger a fail(), causing a replay.

From the API side:
Does this mean that the prepare() method will not be called?
(W) And finally, will this be optional or seamlessly integrated?
Thank You
The tuple trees that are made incomplete due to the bolt task failure will time-out and the spout will be able to replay the source tuple for that tree.
Tuples that have already successfully completed will not be replayed.
(P) So generally you keep any persistent state in a database, oftentimes doing something like waiting to ack tuples until you've done a batch update to the database.
(P) Stateful bolts will just be a much more efficient way of keeping a large amount of state at hand in a bolt.
Good point regarding reinitialization.
(P) The first implementation will target amounts of state that can fit into memory, so reinitialization time won't be a concern.
Once we look at doing much larger amounts of state we'll revisit this question.
This is orthogonal to the prepare method being called.
(P) The prepare method is called whenever a task starts up in a worker, regardless if it existed before in another worker.
(W) This will most definitely be optional.
(W) actually, I think this will end up being a storm-contrib submodule.
Is this issue outdated as of: https://github.com/stormprocessor/storm-state ?
(W) Should it be closed then?
Has anybody tested storm-state in a big setup?
Is there a corresponding backing State for Trident?

title: Cleaning up brew doctor errors
body:
(WD) Here is my ```brew doctor```:

    If you have installed MacGPG2 via the package installer, several other
    checks in this script will turn up problems, such as stray .dylibs in
    /usr/local and permissions issues with share and man in /usr/local/.
(WD) Unbrewed dylibs were found in /usr/local/lib.

(WD) If you didn't put them there on purpose they could cause problems when
    building Homebrew formulae, and may need to be deleted.

Unexpected dylibs:
            /usr/local/lib/libcharset.1.dylib
            /usr/local/lib/libiconv.2.dylib
So I tried removing those two files ```/usr/local/lib/libcharset.1.dylib``` and ```/usr/local/libiconv.2.dylib``` from the ```/usr/local/lib``` folder.

Problem is, when I run the ```brew doctor``` command, I get this:

    Error: No such file or directory - /usr/local/lib/libcharset.1.dylib

The same thing happens when I move the file ```/usr/local/lib/libiconv.2.dylib```

    Error: No such file or directory - /usr/local/lib/libiconv.2.dylib

Any idea how I can use Homebrew to look in the ```Cellar``` directory for those files so I can delete them from ```/usr/local/lib``` ?

(WD) I tried the ```brew link libiconv``` command, but here's the error I got:

    Linking /usr/local/Cellar/libiconv/1.13.1... ln: ./iconvctl.3.html: Permission denied
    Error: Could not create symlink /usr/local/share/doc/libiconv/iconvctl.3.html.

(WD) check that you have permssions on /usr/local/share/doc/libiconv

Now that scared me off, because I don't know what I'm doing.
(MD) I was going to do ```sudo brew link libiconv```, but I hesitated and decided to wait to hear from you guys.

(PD) I also tried ```brew link libcharset```, but here's the error:

    Error: No such keg: /usr/local/Cellar/libcharset

just so you know, my ```brew list``` shows I have libiconv installed:

    cmake 		libgcrypt	        libiconv	msmtp		weechat
    gnutls	    libgpg-error	    libtasn1	pkg-config	wget

I even tried installing libcharset:

    Error: No available formula for libcharset

Any ideas what I should do to clean up my ```brew doctor``` while making everything work?

(PD) tldr: try fixing your permissions: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/wiki/checklist-before-filing-a-new-issue then attempt to uninstall / reinstall libiconv --- re:
I even tried installing libcharset:
you can find the available formula here: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/tree/master/Library/Formula/ i recommend cloning the repo, then you can browse the directory.

(PD) ---

re: libcharset
an easy, hacky, way to investigate is to run:

```
% sudo /usr/libexec/locate.updatedb
% locate libcharset
```

(tangent: i like to set `alias updatedb="sudo /usr/libexec/locate.updatedb"`)

then:

```
% brew info libiconv
libiconv 1.13.1
http://www.gnu.org/software/libiconv/
/usr/local/Cellar/libiconv/1.13.1 (24 files, 1.4M)
http://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/commits/master/Library/Formula/libiconv.rb
```

if you take a look at the file you'll see it's `keg_only`, meaning it's internal to homebrew: https://raw.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/master/Library/Formula/libiconv.rb

essentially it shouldn't be in /usr/local/lib at all, most other installed packages should still reference /usr/lib/* for consistency, whereas homebrew packages will find the newer version.

(PD) ```
% ls -1 /usr/local/Cellar/libiconv/1.13.1/lib/
charset.alias
libcharset.1.dylib
libcharset.a
libcharset.dylib
libiconv.2.dylib
libiconv.dylib
% ls /usr/local/lib/libic*
zsh: no matches found: /usr/local/lib/libic*
% ls /usr/local/lib/libchr*
zsh: no matches found: /usr/local/lib/libchr*
```

(P) Ok, I did the following:
* fixed my permissions
* Ran ```sudo /usr/libexec/locate.updatedb```
* Uninstalled libiconv
* Installed libiconv
* Ran ```brew doctor```

however, the files are still there and ```brew doctor``` looks the same:

    >_ ls /usr/local/lib/libch*
    /usr/local/lib/libcharset.1.dylib
    >_ ls /usr/local/lib/libic*
    /usr/local/lib/libiconv.2.dylib

(P)
* Ran sudo /usr/libexec/locate.updatedb
note that's just to refresh the database for the `locate` command if you find it useful, nothing to do with homebrew.

* http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Darwin/Reference/ManPages/man1/locate.1.html#//apple_ref/doc/man/1/locate
* http://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Darwin/Reference/ManPages/man8/locate.updatedb.8.html

---

these files:

* /usr/local/lib/libcharset.1.dylib
* /usr/local/lib/libiconv.2.dylib

aren't being managed by brew (or at least shouldn't be).
`brew doctor` is saying it doesn't know what to do with them.
since we don't know why they're there to begin with, what are the modification times of the relevant files in /usr/local/lib?
are they old?
are they symlinks?
now look at /usr/local/Cellar/libiconv/1.13.1/lib.
(W) are they new, correlating to the time that you did your update?

(W) and as a precaution, check the system install of these _which should not be modified_ are still there:

* /usr/lib/libcharset.

*
* /usr/lib/libiconv.

title: Pull folder change

(PD) I know this may very well be a patch you will not like, but I think this behavior is more intuitiv and general.

<path>/some/different/place</path> // optional, Parent path on <= 0.9 and the actual path on > 0.9

Already downloaded: /Library/Caches/Homebrew/git-1.8.0.1.tar.gz
==> make  prefix=/usr/local/Cellar/git/1.8.0.1 CC=cc CFLAGS= LDFLAGS= install
/usr/bin/python setup.py install --prefix /usr/local/Cellar/git/1.8.0.1
running install
error: must supply either prefix/exec-prefix/home or install-base/install-platbase -- not both
make [1]: *** [install] Error 1
make : *** [install] Error 2

read THIS: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/wiki/troubleshooting

These open issues may also help:
    https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/issues/11481
    https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/issues/15711
    https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/issues/16194

Is this a bug?
Or is it something I did wrong?
Did you see this?
(P) >read THIS: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/wiki/troubleshooting
(W) OK, sorry I didn't read the link throughly...
I'm surprised there are so many issues when I run 'brew doctor'.
(P) Anyway, after I solved those issues git can be installed without problem.
Thanks.

title: improve x-domain detection
body: (PD) Right now cross domain jsonp suport requires you to specify longPolling and an xdomain flag.
(P) fixed in 96c43b99124db64a81de1bc21857d24f85584ec7
(W) This does not work in IE8.
(W) link.host returns domain:port (even if the port is 80) in IE8, where as window.location.host returns just domain.
Consequently every URL is detected as an xdomain URL in IE8.
Which brings up an interesting question as to how to detect a true cross-domain call.
(W) since a legitimately different port would indeed count as a cross-domain call, I'm not sure yet how to fix this.
(P) @SpaghettiMonster can you file a new bug specifically for IE8 (probably IE < 9)

title: updated all Bitcoin developers copyrights to 2013
body: (WD) Leaving copyrights by others (e.g.
Satoshi, The LevelDB Authors) alone.
(P) ACK, though don't see the need for two commits, rather than one.

(W) I did the first edit with the Github editor, before I knew how many files
there were to change.

Once I understood the scope of it, I had to clone it
locally and bust out sed.

On Sat, Feb 2, 2013 at 9:27 PM, Jeff Garzik <notifications@github.com>wrote:

> ACK, though don't see the need for two commits, rather than one.

>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub<https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/2266#issuecomment-13042666>.
(M) NACK, please never ever touch the translation files ;), see #2251.
(P) Alright, it looks like there's a better pull request open anyway that's going to solve the problem with all the translations needing to be changed anyway.

title: Removing events in d3.dispatch by name only
body: (PD) When attaching several listeners of different types with d3's `d3.dispatch`, it could be handy to just supply a name to `on('.foo', null)`.
(W) Regardless of whether behavior’s get an unbind method, it seems useful to have this functionality as well.
(P) in fact, I’d prefer to suport this initially, so staging for 3.1.
Staged in #1120.

title: Allow `brew upgrade` to upgrade specified formulae (or all formulae if none given).
body: Allow `brew upgrade` to upgrade specified formulae (or all formulae if none given).
I hacked this together with pretty much no Ruby experience, but it tests okay for me.
(PD) Feel free to improve any sub-standard code.
:P
@mxcl - @mikemcquaid - I thought `brew upgrade` already upgraded everything with no arguments.
It does.
(P) I thought it was weird that I couldn't use the upgrade command to selectively upgrade formulae, so I added the ability.
Doesn't `brew install --force` effectively do an upgrade if one is available?
(P) It will do the existing install over again, otherwise, so one needs to check first, e.g.
`brew info`.
Well, yeah.
Yes `brew install --force` does the same thing.
And `brew install $(brew outdated)` does the same thing as `brew upgrade`.
`brew upgrade` is already an alternative command.
(P) I just wanted to offer this alternative command a bit more flexibility akin to the core commands.
(P) I'm redoing this command to be pushed soon, so I'll just (make  SURE) this works with the new command.
But thanks.

title: Virtual timer expired errors and test hangs
body:
(WD) Okay, this bug report sucks at the moment, but after upgrading to 3-1-stable on 1.9.2 I started getting "Virtual timer expired" errors at the end of my test run:


    $ b rspec spec
    No DRb server is running.

Finished in 9.57 seconds
    220 examples, 0 failures
    Virtual timer expired

Exit code is 154.
(WD) Also, sometimes my tests hang indefinitely and I need to Ctrl+C to kill them.
Trying to investigate more, but in the meantime maybe someone with the same issue will add more info.
(W) @brynary Is this still an issue, or can this be closed?
(P) since we don't have any anwser in these 2 months I'll close this issue.
@brynary if this is still happening please feel free to ask to reopen.

title: Remove the options class, replacing it with a hash.
body: (PD) The options class helped to clean up the large smattering of instance variables strewn about the attachment class, but it had a few downsides: plugins didn't have a way to hook into it to get their options out, it had a complex `method_missing` method, and the other methods didn't belong there---it was used as a collection of functions instead of relevant behavior on data.
(PD) This pull request replaces the options class with a hash.
Empty

title: Files not sync but SpakleShare doesn't see
body: I put new files in my directory, but not all of them have been sync on the repository.
(WD) When I check recent events, I see that the files has been added but they don't appear on the repository.
So my local directory and the repository are not synced any more, is there a way to force syncing ?
(P) I found that : git diff master origin/master show differences and by using : git push, everything is synced now.
(M) Maybe custom backend will handle that issue.

title: uv_init() for linux where is it?
body:
(WD) Hi All,
I am fairly new with libuv and I was wondering where is uv_init() from the unix version.
(WD) I was trying to maybe upgrade to a newer version of libuv from an older version is it possible?

But of course there is no uv_init to begin with it appears this must be a fairly old version

Any help is appreciated
(P) uv_init is gone, you don't need to call it anymore :-)
What @saghul said.
Thats great may I ask what method should be called on linux to kick everything off?
uv_run?
There is nothing special to be called on Linux.
(P) just setup all the handles you want and start the loop with uv_run.
(P) You may want to have a look at uvbook: http://nikhilm.github.com/uvbook/index.html

title: BRPOPLPUSH replication failure during 'make  test'
body:
(WD) 'make  test' reported a single error after I compiled Redis 2.4.11 last night:


    !!!

WARNING The following tests failed:
    
    *** [err]: BRPOPLPUSH replication, when blocking against empty list in tests/integration/replication.tcl
    Expected '0000000000000000000000000000000000000000' to be equal to 'e7fa6909b84f8f77daa04105afc12fd8d40c1314'
    Cleanup: may take some time... OK
    make [1]: *** [test] Error 1
    make [1]: Leaving directory `/opt/redis-2.4.11/src'
    make : *** [test] Error 2
    atlas:/opt/redis-2.4.11# 


I saw no warnings or errors while compiling the code.

(PD) I searched Google for this error, but only found 3 references:

http://ci.redis.io/run_144.html
http://ci.redis.io/run_139.html
http://ci.redis.io/run_123.html

Here is my relevant system information:

- Debian 5.0.6 (64-bit / x86-64)
- Linux kernel: 2.6.18-274.7.1.el5.028stab095.1
- gcc version 4.3.2 (Debian 4.3.2-1.1)

I will also mention that I am operating in an OpenVZ, virtualization container.

Can you file an issue on @gleitz's issue tracker?
Posted for gleitz earlier; will follow-up with him.

title: Mindfuck Install Fails with clang
body:
(PD) ```
~$ brew --config
HOMEBREW_VERSION: 0.9.4
ORIGIN: https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew
HEAD: 0d7e2792f2dc911b8acdd3ec400d319c278a9509
HOMEBREW_PREfix: /usr/local
HOMEBREW_CELLAR: /usr/local/Cellar
CPU: quad-core 64-bit sandybridge
OS X: 10.8.3-x86_64
Xcode: 4.6.2
CLT: 4.6.0.0.1.1365549073
GCC-4.2: build 5666
LLVM-GCC: build 2336
Clang: 4.2 build 425
X11: 2.7.4 => /opt/X11
System Ruby: 1.8.7-358
Perl: /usr/bin/perl
Python: /usr/local/bin/python => /usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.4/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/bin/python2.7
Ruby: /Users/parker/.rbenv/shims/ruby
~$ brew install brainfuck
==> Downloading https://github.com/FabianM/brainfuck/archive/0.1.2.tar.gz
######################################################################## 100.0%
==> make  all CC=cc CCFLAGS=
Building
mkdir -p bin
cc  -o /private/tmp/brainfuck-ynC3/brainfuck-0.1.2/bin/brainfuck /private/tmp/brainfuck-ynC3/brainfuck-0.1.2/src/*
clang: error: cannot specify -o when generating multiple output files
make : *** [all] Error 1
```

Looks like it needs to specify a different compiler?
Empty

title: Leiningen 2.2.0
body: Empty
By the way, I also noticed that the Homebrew formula doesn't install the zsh-completion that Leiningen provides.
It's a one-line addition, but would it be better for that to be in a separate pull-request regardless?
(P) just merge it into here
@adamv: done!
(P) I also rebased and swapped the order of the commits to make  it a little clearer that the zsh-completion was there all along.
